question_text:
A 27-year-old man is brought to the emergency department 30 minutes after being shot in the abdomen during a violent altercation. His temperature is 36.5°C (97.7°F), pulse is 118/min and regular, and blood pressure is 88/65 mm Hg. Examination shows cool extremities. Abdominal examination shows a 2.5-cm entrance wound in the left upper quadrant at the midclavicular line, below the left costal margin. Focused ultrasound shows free fluid in the left upper quadrant. Which of the following sets of hemodynamic changes is most likely in this patient?

Cardiac output (CO)
Pulmonary capillary wedge pressure (PCWP)
Systemic vascular resistance (SVR)
Central venous pressure (CVP)

A
↑
↓
↓
↓

B
↓
↓
↑
↓

C
↓
↓
↑
↑

D
↓
↓
↓
↓

E
↓
↑
↑
↑
content_preview: A 27-year-old man is brought to the emergency department 30 minutes after being shot in the abdomen during a violent altercation. His temperature is 36.5°C (97.7°F), pulse is 118/min and regular, and blood pressure is 88/65 mm Hg. Examination shows cool extremities. Abdominal examination shows a 2.5-cm entrance wound in the left upper quadrant at the midclavicular line, below the left costal margin. Focused ultrasound shows free fluid in the left upper quadrant. Which of the following sets of hemodynamic changes is most likely in this patient? Cardiac output (CO) Pulmonary capillary wedge pressure (PCWP) Systemic vascular resistance (SVR) Central venous pressure (CVP) A ↑ ↓ ↓ ↓ B ↓ ↓ ↑ ↓ C ↓ ↓ ↑ ↑ D ↓ ↓ ↓ ↓ E ↓ ↑ ↑ ↑
hint: The patient has many signs of hypovolemic shock, including evidence of bleeding, decreased blood pressure, rapid pulse, cool extremities, and free fluid in the abdomen.
learning_objective: Recognize hypovolemic shock, and recall its hemodynamic findings.

answers.explanation_why: The combination of ↑ CO, ↓ PCWP, ↓ SVR, and ↓ CVP is seen in some cases of distributive shock (e.g., early septic shock), not in hypovolemic shock. Distributive shock is sometimes referred to as warm shock because it involves inappropriate peripheral vasodilation (causing ↓ CVP, ↓ SVR, and thus ↓ PCWP) and increased CO, which leads to excessive blood delivery to the limbs, resulting in inappropriately warm limbs in a hypotensive patient. This patient's limbs are cool, which indicates appropriate peripheral vasoconstriction in an attempt to maintain adequate blood pressure. In addition, this patient has no history of infection that would predispose to septic shock.

The combination of ↓ CO, ↓ PCWP, ↑ SVR, and ↓ CVP is characteristic of hypovolemic shock (hemorrhagic shock). Hemorrhage (e.g., after a gunshot wound) leads to intravascular volume depletion, which decreases venous return to the right atrium (as evidenced by ↓ CVP). Reduced venous return to the right heart results in decreased blood delivery to the left atrium (evident in ↓ PCWP) and consequently low left ventricular end diastolic volume (i.e., decreased preload). Low preload causes decreased CO (because the heart cannot pump blood that is not there). Because low CO leads to hypotension, the peripheral vasculature constricts (↑ SVR) in an attempt to maintain blood pressure that is adequate for organ perfusion.

See “Overview of the types of shock” table.

The combination of ↓ CO, ↓ PCWP, ↑ SVR, and ↑ CVP is characteristic of obstructive shock (e.g., massive pulmonary embolism), not hypovolemic shock. In obstructive shock, blood flow from the right heart to the left heart is blocked, which causes blood to “back up” into the right atrium, causing increased CVP. Insufficient blood is delivered to the LA, leading to decreased LA pressure (and thus ↓ PCWP) and little preload for the LV (causing ↓ CO). Low CO results in hypotension, which induces peripheral vascular constriction (and thus ↑ SVR) in an attempt to maintain adequate blood pressure. This patient's history of a gunshot wound to the abdomen and free fluid in the abdomen suggest a different form of shock.

The combination of ↓ CO, ↓ PCWP, ↓ SVR, and ↓ CVP is seen in some cases of distributive shock (especially neurogenic shock), not in hypovolemic shock. Neurogenic shock typically results from severe CNS trauma (e.g., spinal cord transection) and is associated with other neurologic abnormalities (e.g., paralysis). Neurogenic shock is believed to be caused by loss of autonomic control of cardiovascular parameters due to CNS damage. Heart rate is characteristically low in neurogenic shock (likely due to excessive vagal tone), which leads to decreased CO. SVR is low because of peripheral vasodilation due to loss of sympathetic tone. Peripheral vasodilation causes decreased venous return to the heart, leading to low CVP and consequently low LA pressure (and thus low PCWP). This patient has no history or physical findings to suggest neurologic injury and he is tachycardic on examination.

The combination of ↓ CO, ↑ PCWP, ↑ SVR, and ↑ CVP is characteristic of cardiogenic shock, not hypovolemic shock. If the heart is unable to pump adequately, CO decreases. Blood then “backs up” into the left atrium, causing increased LA pressure (and thus ↑ PCWP). Increased LA pressure leads to increased right heart pressures, causing high CVP. Because decreased CO leads to hypotension, the peripheral vasculature constricts (↑ SVR) in an attempt to maintain blood pressure that is adequate for organ perfusion. This patient has no history to suggest a pump dysfunction (e.g., history of heart failure or arrhythmia) that would predispose to cardiogenic shock.

question_text: A 68-year-old man is brought to the emergency department because of a severe headache, nausea, and vomiting for 30 minutes. Forty-five minutes ago, he fell and struck his head, resulting in loss of consciousness for 1 minute. After regaining consciousness, he felt well for 15 minutes before the headache began. On arrival, the patient becomes rigid and his eyes deviate to the right; he is incontinent of urine. Intravenous lorazepam is administered and the rigidity resolves. Which of the following is the most likely cause of the patient's condition?
content_preview: A 68-year-old man is brought to the emergency department because of a severe headache, nausea, and vomiting for 30 minutes. Forty-five minutes ago, he fell and struck his head, resulting in loss of consciousness for 1 minute. After regaining consciousness, he felt well for 15 minutes before the headache began. On arrival, the patient becomes rigid and his eyes deviate to the right; he is incontinent of urine. Intravenous lorazepam is administered and the rigidity resolves. Which of the following is the most likely cause of the patient's condition?
hint: After sustaining a head injury and briefly losing consciousness, the patient experienced a brief asymptomatic period (a lucid interval), followed by signs and symptoms of elevated intracranial pressure (headache, nausea, vomiting, and seizure).
learning_objective: Recognize an epidural hematoma.

answers.explanation_why: Intracerebral hemorrhage typically results from a spontaneous (i.e., nontraumatic) rupture of vessels secondary to structural changes of the vessel walls, e.g., in chronic hypertension or cerebral amyloid angiopathy. Patients present with headache and focal neurologic deficits such as hemiparesis. Rarely, it is caused by a head trauma with direct damage of the vessel. Signs of increased ICP and a lucid interval are more suggestive of another diagnosis.

images.title: Intracerebral hematoma
images.description: CT head (without contrast; axial plane)A large hyperdense hematoma (green overlay) in the posterior aspect of the left cerebral hemisphere is accompanied by hypodense edema (red overlay), effacement of the occipital horn of the left lateral ventricle, and midline shift (dashed line and arrowheads).ROH: right occipital horn

answers.explanation_why: A mismatch between production and absorption of CSF is the cause of idiopathic intracranial hypertension, which usually presents with chronic headaches and visual symptoms (e.g., transient loss of vision) that worsen over months to years. It is not associated with head trauma.

images.title: Optic disc edema
images.description: Fundus photography of the left eyeLeft image: Blurred disc margins (green overlay) with venous dilatation and tortuosity (blue overlay) and small hemorrhages (examples indicated by arrowheads) are visible.Blurred disc margins suggest optic disc edema. In intracranial hypertension, as seen in this image, optic disc edema is called papilledema.Right image: Resolution of optic disc edema after treatment. Sharp disc margins and normal retinal vessels are visible. There are no hemorrhages.

answers.explanation_why: Rupture of bridging veins causes subdural hematoma (SDH). The onset of symptoms in patients with subdural hematoma depends on the size, location, and rate of growth of the SDH. In acute-onset SDH, the patient can also present with headache and signs of increased ICP immediately following head trauma. In rare cases, patients may also experience a lucid interval. However, the temporary recovery of consciousness is more commonly associated with a different diagnosis.

images.title: Subdural hematoma and cerebral edema
images.description: CT head (without IV contrast; axial section; brain window) of a patient with a history of traumaA large acute subdural hematoma is visible as a hyperdense crescent-shaped lesion along the lateral aspect of the left hemisphere (red overlay). It is accompanied by an extracranial soft tissue hematoma (hatched red overlay). There is extensive hypodense left cerebral edema (gray overlay), with sulcal effacement and shift of midline structures (green line) to the right. The anterior horns of the lateral ventricles (hatched green overlay) are compressed and the posterior horn of the right lateral ventricle (red circle) is dilated.

answers.content: Acute insufficiency of cerebral blood flow
answers.explanation_why: Acute insufficiency of cerebral blood flow causes an ischemic stroke, the symptoms of which depend on the affected area of the brain. Patients typically have risk factors such as diabetes or hypercholesterolemia and present with focal neurological deficits like hemiparesis, none of which applies to this patient. In addition, seizures, elevated ICP, and traumatic etiology are all unusual findings for ischemic stroke.
answers.explanation_but: In malignant middle cerebral artery (MCA) infarction, the most devastating form of acute stroke, complete occlusion leads to acute brain edema and elevated ICP, which may cause herniation of the brain, usually over a course of 1–5 days. Although this condition cannot be entirely ruled out in this patient, the absence of risk factors for ischemic stroke, the acute deterioration of symptoms, and the presence of a lucid interval make this scenario unlikely.

images.title: Acute ischemic stroke with hyperdense middle cerebral artery sign
images.description:
Click on the overlay icon below the taskbar on the left to toggle the overlay on and off.

CT head (without contrast; axial plane)The right cerebral hemisphere is hypodense (green overlay) in the distributions of the middle and anterior cerebral arteries. The presence of thromboembolic material has caused the right middle cerebral artery (MCA) to appear hyperdense (hyperdense-MCA sign; white arrowhead). Cerebral edema has resulted in effacement of the sulci and the loss of differentiation between the medulla and cortex. Accompanying mass effect has compressed the right lateral ventricle (red overlay) and caused slight contralateral shift of the midline (indicated by white arrow and dashed line).

answers.content: Bleeding between dura mater and skull
answers.explanation_why:
Bleeding between the dura mater and the skull causes epidural hematoma. This diagnosis should be suspected in any patient with head trauma causing loss of consciousness followed by a lucid interval and subsequently renewed deterioration and signs of elevated ICP. The lucid interval represents the time required for the blood to accumulate in the epidural space to proportions great enough to compress the brain.

The diagnosis is confirmed by noncontrast cranial CT which shows a biconvex, hyperdense, sharply demarcated lesion located between the brain and the calvarium, limited by suture lines. Emergency treatment is necessary and involves surgical opening of the skull and evacuation of the hematoma.

images.title: Epidural and subdural hematomas
images.description:
Click on the overlay icon below the taskbar on the left to toggle the overlay on and off.

CT head (brain window: axial and coronal planes; bone window: axial plane)A biconvex epidural hematoma (green overlay) with mass effect is seen in the left frontal region, adjacent to which is a small frontotemporal subdural hematoma (red overlay). A calvarial fracture (arrowheads) involves the left temporal and parietal bones.

answers.explanation_why: Rupture of a cerebral aneurysm is a potential cause of a subarachnoid hemorrhage that can also occur after head trauma. Patients typically present with sudden, excruciating headaches (thunderclap headache), meningism, and loss of consciousness. While this patient experienced headache and a loss of consciousness, the signs of elevated ICP and his momentary recovery of consciousness suggest another diagnosis.

images.title: Subarachnoid hemorrhage
images.description: CT head (without contrast; axial plane)Multiple areas of high attenuation in the basal cisterns, Sylvian fissures, and sulci (examples indicated by green overlay) are characteristic of extensive subarachnoid hemorrhage.

question_text: Two days after hospital admission and surgical treatment for a cut on his right thigh from a sickle, a 35-year-old man presents to the emergency department with wound swelling, fever, chills, and severe pain. He had a similar injury 4 months ago that resolved after treatment with bacitracin ointment and daily dressings. He works on a farm on the outskirts of the city. He appears anxious. His temperature is 38.5°C (101.3°F), pulse is 103/min, and blood pressure is 114/76 mm Hg. Examination shows a 6-cm edematous deep, foul-smelling wound on the medial surface of the right thigh. The skin over the thigh appears darker than the skin on the lower leg. There are multiple blisters around the wound. Light palpation around the wound causes severe pain; crepitus is present. Which of the following is the most likely causal organism?
content_preview: Two days after hospital admission and surgical treatment for a cut on his right thigh from a sickle, a 35-year-old man presents to the emergency department with wound swelling, fever, chills, and severe pain. He had a similar injury 4 months ago that resolved after treatment with bacitracin ointment and daily dressings. He works on a farm on the outskirts of the city. He appears anxious. His temperature is 38.5°C (101.3°F), pulse is 103/min, and blood pressure is 114/76 mm Hg. Examination shows a 6-cm edematous deep, foul-smelling wound on the medial surface of the right thigh. The skin over the thigh appears darker than the skin on the lower leg. There are multiple blisters around the wound. Light palpation around the wound causes severe pain; crepitus is present. Which of the following is the most likely causal organism?
hint: Severe pain, fever, crepitus, darkened skin, and blisters around a deep, foul-smelling wound suggest gas gangrene, a rare subtype of necrotizing fasciitis.
learning_objective: Recognize gas gangrene, and recall its most common causal organism.

answers.explanation_why: Staphylococcus epidermidis usually becomes pathogenic in immunocompromised patients, especially those with invasive devices like catheters, central lines, or surgical implants. This patient has no such device and is not immunocompromised, making the organism an unlikely cause of his symptoms. Moreover, S. epidermidis is not associated with the development of gas gangrene.

Gas gangrene is a life-threatening necrotizing soft tissue infection most commonly caused by the rapid proliferation and spread of Clostridium perfringens from a contaminated wound. Clinical features include excruciating muscle pain, edema with subsequent skin discoloration (red-purple to black), and gas production. Crepitus is generally present, as well as a feathering pattern of gas on soft tissue imaging. To have a chance at survival, this patient should receive empiric antibiotic treatment and undergo surgical debridement immediately.

Pseudomonas aeruginosa is a gram-negative aerobic bacterium that can cause skin and soft tissue infections in immunocompromised patients. The most common infections caused by P. aeruginosa are ecthyma gangrenosum, burn wound infections, osteomyelitis, and folliculitis associated with hot tub use. P. aeruginosa is an unlikely cause of necrotizing soft tissue infection, especially in a patient who is not immunocompromised.

Species of the Rhizopus and Mucor genera can cause mucormycosis, which may involve deep tissue necrosis manifesting with features similar to those seen in this patient. However, since this patient is neither immunocompromised nor diabetic, infection with pathogens from these genera is unlikely.

Staphylococcus aureus is one of the most common causes of soft tissue infections, including cellulitis, skin abscesses, and folliculitis. However, it is not a monomicrobial cause of gas-containing necrotizing fasciitis and is only sometimes involved in polymicrobial cases. A different pathogen is more likely.

Pasteurella multocida is a common cause of infection in animal bite wounds, especially those from cats. Infection with the organism can result in cellulitis, abscess formation, and even necrotizing soft tissue infection, which would cause symptoms similar to those seen in this patient. This patient does not, however, have a history of animal bites, making this pathogen very unlikely.

Vibrio vulnificus is a pathogenic bacterium found in marine environments. Although V. vulnificus can also cause necrotizing soft tissue infections, it is less likely than other causes, especially in a patient without a history of exposure to marine environments.

question_text: A 23-year-old woman with Ehlers-Danlos syndrome is brought to the emergency department with pain and swelling of the right knee after she twisted it while dancing. She had two similar episodes last year that were treated conservatively. She was treated for a fracture of her humerus 2 years ago. She has gastroesophageal reflux disease. Her sister has allergic rhinitis. Her only medication is omeprazole. She appears tense and uncomfortable. Her temperature is 37.1°C (99.3°F), pulse is 97/min, and blood pressure is 110/70 mm Hg. Examination shows mild scoliosis. The lungs are clear to auscultation. Cardiac examination shows a mid-systolic click. The right knee shows a large, tender effusion and the patella is displaced laterally. Lachman test, posterior drawer test, and Apley test are negative. A complete blood count and serum concentrations of electrolytes, urea nitrogen, and creatinine are within the reference range. Toxicology screening is negative. X-ray of the knee joint shows an osteochondral fragment within the knee joint. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
content_preview: A 23-year-old woman with Ehlers-Danlos syndrome is brought to the emergency department with pain and swelling of the right knee after she twisted it while dancing. She had two similar episodes last year that were treated conservatively. She was treated for a fracture of her humerus 2 years ago. She has gastroesophageal reflux disease. Her sister has allergic rhinitis. Her only medication is omeprazole. She appears tense and uncomfortable. Her temperature is 37.1°C (99.3°F), pulse is 97/min, and blood pressure is 110/70 mm Hg. Examination shows mild scoliosis. The lungs are clear to auscultation. Cardiac examination shows a mid-systolic click. The right knee shows a large, tender effusion and the patella is displaced laterally. Lachman test, posterior drawer test, and Apley test are negative. A complete blood count and serum concentrations of electrolytes, urea nitrogen, and creatinine are within the reference range. Toxicology screening is negative. X-ray of the knee joint shows an osteochondral fragment within the knee joint. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
hint: A laterally displaced patella, right knee effusion and pain, a past history of similar episodes, and a history of Ehlers-Danlos syndrome make the diagnosis of acute patellar dislocation highly likely. The osteochondral fragment within the knee joint indicates an avulsion fracture of the lateral femoral condyle or patella.
learning_objective: Recognize acute patellar dislocation with osteochondral fracture, and choose the most appropriate next step in management.

answers.explanation_why:
In a patient with a patellar dislocation and a concurrent osteochondral fracture, knee arthroscopy is the initial procedure indicated to either repair the osteochondral defect or remove the intraarticular fragment if a repair cannot be performed. Following removal of the fragment, reduction is performed intraoperatively, and the knee is flexed and extended through its entire range of motion.

Individuals with Ehlers-Danlos syndrome often present with joint hypermobility, which puts them at increased risk for joint dislocations (especially of the knee and shoulder).

Above-knee casts are rarely used to immobilize the knee after the initial treatment of patellar dislocations nowadays because prolonged immobilization is associated with a higher risk of restricted joint movement, while early physiotherapy and functional bracing are associated with better outcomes. If fracture of the distal femur or tibia occurs along with patellar dislocation, an above-knee cast may be used for immobilization after initial treatment. However, such injuries occur only following high-energy trauma, and neither x-ray nor the patient's clinical presentation suggest femoral or tibial fractures.

A knee brace alone is unlikely to help this patient in the acute phase immediately following her injury. Following initial treatment, a knee brace that can be locked in extension (knee immobilizer) is used for 10–14 days. After 2 weeks, a functional brace can be used until the patient can walk without a limp.

This is a good answer option to consider because closed reduction of the patella is the treatment of choice in cases of uncomplicated patellar dislocation. This question aims at testing the management of patella dislocation complicated by an osteochondral fracture, which is seen in approximately 30–40% of patients with acute patellar dislocation. The osteochondral fracture should be repaired or removed before reducing the patellar dislocation to prevent osteochondral damage, which can occur during reduction as a result of shearing forces.

Recurrent patellar dislocation predisposes the patient to develop patellofemoral osteoarthritis of the knee, which may be treated with knee replacement surgery in severe cases. However, total knee replacement is not indicated to treat acute patellar dislocation.

Early physiotherapy minimizes muscle atrophy and maintains range of motion of the knee, which is why it plays an important role following the initial treatment of patellar dislocation. Strengthening exercises are continued for 3–4 months and help prevent recurrence of patellar dislocation by strengthening both the static stabilizers (ligaments) and the dynamic stabilizers (quadriceps muscles) of the knee joint and patella. However, physiotherapy does not play a role in the initial management of acute patellar dislocation.

question_text: A 14-year-old girl is brought to the physician after she accidentally cut her right forearm earlier that morning while working with her mother's embroidery scissors. She has no history of serious illness. The mother says she went to elementary and middle school abroad and is not sure if she received all of her childhood vaccinations. She appears healthy. Her temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse 90/min, and blood pressure is 102/68 mm Hg. Examination shows a clean 2-cm laceration on her right forearm with surrounding edema. There is no erythema or discharge. The wound is irrigated with water and washed with soap. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
content_preview: A 14-year-old girl is brought to the physician after she accidentally cut her right forearm earlier that morning while working with her mother's embroidery scissors. She has no history of serious illness. The mother says she went to elementary and middle school abroad and is not sure if she received all of her childhood vaccinations. She appears healthy. Her temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse 90/min, and blood pressure is 102/68 mm Hg. Examination shows a clean 2-cm laceration on her right forearm with surrounding edema. There is no erythema or discharge. The wound is irrigated with water and washed with soap. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
hint: This patient has a clean, minor wound and her immunization status against tetanus is unknown.
learning_objective: Recognize a clean, minor wound with unknown tetanus immunization status, and choose the most appropriate vaccination.

answers.explanation_why: DTaP is the vaccine preparation of choice for the primary immunization schedule as well as for postexposure prophylaxis in children between the ages of 6 weeks and 7 years. In a 14-year-old patient with a clean, minor wound and an unknown immunization history, active immunization is required. However, a different preparation suited for active immunization in older children is required, since DTaP is not indicated for postexposure prophylaxis in children older than 7 years of age.

Metronidazole is effective against anaerobic bacteria, including Clostridium tetani, which causes tetanus. Intravenous metronidazole is used along with tetanus immunoglobulin (TIG) to treat acute tetanus infection. Metronidazole does not play a role in postexposure prophylaxis.

In a patient with a clean, minor wound and an unknown immunization history, active immunization with Tdap is required. If the wound was neither clean nor minor, Tdap should otherwise be combined with TIG.

See “Tetanus prophylaxis after injury” table.

A combination of tetanus immunoglobulin (TIG) and Tdap is used for postexposure prophylaxis in individuals with an unknown immunization history who have wounds that are neither clean nor minor. TIG is not indicated for clean wounds, as is the case with this patient.

Tetanus immunoglobulin (TIG) is used for postexposure prophylaxis in combination with active immunization in individuals with an unknown immunization history who have wounds that are neither clean nor minor. TIG is not indicated for clean wounds, nor should it be administered alone (i.e., only passive immunization) in any patient older than 6 weeks of age.

Passive immunization on its own (only TIG) is indicated for postexposure prophylaxis in infants less than 6 weeks of age with a dirty, contaminated wound, since active immunization with the tetanus toxoid is not recommended for this age group.

Tetanus has a high mortality rate (10%) even with early, aggressive treatment. Therefore, prevention of tetanus via postexposure prophylaxis is always required in a patient with any wound and an unknown immunization history. If a patient has a clean, minor wound and had received ≥ 3 tetanus toxoid doses with the last dose less than 10 years ago, no further steps would be required

question_text: A 36-year-old man comes to the emergency department 4 hours after a bike accident for severe pain and swelling in his right leg. He has not had a headache, nausea, vomiting, abdominal pain, or blood in his urine. He has a history of gastroesophageal reflux disease and allergic rhinitis. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 17 years and drinks an average of one alcoholic beverage daily. His medications include levocetirizine and pantoprazole. He is in moderate distress. His temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 112/min, and blood pressure is 140/80 mm Hg. Examination shows multiple bruises over both lower extremities and the face. There is swelling surrounding a 2-cm laceration 13 cm below the right knee. The lower two-thirds of the tibia is tender to palpation and the skin is pale and cool to the touch. The anterior tibial, posterior tibial, and dorsalis pedis pulses are weak. Capillary refill time of the right big toe is 4 seconds. Passive dorsiflexion of his right foot causes severe pain in his calf. Cardiopulmonary examination is normal. An x-ray of the right leg shows a dislocated fracture of the tibial center with posterior displacement of the distal tibial part. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
content_preview: A 36-year-old man comes to the emergency department 4 hours after a bike accident for severe pain and swelling in his right leg. He has not had a headache, nausea, vomiting, abdominal pain, or blood in his urine. He has a history of gastroesophageal reflux disease and allergic rhinitis. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 17 years and drinks an average of one alcoholic beverage daily. His medications include levocetirizine and pantoprazole. He is in moderate distress. His temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 112/min, and blood pressure is 140/80 mm Hg. Examination shows multiple bruises over both lower extremities and the face. There is swelling surrounding a 2-cm laceration 13 cm below the right knee. The lower two-thirds of the tibia is tender to palpation and the skin is pale and cool to the touch. The anterior tibial, posterior tibial, and dorsalis pedis pulses are weak. Capillary refill time of the right big toe is 4 seconds. Passive dorsiflexion of his right foot causes severe pain in his calf. Cardiopulmonary examination is normal. An x-ray of the right leg shows a dislocated fracture of the tibial center with posterior displacement of the distal tibial part. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
hint: Findings of a tibial fracture, pale, cool skin, weak peripheral pulses, increased capillary refill time, and pain in the calf muscle on passively dorsiflexing the foot are consistent with acute compartment syndrome and impending limb ischemia.
learning_objective: Recognize acute compartment syndrome, and choose the most appropriate surgical intervention.

answers.explanation_why: One of the many indications of LMWH is the treatment of deep vein thrombosis (DVT). DVT can manifest with swelling of the lower limb and pain in the calf muscle on dorsiflexion of the foot. However, in patients with DVT, the extremities are usually warm and have a reddish-purple hue, normal pulses, and/or distended superficial veins.

Open reduction and internal fixation (ORIF) with an intramedullary nail are usually the treatment of choice for many types of open fractures of the tibial shaft, which this patient has. However, the presence of compartment syndrome warrants a more urgent procedure to save the limb before any definitive therapy is implemented.

An above knee cast may be used to nonsurgically treat a noncomminuted, minimally displaced tibial shaft fracture. However, this patient's fracture is open and has significant displacement, which requires surgical treatment. Regardless, a cast is contraindicated in this patient with compartment syndrome as it would drastically increase compartment pressure and further increase the risk of developing limb ischemia.

Fasciotomy is the treatment of choice for compartment syndrome. It should be conducted within six hours of the onset of clinical symptoms (to prevent necrosis, irreversible nerve damage, and possible amputation) and followed up with open wound management. The diagnosis is primarily clinical; however, needle manometry to calculate the delta pressure (diastolic blood pressure - intracompartmental pressure) is often performed to confirm the diagnosis. A delta pressure < 30 mm Hg confirms acute compartment syndrome, which is an indication for fasciotomy. For patients who present extremely late (3–5 days after onset), amputation is the treatment of last resort.

Clindamycin is used to treat skin and soft tissue infections caused by anaerobic bacteria and certain gram-positive organisms such as MRSA. However, the history of trauma in this patient along with pale, cool skin instead of warm, erythematous skin, and the absence of fever suggest a noninfectious condition. If surgery is indicated, clindamycin is considered an alternative to cefazolin for surgical prophylaxis in patients with a beta-lactam allergy. However, the presence of compartment syndrome in this patient warrants a more urgent procedure to save the limb before any definitive therapy can be implemented.

Placing a filter within the inferior vena cava is indicated to treat and/or prevent pulmonary embolism in patients with deep vein thrombosis (DVT) when anticoagulant therapy is either contraindicated or ineffective. DVT can manifest with swelling of the lower limb, and pain in the calf muscle on dorsiflexion of the foot, as seen in this patient. But the extremities in a patient with DVT are usually warm with a reddish purple hue, normal pulses, and/or distended superficial veins.

question_text:
A 63-year-old man is brought to the emergency department 30 minutes after being involved in a high-speed motor vehicle collision. He is obtunded on arrival. He is intubated and mechanical ventilation is begun. The ventilator is set at an FiO_2 of 60%, tidal volume of 440 mL, and positive end-expiratory pressure of 7 cm H_2O. On the third day of intubation, his temperature is 37.3°C (99.1°F), pulse is 91/min, and blood pressure is 103/60 mm Hg. There are decreased breath sounds over the left lung base. Cardiac examination shows no abnormalities. The abdomen is soft and not distended. Arterial blood gas analysis shows:

pH
7.49

pCO_2

29 mm Hg

pO_2

73 mm Hg

HCO_3^-

20 mEq/L

O_2 saturation
89%

Monitoring shows a sudden increase in the plateau airway pressure. An x-ray of the chest shows deepening of the costophrenic angle on the left side. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
content_preview: A 63-year-old man is brought to the emergency department 30 minutes after being involved in a high-speed motor vehicle collision. He is obtunded on arrival. He is intubated and mechanical ventilation is begun. The ventilator is set at an FiO2 of 60%, tidal volume of 440 mL, and positive end-expiratory pressure of 7 cm H2O. On the third day of intubation, his temperature is 37.3°C (99.1°F), pulse is 91/min, and blood pressure is 103/60 mm Hg. There are decreased breath sounds over the left lung base. Cardiac examination shows no abnormalities. The abdomen is soft and not distended. Arterial blood gas analysis shows: pH 7.49 pCO2 29 mm Hg pO2 73 mm Hg HCO3- 20 mEq/L O2 saturation 89% Monitoring shows a sudden increase in the plateau airway pressure. An x-ray of the chest shows deepening of the costophrenic angle on the left side. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
hint: Decreased breath sounds, increased airway pressure, respiratory alkalosis, and deep sulcus sign on chest x-ray in a mechanically ventilated patient indicate a pneumothorax.
learning_objective: Recognize the signs of pneumothorax in a mechanically ventilated patient, and choose the most appropriate intervention.

answers.explanation_why: Immediate insertion of a large-bore needle into the 2^nd intercostal space along the midclavicular line or the 4^th–5^th intercostal space between the anterior and midaxillary line is indicated for tension pneumothorax. Although tension pneumothorax may also manifest with decreased oxygen saturation and deep sulcus sign, further findings such as contralateral tracheal deviation, distended neck veins, cyanosis, and hemodynamic instability (e.g., tachycardia, hypotension) are commonly seen.

Respiratory fluoroquinolones such as levofloxacin are the first-line treatment in patients with hospital-acquired pneumonia who do not have risk factors for multiresistant pathogens (e.g., prior antibiotic treatment, structural lung disease). Pneumonia typically manifests with high fever and chills, productive cough, tachypnea, and dyspnea. Chest x-ray usually shows extensive opacities restricted to one pulmonary lobe, poorly defined patchy infiltrates, or diffuse reticular opacity. These features are not present in this patient.

Increasing the positive end-expiratory pressure (PEEP) is often necessary when treating acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS). Patients with ARDS typically present with acute onset tachypnea, tachycardia, cyanosis, dyspnea, diffuse crackles, and possibly fever, cough, and chest pain. Chest x-ray of patients with ARDS usually reveals diffuse bilateral infiltrates, air bronchogram, atelectasis, and pleural effusions. This patient's x-ray indicates a pneumothorax, most likely due to increased pressures during mechanical ventilation. Increasing the PEEP is contraindicated as it would exacerbate his condition.

Insertion of a chest tube into the 4^th–5^th intercostal space between the anterior and midaxillary line (safe triangle) is the most appropriate next step for treating pneumothorax in a mechanically ventilated patient. Mechanical ventilation (especially with a high positive end-expiratory pressure) is considered a risk factor for developing pneumothorax. High ventilatory pressure can damage the lung tissue, causing a leak that allows air to enter the pleural cavity. Because the air entering the pleural space comes from the lung rather than the exterior, it is known as a closed pneumothorax. Following completion of the procedure, another chest x-ray to control the position of chest tube placement should be performed. To prevent further lung damage, the ventilatory pressure should be decreased.

Pneumothorax is often hard to diagnose in ventilated patients. Since the x-ray is obtained in the supine position, less air collects apically, making the pneumothorax less obvious.

Indications to obtain a CT scan include uncertain diagnosis despite chest x-ray, suspected underlying lung disease (to determine likelihood of recurrent disease), and presurgical workup. The patient had a chest x-ray that showed deepening of the costophrenic angle, indicating a pneumothorax. Further workup with a chest CT is not needed at this time.

Close observation would be the most appropriate next step in the management of asymptomatic patients with a small primary spontaneous pneumothorax (rim between the lung edge and chest wall < 2–3 cm). Such a pneumothorax usually resolves spontaneously within ∼ 10 days and symptomatic treatment and serial follow-up with repeat chest x-ray are sufficient. This patient is symptomatic, presenting with iatrogenic pneumothorax most likely due to mechanical ventilation, and requires treatment.

question_text:
A 56-year-old woman comes to the emergency department because of worsening pain and swelling in her right knee for 3 days. She underwent a total knee arthroplasty of her right knee joint 5 months ago. The procedure and immediate aftermath were uneventful. She has hypertension and osteoarthritis. Current medications include glucosamine, amlodipine, and meloxicam. Her temperature is 37.9°C (100.2°F), pulse is 95/min, and blood pressure is 115/70 mm Hg. Examination shows a tender, swollen right knee joint; range of motion is limited by pain. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Arthrocentesis of the right knee is performed. Analysis of the synovial fluid shows:

Appearance
Cloudy

Viscosity
Absent

WBC count
78,000/mm^3

Segmented neutrophils
94%

Lymphocytes
6%

Synovial fluid is sent for culture and antibiotic sensitivity. Which of the following is the most likely causal pathogen?
content_preview: A 56-year-old woman comes to the emergency department because of worsening pain and swelling in her right knee for 3 days. She underwent a total knee arthroplasty of her right knee joint 5 months ago. The procedure and immediate aftermath were uneventful. She has hypertension and osteoarthritis. Current medications include glucosamine, amlodipine, and meloxicam. Her temperature is 37.9°C (100.2°F), pulse is 95/min, and blood pressure is 115/70 mm Hg. Examination shows a tender, swollen right knee joint; range of motion is limited by pain. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Arthrocentesis of the right knee is performed. Analysis of the synovial fluid shows: Appearance Cloudy Viscosity Absent WBC count 78,000/mm3 Segmented neutrophils 94% Lymphocytes 6% Synovial fluid is sent for culture and antibiotic sensitivity. Which of the following is the most likely causal pathogen?
hint: A painful swollen knee, restricted range of motion, low-grade fever, and synovial fluid analysis showing purulent synovial fluid and increased WBC count with neutrophil predominance are suggestive of infectious arthritis. This patient's history of arthroplasty makes a bacterial prosthetic joint infection most likely.
learning_objective: Recognize prosthetic joint infection, and recall its common pathogens.

answers.explanation_why: Pseudomonas aeruginosa is found in immunosuppressed patients with arthritis. The patient has no history of conditions that would predispose her to P. aeruginosa infection (e.g., underlying malignancy, IV drug use, diabetes mellitus), which makes this pathogen an unlikely cause.

Staphylococcus epidermidis has the ability to form a biofilm and can therefore grow on the surface of foreign material such as prosthetic joints, prosthetic cardiac valves, IV catheters, and pacemakers. This patient underwent an arthroplasty in her right knee 5 months ago and is now presenting with septic arthritis, which makes a foreign body infection very likely. S. epidermidis is the most common cause of prosthetic infections 3–12 months after surgery. If this patient had presented within < 3 months after the arthroplasty or > 12 months after surgery, Staphylococcus aureus would be most likely. Treatment of prosthetic joint infections usually consists of removal of the prosthesis and debridement of the bone and surrounding tissue, followed by IV antibiotics (e.g., oxacillin or ceftriaxone) for 6–8 weeks. Reimplantation of the prosthesis should be performed after repeat negative synovial fluid cultures or after completion of antimicrobial therapy if clinical signs of infection are absent.

Staphylococcus aureus is the most common cause of septic arthritis. However, patients with joint infection due to S. aureus are usually acutely ill with high fever, chills, and present within 3 months after arthroplasty. Given the fact that this patient presents 5 months after surgery, an infection with a less virulent pathogen is more likely.
Escherichia coli is a possible cause of septic arthritis in immunosuppressed patients. However, the patient has no history of immunosuppression, this pathogen an unlikely cause.
Streptococcus agalactiae (or group B Streptococcus) does not commonly cause septic arthritis, making this pathogen an unlikely cause.

question_text: A previously healthy 27-year-old man is brought to the emergency department 35 minutes after being involved in a high-speed motor vehicle collision in which he was an unrestrained passenger. He was ambulatory at the accident scene, with stable vital signs and no major external injuries except abrasions to both upper extremities. On arrival, he is alert and oriented. Temperature is 37.3°C (99.1°F), pulse is 88/min, respirations are 14/min, and blood pressure is 128/74 mm Hg. Abdominal examination shows ecchymosis over the upper abdomen, with tenderness to palpation over the left upper quadrant. There is no guarding or rigidity. Rectal examination is unremarkable. A CT scan of the abdomen with intravenous contrast shows a subcapsular splenic hematoma, with no contrast extravasation and minimal blood in the peritoneal cavity. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
content_preview: A previously healthy 27-year-old man is brought to the emergency department 35 minutes after being involved in a high-speed motor vehicle collision in which he was an unrestrained passenger. He was ambulatory at the accident scene, with stable vital signs and no major external injuries except abrasions to both upper extremities. On arrival, he is alert and oriented. Temperature is 37.3°C (99.1°F), pulse is 88/min, respirations are 14/min, and blood pressure is 128/74 mm Hg. Abdominal examination shows ecchymosis over the upper abdomen, with tenderness to palpation over the left upper quadrant. There is no guarding or rigidity. Rectal examination is unremarkable. A CT scan of the abdomen with intravenous contrast shows a subcapsular splenic hematoma, with no contrast extravasation and minimal blood in the peritoneal cavity. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
hint: Tenderness of the left upper quadrant and a subcapsular splenic hematoma on CT scan following significant trauma indicate splenic injury. This patient's normal heart rate and blood pressure indicate that he is currently hemodynamically stable.
learning_objective: Choose the appropriate management for a hemodynamically stable patient with splenic injury.

answers.explanation_why:
In patients with splenic injury who are hemodynamically stable, nonoperative management is warranted and consists of observation, pain management, and serial abdominal examination (including ultrasound) and hemoglobin and hematocrit measurement to monitor any further complications that may develop.

Surgical intervention is indicated in hemodynamically unstable patients.
Exploratory laparotomy and splenectomy are indicated for hemodynamically unstable patients with hilar rupture.

As this patient is hemodynamically stable, a nonoperative approach is suitable. Because there is a significant risk that the splenic injury may progress, leading to rupture and intraabdominal bleeding, another course of management is more appropriate than analgesia and discharge home.

Laparotomy and partial splenic resection are indicated in peripheral splenic rupture, which this patient could have, given the subcapsular hematoma. However, this procedure is most appropriate for hemodynamically unstable patients.

question_text: A 19-year-old man is brought to the emergency department 2 hours after he sustained an injury to his right hand while playing basketball. The ball hit his right index finger with force and he is now unable to lift the end of the finger. Examination shows a right index finger flexed at the distal interphalangeal joint and inability to actively extend the distal phalanx; range of motion is limited by pain. There is an extension deficit of 10°. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. An x-ray of the hand shows no fractures. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
content_preview: A 19-year-old man is brought to the emergency department 2 hours after he sustained an injury to his right hand while playing basketball. The ball hit his right index finger with force and he is now unable to lift the end of the finger. Examination shows a right index finger flexed at the distal interphalangeal joint and inability to actively extend the distal phalanx; range of motion is limited by pain. There is an extension deficit of 10°. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. An x-ray of the hand shows no fractures. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
hint: The flexed distal interphalangeal joint with the inability to actively extend the distal phalanx after direct trauma to the finger suggests an extensor tendon injury (mallet finger).
learning_objective: Recognize mallet finger, and choose the most appropriate management.

answers.explanation_why: In uncomplicated extensor digitorum tendon injuries (no associated displaced fractures, extension deficit < 45°), a stack splint is used to stabilize the joint for 6–8 weeks in slight hyperextension in order to achieve a close approximation of the tendon ends and full recovery. When applying splints to areas with bony protuberances, as in this case, excessive direct pressure from the splint must be avoided. Continuous pressure can lead to skin necrosis and subsequent healing disorders and infections.

images.title: Mallet finger
images.description: Right middle finger with extended PIP and flexed DIP jointsThis condition results from sudden forced hyperflexion of the DIP joint while the digit is extended (particularly common in sports such as basketball and baseball), which causes rupture or avulsion of the extensor digitorum tendon.

answers.explanation_why: Kirschner wires are used to fixate bone fragments, particularly in fractures of smaller bones. As this patient most likely has an extensor tendon injury and shows no signs of fractures on x-ray, Kirschner wire fixation is unnecessary at this time.

While a concomitant avulsion fracture can occur in extensor tendon injuries, it only requires intraosseous suturing in select cases, as the distal interphalangeal joint is a non-weight-bearing joint and articular incongruities often heal well or are well-tolerated. Additionally, this patient's x-ray shows no signs of an associated fracture.

Buddy taping is used for minor finger or toe injuries (e.g., nondisplaced stable fractures, sprains, dislocations) if the damaged digit requires immobilization. This treatment is not the most appropriate for an acute mallet finger because it cannot ensure the ideal recovery position. In certain patients with mallet finger who need additional finger protection (e.g., athletes returning to sports, individuals with jobs that involve heavy lifting), buddy taping may be considered after initial therapy.

Surgical treatment of mallet finger is rarely required and only indicated in patients with severe fractures, subluxation of the joint, failure of conservative treatment, or in patients who cannot wear a splint (e.g., because of their profession). This patient has none of the above indications. Injuries to the flexor digitorum profundus tendon virtually always require surgical treatment. However, such injuries manifest with an inability to actively flex the distal phalanx (Jersey finger).

question_text: A 26-year-old medical student comes to the physician for a chest x-ray to rule out active pulmonary tuberculosis. He needs a medical and radiological report before starting a medical internship in South Africa in 6 weeks. He says he feels well. He has no history of serious illness. He has smoked 1 pack of cigarettes daily for the past 6 years. He does not drink alcohol. He is 190 cm (6 ft 3 in) tall and weighs 75 kg (170 lb); BMI is 20.8 kg/m^2. His temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 80/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 128/89 mm Hg. The lungs are clear to auscultation. Cardiac examination shows no abnormalities. The x-ray of the chest shows a small pneumothorax (rim of < 2 cm) between the upper left lung margin and the chest wall. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management of this patient?
content_preview: A 26-year-old medical student comes to the physician for a chest x-ray to rule out active pulmonary tuberculosis. He needs a medical and radiological report before starting a medical internship in South Africa in 6 weeks. He says he feels well. He has no history of serious illness. He has smoked 1 pack of cigarettes daily for the past 6 years. He does not drink alcohol. He is 190 cm (6 ft 3 in) tall and weighs 75 kg (170 lb); BMI is 20.8 kg/m2. His temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 80/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 128/89 mm Hg. The lungs are clear to auscultation. Cardiac examination shows no abnormalities. The x-ray of the chest shows a small pneumothorax (rim of < 2 cm) between the upper left lung margin and the chest wall. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management of this patient?
hint: The x-ray shows a small pneumothorax (rim of < 2 cm) between the lung margin and the chest wall as an incidental finding. In a tall, fit, and smoking young adult this is suspicious of a primary spontaneous pneumothorax.
learning_objective: Recognize primary spontaneous pneumothorax, and choose the most appropriate management.

answers.explanation_why: Video-assisted thoracoscopic surgery would be indicated as an alternative treatment for tension pneumothorax, or for the recurrence of a spontaneous pneumothorax. Because this patient only has a small pneumothorax and is hemodynamically stable, he requires a different approach.

Emergent needle thoracostomy would be indicated in the case of a tension pneumothorax. A tension pneumothorax would cause sudden chest pain, dyspnea, cyanosis, absent breath sounds, hemodynamic instability, and tracheal deviation on chest x-ray.

Observation with follow-up serial chest x-rays are the recommended treatment for small primary spontaneous pneumothoraces with an apex-to-cupola distance < 3 cm that does not compromise the gas exchange function. A small pneumothorax is likely to resolve spontaneously within a few days (∼ 10 days).

This patient's smoking history, male sex, young age, and physical features (tall stature, low body weight) put him at increased risk for primary spontaneous pneumothorax.
Immediate intubation and assisted ventilation is not indicated for the management of pneumothorax (and may even worsen tension pneumothorax, which requires decompression).

A chest CT is useful for the evaluation of pneumothorax when the chest x-ray fails to point to a clear diagnosis, as it can provide detailed information about the cause of the condition. However, this patient's diagnosis has already been established and further diagnostic evaluation is not indicated at this time.

Urgent chest tube placement is indicated for a symptomatic or large pneumothorax (i.e, a rim of > 2 cm between the lung margin and the chest wall on chest x-ray), but this patient has a small primary spontaneous pneumothorax and is asymptomatic.

question_text: A 24-year-old man is brought to the emergency department 15 minutes after he sustained a stab wound to the left chest. On arrival, he has rapid, shallow breathing and appears anxious. His pulse is 135/min, respirations are 30/min and shallow, and palpable systolic blood pressure is 80 mm Hg. Examination shows no active external bleeding. There is a 2.5-cm single stab wound to the left chest at the 4^th intercostal space at the midclavicular line. Cardiovascular examination shows muffled heart sounds and jugular venous distention. Breath sounds are normal. Further evaluation of this patient is most likely to show which of the following findings?
content_preview: A 24-year-old man is brought to the emergency department 15 minutes after he sustained a stab wound to the left chest. On arrival, he has rapid, shallow breathing and appears anxious. His pulse is 135/min, respirations are 30/min and shallow, and palpable systolic blood pressure is 80 mm Hg. Examination shows no active external bleeding. There is a 2.5-cm single stab wound to the left chest at the 4th intercostal space at the midclavicular line. Cardiovascular examination shows muffled heart sounds and jugular venous distention. Breath sounds are normal. Further evaluation of this patient is most likely to show which of the following findings?
hint: Muffled heart sounds, hypotension, and jugular venous distention (also known as Beck triad) following penetrating chest trauma are consistent with cardiac tamponade.
learning_objective: Recognize cardiac tamponade, and recall its characteristic hemodynamic finding during inspiration.

answers.content: Tracheal deviation toward the right side
answers.explanation_why: Tracheal deviation toward the contralateral side of a lesion can occur with a tension pneumothorax or a massive hemothorax. Although both of these conditions can be caused by penetrating chest trauma and result in tachycardia, hypotension, and jugular venous distention, this patient does not have reduced breath sounds, which is a characteristic auscultatory finding in both of these conditions.

answers.content: A drop in systolic blood pressure of 14 mm Hg during inspiration
answers.explanation_why: In cardiac tamponade, outward expansion of the ventricles is limited because of fluid in the pericardial space. During inspiration, increased venous return leads to increased right ventricular volume. As outward expansion is limited, the right ventricle expands via the interventricular septum, which bulges into the left ventricle. This effect leads to further reduction in left ventricular filling during inspiration, resulting in decreased stroke volume and a subsequent drop in blood pressure. A drop in systolic blood pressure > 10 mm Hg during inspiration is known as pulsus paradoxus, a sign characteristically seen in moderate and severe cardiac tamponade but also in some cases of severe asthma, tension pneumothorax, and constrictive pericarditis.

answers.content: Herniation of the stomach into the chest
answers.explanation_why: Herniation of the stomach into the chest indicates diaphragmatic injury. This condition may also result after a penetrating chest trauma. Although shallow breathing is a feature consistent with diaphragmatic injury, this patient is lacking other key findings of this condition, such as chest or abdominal pain, reduced breath sounds, and bowel sounds in the chest on auscultation. In addition, muffled heart sounds would not be expected in this condition.

Subcutaneous emphysema or crepitus suggests either bronchial rupture, esophageal rupture, or pneumothorax, which also may be caused by penetrating trauma. None of these conditions cause muffled heart sounds.

answers.content: Paradoxical motion of part of the chest with breathing
answers.explanation_why: Paradoxical motion of part of the chest with breathing suggests flail chest, which is usually caused by severe blunt thoracic trauma rather than penetrating chest trauma. Although this patient has shallow breathing, which may be a feature of flail chest, the condition is not associated with muffled heart sounds or jugular venous distention, and it is unlikely that a single stab wound would cause several rib fractures.

images.title: Pathomechanism of flail chest
images.description: Paradoxical movement of a separate chest wall segment that moves inward during inspiration and outward during expiration. Caused by detachment of a segment of the rib cage from the chest wall due to fracture of three or more adjacent ribs in at least two places.

question_text:
A 28-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department 30 minutes after being involved in a high-speed motor vehicle collision in which she was the unrestrained driver. On arrival, she is semiconscious and incoherent. She has shortness of breath and is cyanotic. Her pulse is 112/min, respirations are 59/min, and blood pressure is 128/89 mm Hg. Examination shows a 3-cm (1.2-in) laceration on the forehead and multiple abrasions over the thorax and abdomen. There is crepitation on palpation of the thorax on the right. Auscultation of the lung shows decreased breath sounds on the right side. A crunching sound synchronous with the heartbeat is heard best over the precordium. There is dullness on percussion of the right hemithorax. The lips and tongue have a bluish discoloration. There is an open femur fracture on the left. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Arterial blood gas analysis on room air shows:

pH
7.31

PCO_2

55 mm Hg

PO_2

42 mm Hg

HCO_3^-

22 mEq/L

O_2 saturation
76%

The patient is intubated and mechanically ventilated. Infusion of 0.9% saline is begun. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
content_preview: A 28-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department 30 minutes after being involved in a high-speed motor vehicle collision in which she was the unrestrained driver. On arrival, she is semiconscious and incoherent. She has shortness of breath and is cyanotic. Her pulse is 112/min, respirations are 59/min, and blood pressure is 128/89 mm Hg. Examination shows a 3-cm (1.2-in) laceration on the forehead and multiple abrasions over the thorax and abdomen. There is crepitation on palpation of the thorax on the right. Auscultation of the lung shows decreased breath sounds on the right side. A crunching sound synchronous with the heartbeat is heard best over the precordium. There is dullness on percussion of the right hemithorax. The lips and tongue have a bluish discoloration. There is an open femur fracture on the left. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Arterial blood gas analysis on room air shows: pH 7.31 PCO2 55 mm Hg PO2 42 mm Hg HCO3- 22 mEq/L O2 saturation 76% The patient is intubated and mechanically ventilated. Infusion of 0.9% saline is begun. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
hint: This patient presents with subcutaneous emphysema (crepitation on palpation), decreased breath sounds, and crunching sounds synchronous with the heartbeat (Hamman sign) following blunt chest trauma. These findings are consistent with pneumomediastinum.
learning_objective: Recognize bronchial rupture.

answers.explanation_why: An aortic dissection can be idiopathic, associated with underlying diseases, or traumatic, following blunt chest trauma. Patients with an aortic dissection can present with an acute onset of severe, tearing chest pain radiating to the back, hypertension (though hypotension is also seen when the dissection is complicated by cardiac tamponade or aortic rupture), weak or asymmetric peripheral pulses, and different blood pressures in the upper extremities. Pneumomediastinum is not a feature of aortic dissection.

Cardiac tamponade can occur following blunt chest trauma. A patient with cardiac tamponade would experience cardiogenic shock and classically present with Beck triad. This patient's symptoms are not typical of cardiac tamponade.

Tracheobronchial injuries such as a bronchial rupture can occur after a high-speed trauma. A bronchial rupture can present with Hamman sign (as a result of the pneumomediastinum) and respiratory acidosis (due to alveolar hypoventilation from airway obstruction and atelectasis). The dullness on percussion in the right hemithorax suggests a fluid collection. In the context of recent trauma, this finding likely represents an associated hemothorax. Patients with a tracheobronchial injury may develop a pneumothorax or a pneumomediastinum which reaccumulates even after a thoracostomy.

Flail chest can be caused by blunt chest trauma. The flail segment, consisting of multiple adjacent ribs broken in multiple places, would be evident on physical examination. Additionally, paradoxical breathing (the flail segment moves opposite to the chest wall as the patient breaths) would be present. Although this patient may have rib fractures due to the high-speed trauma, the examination is inconsistent with a flail chest.

images.title: Pathomechanism of flail chest
images.description: Paradoxical movement of a separate chest wall segment that moves inward during inspiration and outward during expiration. Caused by detachment of a segment of the rib cage from the chest wall due to fracture of three or more adjacent ribs in at least two places.

answers.explanation_why: Tension pneumothorax is often caused by high-speed trauma such as a motor vehicle collision. Patients usually exhibit hyperresonance on percussion (instead of dullness) and present with hemodynamic compromise. Because this patient is relatively hemodynamically stable, tension pneumothorax is an unlikely diagnosis.

Myocardial rupture can be caused by blunt chest trauma. Patients with a myocardial rupture experience acute hemodynamic deterioration with jugular venous distention on exam, but this patient's blood pressure is stable. Because of the high mortality associated with myocardial rupture, it would also be unlikely that this patient would have survived such trauma 30 minutes later.

Pulmonary embolism can be caused by embolism of fat following a femoral fracture and typically presents with nonspecific findings including pleuritic chest pain and pleural effusion. While chest pain cannot be excluded in this patient and the dullness on percussion may represent an effusion, pulmonary embolism would not manifest with the crepitus on palpation, Hamman sign, and decreased breath sounds, and is, therefore, an unlikely diagnosis.

question_text: A 28-year-old man is brought to the emergency department with shortness of breath and chest pain 35 minutes after he was involved in a high-speed motor vehicle collision. He was the helmeted driver of a scooter hit by a truck. On arrival, he is alert and oriented with a Glasgow Coma Scale rating of 14. His temperature is 37.3°C (99.1°F), pulse is 103/min, respirations are 33/min and blood pressure is 132/88 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 94%. Examination shows multiple abrasions over his anterior abdomen and extremities. There is a 2.5-cm (1-in) laceration on the left side of the chest. There are decreased breath sounds over the left base. Cardiac examination shows no abnormalities. The abdomen is soft and there is tenderness to palpation over the left upper quadrant. Bowel sounds are normal. His hemoglobin concentration is 13.6 g/dL, leukocyte count is 9110/mm^3, and platelet count is 190,000/mm^3. A chest x-ray is shown. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
content_preview: A 28-year-old man is brought to the emergency department with shortness of breath and chest pain 35 minutes after he was involved in a high-speed motor vehicle collision. He was the helmeted driver of a scooter hit by a truck. On arrival, he is alert and oriented with a Glasgow Coma Scale rating of 14. His temperature is 37.3°C (99.1°F), pulse is 103/min, respirations are 33/min and blood pressure is 132/88 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 94%. Examination shows multiple abrasions over his anterior abdomen and extremities. There is a 2.5-cm (1-in) laceration on the left side of the chest. There are decreased breath sounds over the left base. Cardiac examination shows no abnormalities. The abdomen is soft and there is tenderness to palpation over the left upper quadrant. Bowel sounds are normal. His hemoglobin concentration is 13.6 g/dL, leukocyte count is 9110/mm3, and platelet count is 190,000/mm3. A chest x-ray is shown. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
hint: This patient, who has just been in a car accident, is in respiratory distress and has chest pain, decreased breath sounds over his left lung, and a chest x-ray that is typical for this condition.
learning_objective: Recognize diaphragmatic rupture.

answers.explanation_why:
Diaphragmatic rupture is most commonly caused by penetrating injuries, followed by blunt trauma, both of which can be caused by a high-speed motor vehicle collision. Clinical features include chest/abdominal wall bruises, decreased breath sounds due to herniation of abdominal contents into the chest, and respiratory distress. Chest auscultation may reveal bowel sounds. Chest x-ray may show disturbed contour of the hemidiaphragm, displaced abdominal organs, and mediastinal shift, as well as an hourglass sign if abdominal contents are constricted at the defect. A CT scan of the chest and abdomen is necessary to confirm the diagnosis.

Diaphragmatic ruptures more commonly occur on the left side because the right diaphragm is protected by the liver. Patients may initially be asymptomatic, so this condition is often not diagnosed immediately.

Esophageal perforation may occur in a variety of clinical scenarios, including Boerhaave syndrome, blunt and penetrating chest trauma, and iatrogenic esophageal perforation (e.g., following endoscopy). Patients with esophageal perforation present with chest pain, tachycardia, and tachypnea. However, this condition is often associated with additional findings such as fever and crepitus over the chest due to mediastinal emphysema. Unlike in this patient, a chest x-ray typically shows a widened mediastinum. Herniation of the stomach into the thorax is not typically associated with esophageal perforation.

Flail chest can cause respiratory distress due to detachment of a segment of the rib cage from the chest wall, which results from three or more adjacent ribs fractured in two or more places. While flail chest can occur following high-velocity trauma, the absence of rib fractures on this patient's chest x-ray rules this condition out.

images.title: Flail chest
images.description: X-ray chest (AP view; supine) of patient with a history of traumaMultiple right rib fractures (red lines) are present, some of which show marked displacement. There is extensive subcutaneous emphysema (examples indicated by arrowheads). The right lung is diffusely opaque (green overlay), likely reflective of pulmonary contusion in view of the trauma history.White overlay: ribs

answers.explanation_why: A pneumothorax can occur spontaneously or following trauma such as a high-speed motor vehicle collision. Patients typically present with tachypnea, dyspnea, chest pain, and unilaterally reduced breath sounds. However, a chest x-ray usually shows a pleural line, a sudden change in radiolucency, and an abrupt stop in pulmonary vascular markings. This patient's x-ray findings are not consistent with a pneumothorax.

images.title: Pneumothorax without tension
images.description: X-ray chest (PA view)A thin white line represents the visceral pleura of the left lung (dotted line). No lung markings are seen peripheral to the visceral pleura (green overlay).The appearance is consistent with a left pneumothorax. There is no evidence of contralateral mediastinal shift, diaphragmatic depression, or ipsilateral intercostal space widening to suggest tension pneumothorax.

answers.explanation_why: The phrenic nerve innervates the diaphragm via the nerve roots C3, C4, and C5. Phrenic nerve palsy is often iatrogenic (e.g., following supraclavicular block) and may occasionally occur following trauma. This condition leads to ipsilateral elevation of the diaphragm, which affects pulmonary and cardiac function. Patients can present with dyspnea. However, x-ray usually shows elevation of the diaphragm on the affected side and not herniation of abdominal contents into the thorax.

images.title: Elevation of the left hemidiaphragm from phrenic nerve paralysis 2/2
images.description: X-ray chest (lateral view)There is elevation of the left hemidiaphragm (dashed line) with adjacent atelectasis (yellow overlay) of lung parenchyma and underlying dilated bowel (B).Blue overlay: hardware left humerus; solid line: right hemidiaphragm

images.title: Posttraumatic diaphragmatic hernia simulating diaphragm elevation
images.description: X-ray chest (PA view) of a patient following thoracic traumaA gas bubble on the left (green overlay) is positioned higher than normal and contains an air-fluid level (line). Additionally, the left hemidiaphragm is elevated, lobulated, and not sharply delineated in its entirety (dashed line).Elevation of a hemidiaphragm can result from abnormalities above, below, or involving the diaphragm. Diaphragmatic rupture can simulate elevation and must be considered in the differential diagnosis of elevation in a trauma setting. A CT scan of this patient confirmed diaphragmatic rupture with the stomach located in the left hemithorax.

question_text: The x-ray findings suggest a diaphragmatic rupture. A trauma 'huddle' is called, and morphine is administered for pain. Low-flow oxygen and infusion with 0.9% saline are begun. Five minutes later, pulse is 100/min and blood pressure is 132/88 mm Hg. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
content_preview: The x-ray findings suggest a diaphragmatic rupture. A trauma 'huddle' is called, and morphine is administered for pain. Low-flow oxygen and infusion with 0.9% saline are begun. Five minutes later, pulse is 100/min and blood pressure is 132/88 mm Hg. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
learning_objective: Recognize suspected traumatic diaphragmatic rupture, and choose the most appropriate diagnostic test.

answers.explanation_why: A barium swallow may be used to confirm suspected diaphragmatic rupture by showing abdominal contents above the diaphragm. However, a barium swallow test is not routinely used in the diagnosis of traumatic diaphragmatic rupture, as the procedure is lengthier and less precise than other procedures and requires the patient's cooperation. Moreover, traumatic diaphragmatic ruptures are often associated with other injuries such as esophageal tears. If barium, a water-insoluble contrast media, enters the mediastinum through a perforation, it may lead to mediastinitis and subsequent fibrosis. A barium study should therefore only be performed after perforations of the gastrointestinal tract have been ruled out.

Chest fluoroscopy may be indicated for suspected phrenic nerve palsy or conditions involving decreased lung elasticity (e.g., interstitial lung diseases). However, this patient presents with signs and symptoms suggestive of diaphragmatic rupture, and his chest x-ray should be followed by a different and more specific imaging technique to confirm the diagnosis.

answers.content: CT of the chest, abdomen, and pelvis
answers.explanation_why: A CT of the chest, abdomen, and pelvis is the most appropriate next step in the management of this patient, who is suspected of having a traumatic diaphragmatic rupture. X-ray findings alone are not sufficient to establish diaphragmatic rupture as the definitive diagnosis, as x-rays only show indirect signs of the injury. Moreover, concomitant injuries should be ruled out. A CT would be able to directly visualize the discontinuity of the affected hemidiaphragm and confirm the diagnosis. Indirect findings include thickening of the diaphragm, elevation of abdominal organs, and herniation of abdominal contents into the thorax.

images.title: Diaphragmatic rupture (1/2)
images.description: Chest CT scan after IV contrast medium administration in the lung window, arterial phase, axial section, at the level of the junction at which the superior vena cava meets the right atrium: There is herniation of the abdominal organs into the left thoracic cavity. These are most likely sections of the stomach (St, with air-fluid levels = green areas) and the spleen (Sp). Parts of the parenchyma of the left lung are still visible in the ventral region. The ground-glass opacified, diffuse areas in the right lung (red areas) most likely indicate a small ventilatory disturbance. In addition, there is either a small hemothorax or pleural effusion visible in the right dorsal field (red hatched area). (AA=ascending aorta, DA=descending aorta, LA=left atrium, LV=left ventricle, RA=right atrium, RV=right ventricle, V=superior vena cava)

answers.explanation_why: ICU admission and observation without any further intervention would be an inappropriate decision for this patient, who requires confirmation of the diaphragmatic rupture and subsequent surgery.

Emergency surgery is the treatment of choice in patients with confirmed diaphragmatic rupture or those who are hemodynamically unstable. However, this patient is hemodynamically stable and only had an x-ray of the chest, which is not sufficient to establish a definite diagnosis. Therefore, he should undergo further diagnostic testing to confirm the diagnosis before undergoing surgery.

Video-assisted thoracoscopic surgery (VATS) may be performed to obtain a biopsy, resect thoracic masses, or even to repair a diaphragmatic rupture in some cases. However, the diagnosis should be confirmed in this patient before treatment is initiated.

MRI of the chest and abdomen can be performed for suspected diaphragmatic injury, as this test is able to directly visualize the discontinuity of the affected hemidiaphragm, which would confirm the diagnosis. However, MRI is not the gold standard in trauma patients since there are other imaging techniques that are faster and almost as precise. MRI is the preferred confirmatory test for pregnant women.
