question_text: A 26-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department 20 minutes after being involved in a high-speed motor vehicle collision in which she was a restrained passenger. On arrival, she is lethargic and incoherent. She is in respiratory distress. Her pulse is 130/min, respirations are 29/min, and blood pressure is 88/58 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 70%. Examination shows multiple facial lacerations. There is dullness to percussion and decreased breath sounds over the left lung base. Abdominal examination shows diffuse tenderness with no guarding or rebound. Bowel sounds are normal. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Her hemoglobin concentration is 8.1 g/dL. An x-ray of the chest shows a fractured left second rib, depression of the left main bronchus, deviation of the nasogastric tube to the right, left pleural effusion, and a widened mediastinum. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
content_preview: A 26-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department 20 minutes after being involved in a high-speed motor vehicle collision in which she was a restrained passenger. On arrival, she is lethargic and incoherent. She is in respiratory distress. Her pulse is 130/min, respirations are 29/min, and blood pressure is 88/58 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 70%. Examination shows multiple facial lacerations. There is dullness to percussion and decreased breath sounds over the left lung base. Abdominal examination shows diffuse tenderness with no guarding or rebound. Bowel sounds are normal. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Her hemoglobin concentration is 8.1 g/dL. An x-ray of the chest shows a fractured left second rib, depression of the left main bronchus, deviation of the nasogastric tube to the right, left pleural effusion, and a widened mediastinum. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
hint: This condition should always be considered in patients presenting with respiratory distress and signs of developing shock after trauma from rapid deceleration (e.g., high-speed motor vehicle collision). The x-ray findings are highly suggestive of the diagnosis.
learning_objective: Recognize thoracic aortic rupture.

answers.explanation_why: Flail chest can manifest with respiratory distress. However, paradoxical chest movement is not present in this patient. Additionally, the chest x-ray shows only one fractured rib, and a widened mediastinum is not associated with flail chest, making it an unlikely diagnosis.

images.title: Pathomechanism of flail chest
images.description: Paradoxical movement of a separate chest wall segment that moves inward during inspiration and outward during expiration. Caused by detachment of a segment of the rib cage from the chest wall due to fracture of three or more adjacent ribs in at least two places.

answers.explanation_why: Diaphragmatic rupture commonly results from blunt or penetrating trauma and occurs more often on the left than on the right side (as the liver protects against a rupture on the right). The condition can manifest with respiratory distress and decreased breath sounds. However, x-ray findings typically show herniation of abdominal organs like the stomach and colon, causing an “hourglass” appearance rather than a widened mediastinum.

images.title: Diaphragmatic rupture
images.description: AP chest X-ray of a 29-year-old patient with chest trauma after a motor-vehicle crash: the tip of the central venous catheter on the right side (black arrows) projects onto the right atrium. The left hemidiaphragm (black dotted line) is much higher than the right one. The stomach is located within the thorax, as can be seen by the circled gastric bubble. The lung tissue shows streaky densities, which hints towards intraparenchymal hemorrhage. The combination of these findings most likely indicates a ruptured diaphragm with a stomach herniated into the thoracic cavity.

answers.explanation_why: Pulmonary contusion typically occurs after blunt trauma and can manifest with tachycardia, respiratory distress, and hypoxia. However, it does not commonly present with dullness on percussion. Additionally, the chest x-ray typically shows patchy alveolar infiltrates and not a widened mediastinum, as described above.

images.title: Pulmonary trauma
images.description: CT chest (axial plane; lung window) following trauma to the chestAreas of ground glass and consolidation in both lungs are the result of pulmonary contusion (green overlay). Ovoid traumatic lacerations in the left lung contain opaque blood (red overlay). Two of the lacerations also contain air, producing air-fluid levels (dashed line). A pneumothorax is present anteriorly in the right hemithorax (blue overlay).

answers.explanation_why: Traumatic bronchial rupture often results from high-velocity blunt chest wall trauma and can manifest with respiratory distress. However, it is typically associated with pneumothorax and subcutaneous emphysema – features not present in this woman.

images.title: Traumatic pneumothorax and pneumomediastinum with subcutaneous emphysema
images.description: X-ray chest (PA view)Extensive subcutaneous emphysema is seen as linear lucencies throughout the soft tissues of the thorax, neck, and upper abdomen (examples indicated by green overlay). A small residual right pneumothorax (arrowheads) is visible and pneumomediastinum is seen along the trachea, main bronchi, and cardiac silhouette (red overlay and arrows). A chest tube (yellow overlay) is in place, with its tip in the apex of the right hemithorax.Pneumomediastinum and pneumothorax can result from blunt or penetrating thoracic injury and various other conditions (e.g., lung disease, intestinal perforation, medical procedure). Air that escapes from the lungs, airways, or bowel can track into the mediastinal and subcutaneous soft tissues.

answers.explanation_why: A widened mediastinum, esophageal deviation, depression of the left main bronchus, and hemothorax (suggested by left pleural effusion) are consistent with thoracic aortic rupture (TAR). TAR can be traumatic (e.g., due to high-velocity blunt chest wall trauma) or spontaneous (e.g., following aortic dissection). Only around 20% of patients with blunt traumatic aortic injuries survive long enough to reach the hospital; therefore, immediate resuscitation and prompt surgical repair of the thoracic aorta is required in patients with suggestive findings (e.g., symptoms of respiratory distress, features of hemorrhagic shock).

images.title: Nontraumatic rupture of the thoracic aorta
images.description: CT chest (with contrast; axial plane)There is extravasation of contrast (red overlay) from the nonaneurysmal atherosclerotic descending thoracic aorta (bright green overlay), with surrounding hematoma (green striped overlay).

answers.explanation_why: Cardiac tamponade results from conditions such as pericarditis, chest trauma, malignancies, or kidney dysfunction. Cardiac tamponade can manifest with respiratory distress. This patient has hypotension, but she does not have the jugular venous distention or muffled heart sounds that would be expected in an individual with cardiac tamponade (Beck’s triad). Additionally, in contrast to this vignette, x-ray findings of cardiac tamponade would typically include an enlarged cardiac silhouette.

images.title: Enlarged cardiac silhouette
images.description: Chest X-ray (PA view) of a patient with a history of pericarditis and clinical findings of tamponadeThe cardiac silhouette is enlarged (globular water bottle-shape; enlargement highlighted by green-hatched overlay) due to pericardial effusion.

answers.explanation_why: While a tension pneumothorax can manifest with tachycardia and hypoxia, the lung is typically hyperresonant and not dull to percussion. Additionally, although mediastinal shift is seen on the chest x-ray of tension pneumothorax, absent lung markings would also be expected and there would not be a widened mediastinum.

images.title: Tension pneumothorax
images.description: X-ray chest (PA view)A large pneumothorax (green overlay) has resulted in collapse of the right lung along the mediastinum (edge marked by white dashed line). No bronchovascular markings are seen in the right hemithorax. Additionally, the mediastinum has shifted to the contralateral left side (blue line and arrows), the right hemidiaphragm is depressed (red line and arrow), and the right intercostal spaces are widened (example indicated by white arrows).These findings are characteristic of tension pneumothorax.

question_text: A 28-year-old man is brought to the emergency department after being struck by a car while he was crossing the street one hour ago. He did not lose consciousness. He has pain in his right arm, forehead, and pelvis. He also has an urge to urinate but has been unable to do so since the accident. He appears uncomfortable. His temperature is 37.1°C (98.9°F), pulse is 72/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 118/82 mm Hg. He is alert and oriented to person, place, and time. There are abrasions over his scalp and face and a 1 x 3 cm area of ecchymosis above his right eye. His pupils are equal, round, and reactive to light. Musculoskeletal examination shows tenderness and ecchymosis over the right distal forearm with intact pulses, sensation, and capillary refill. There is no tenderness of the cervical spine. Abdominal examination shows suprapubic tenderness. A scant amount of blood is present at the urethral meatus. A CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis shows a fracture of both ipsilateral pubic rami. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
content_preview: A 28-year-old man is brought to the emergency department after being struck by a car while he was crossing the street one hour ago. He did not lose consciousness. He has pain in his right arm, forehead, and pelvis. He also has an urge to urinate but has been unable to do so since the accident. He appears uncomfortable. His temperature is 37.1°C (98.9°F), pulse is 72/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 118/82 mm Hg. He is alert and oriented to person, place, and time. There are abrasions over his scalp and face and a 1 x 3 cm area of ecchymosis above his right eye. His pupils are equal, round, and reactive to light. Musculoskeletal examination shows tenderness and ecchymosis over the right distal forearm with intact pulses, sensation, and capillary refill. There is no tenderness of the cervical spine. Abdominal examination shows suprapubic tenderness. A scant amount of blood is present at the urethral meatus. A CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis shows a fracture of both ipsilateral pubic rami. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
hint: Blood at the urethral meatus and features of urinary retention (inability to void, suprapubic pain) in the setting of a pelvic fracture suggest posterior urethral injury.
learning_objective: Recognize posterior urethral injury, and choose the most appropriate diagnostic study.

answers.explanation_why:
Retrograde urethrography is the first step in diagnosing suspected urethral injuries such as posterior urethral injury, which often occurs in patients with pelvic fractures due to blunt force trauma (e.g., from motor vehicle collisions). Contrast extravasation from the urethra indicates the precise location of the injury. In addition to the inability to void and blood at the urethral meatus, both seen here, findings that raise concern for posterior urethral injury include scrotal and perineal ecchymoses and a high-riding prostate on digital rectal examination.

Foley catheterization should be avoided in patients with suspected urethral injury because it may worsen the condition.

Intravenous pyelography can be used in the evaluation of kidney injuries. This patient does not have features suggesting a kidney injury, such as significant blood loss, hemodynamic instability, ipsilateral pain, or hematoma. Furthermore, in recent years, IV pyelography has been largely replaced by contrast-enhanced CT for diagnosing kidney injuries.

Retrograde cystography is used to assess for bladder rupture in patients with a pelvic fracture or gross hematuria due to trauma. However, before performing cystography, urethral injury should be ruled out with a different diagnostic approach.
Foley catheterization is commonly used in patients with urinary retention. However, urethral catheterization should be avoided in suspected urethral injury as it may worsen the condition.

Retroperitoneal ultrasound can be used to evaluate retroperitoneal structures, including the kidneys. However, this patient does not have signs of a kidney injury, such as significant blood loss, hemodynamic instability, ipsilateral pain, or hematoma.

question_text: A 32-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department for the evaluation of burn injuries that she sustained after stumbling into a bonfire 1 hour ago. The patient has severe pain in her left leg and torso, and minimal pain in her right arm. She does not smoke cigarettes. She takes no medications. She is tearful and in moderate distress. Her temperature is 37.2°C (99.0°F), pulse is 88/min, respirations are 19/min, and blood pressure is 118/65 mm Hg. Her pulse oximetry is 98% on room air. Cardiopulmonary examination shows no abnormalities. There are two tender, blanchable erythemas without blisters over a 5 x 6-cm area of the left abdomen and a 3 x 2-cm area of the left anterior thigh. There is also an area of white, leathery skin and tissue necrosis encircling the right upper extremity just proximal to the elbow, which is dry and nontender. An ECG shows normal sinus rhythm with no ST or T wave changes. Administration of intravenous fluids is begun. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
content_preview: A 32-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department for the evaluation of burn injuries that she sustained after stumbling into a bonfire 1 hour ago. The patient has severe pain in her left leg and torso, and minimal pain in her right arm. She does not smoke cigarettes. She takes no medications. She is tearful and in moderate distress. Her temperature is 37.2°C (99.0°F), pulse is 88/min, respirations are 19/min, and blood pressure is 118/65 mm Hg. Her pulse oximetry is 98% on room air. Cardiopulmonary examination shows no abnormalities. There are two tender, blanchable erythemas without blisters over a 5 x 6-cm area of the left abdomen and a 3 x 2-cm area of the left anterior thigh. There is also an area of white, leathery skin and tissue necrosis encircling the right upper extremity just proximal to the elbow, which is dry and nontender. An ECG shows normal sinus rhythm with no ST or T wave changes. Administration of intravenous fluids is begun. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
hint: This patient has a 3^rd degree (full-thickness) circumferential burn on her right upper extremity, as indicated by the encircling white, leathery skin and necrosis without feeling. Such burns may lead to distal ischemia and compartment syndrome.
learning_objective: Recognize full-thickness circumferential burns, and choose the most appropriate monitoring for complications.

answers.explanation_why: Serial arterial blood gas analysis is indicated in burn patients if inhalation injury is suspected. Such patients would include those presenting with dyspnea, coughing, wheezing, patients trapped in confined spaces, or who lose consciousness in the presence of heavy smoke. The patient is stable and breathing normally, and did not experience any of these situations.
A soft-tissue ultrasound is indicated for the evaluation of lymph nodes and conditions, such as cellulitis and abscess, but it is not useful for the diagnosis of compartment syndrome.

Ampicillin (or any other systemic antibiotic) is currently not recommended for prophylaxis of infections in burn patients because of a lack of supporting evidence. Although systemic antibiotics have a role in the treatment of burn wound infections, the patient was brought in just after the burn occurred; a potential infection would not have had time to develop yet.

answers.content: Monitoring of peripheral pulses and capillary filling
answers.explanation_why: Regular monitoring of peripheral pulses and capillary filling is indicated in this patient because of her risk for distal ischemia. Her circumferential burn may impair blood flow to the limb secondary to a loss of skin elasticity (due to a developing eschar) or result in compartment syndrome (caused by an accumulation of fluids) during the healing process.

Severely burned patients are at risk of developing acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) because the extensive tissue damage may lead to a massive release of inflammatory mediators. A chest x-ray is therefore indicated in burn patients who present with symptoms of ARDS (e.g., dyspnea, tachypnea, low oxygen saturation, cyanosis). However, this is not the case for this patient, who is hemodynamically stable and breathing normally.

question_text: Three hours later, the patient is reassessed. Her right arm is put in an elevated position and a physical examination of the extremity is performed. The examination reveals reduced capillary return and peripheral pallor. Pulse oximetry of her right index finger on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 84%. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
content_preview: Three hours later, the patient is reassessed. Her right arm is put in an elevated position and a physical examination of the extremity is performed. The examination reveals reduced capillary return and peripheral pallor. Pulse oximetry of her right index finger on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 84%. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
hint: This patient's circumferential burn can cut off blood supply to the extremity.
learning_objective: Recognize impaired perfusion secondary to circumferential burn, and choose the most appropriate intervention.

answers.explanation_why: Fasciotomy is the treatment of choice for acute compartment syndrome (ACS). While this woman shows signs of compromised distal perfusion (reduced capillary refill, pallor, and peripheral O_2 saturation of 84%) that could also be due to developing ACS, the vascular compromise is more likely caused by the circumferential eschar itself. Furthermore, ACS is generally associated with severe pain, often out of proportion to the extent of the injury. This patient only has minimal pain in her right arm, resulting from the third-degree burn that has destroyed the cutaneous nerves. Sensation of the deeper layers, including the muscle compartments, however, should still be intact.

Amputation of the extremity may be indicated in patients with severe fourth-degree burns. It is also the last resort in patients with acute compartment syndrome and/or acute limb ischemia who present very late (3–5 days) after onset with a nonviable limb. This woman has a third-degree burn, and although her findings suggest beginning vascular compromise (reduced capillary refill, pallor, and a peripheral O_2 saturation of 84%), less radical measures are indicated first to restore blood flow.

A split-thickness skin graft is a definitive treatment option for third-degree burns, such as the wound on this patient's right arm. However, definitive management is only considered after all immediate measures have been carried out. This patient presents acutely with signs of vascular compromise, as indicated by the reduced capillary refill; blood flow needs to be restored as soon as possible to prevent compartment syndrome and acute limb ischemia.

This patient has extensive burns on her arm, leg, and torso. Adequate fluid resuscitation is an important part of the immediate measures for severe burn wounds to counter the fluid loss/shift and to prevent dehydration and associated complications such as acute kidney injury and shock. The circumferential edema that results from the burn eschar and causes compromised perfusion of her arm is likely exacerbated by fluid replacement, but decreasing the rate of IV fluids is not the appropriate therapeutic measure to resolve the vascular compromise.

Escharotomy is the treatment of choice for third-degree (full-thickness) circumferential burns leading to impaired perfusion of the extremity, such as the burn on this patient's right arm. Reduced capillary return, peripheral pallor, and markedly reduced oxygen saturation indicate vascular compromise secondary to the developing eschar and the associated constriction caused by the edematous, unyielding skin. If perfusion is not restored in a timely manner, compartment syndrome and acute limb ischemia may result.

images.title: Third-degree burn (full-thickness burn)
images.description: Photograph of the chest and right shoulderThe skin appears dry, leathery, and black, indicating tissue necrosis (eschar). There is no visible blistering.These features are characteristic of a third-degree burn, which affects all the layers of the skin (i.e., the epidermis, dermis, and subcutaneous tissue).

question_text: A 75-year-old man is brought to the emergency department because of a 5-hour history of worsening chest pain and dyspnea. Six days ago, he fell in the shower and since then has had mild pain in his left chest. He appears pale and anxious. His temperature is 36.5°C (97.7°F), pulse is 108/min, respirations are 30/min, and blood pressure is 115/58 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 88%. Examination shows decreased breath sounds and dullness to percussion over the left lung base. There is a 3-cm (1.2-in) hematoma over the left lower chest. An x-ray of the chest shows fractures of the left 8^th and 9^th rib, increased opacity of the left lung, and mild tracheal deviation to the right. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
content_preview: A 75-year-old man is brought to the emergency department because of a 5-hour history of worsening chest pain and dyspnea. Six days ago, he fell in the shower and since then has had mild pain in his left chest. He appears pale and anxious. His temperature is 36.5°C (97.7°F), pulse is 108/min, respirations are 30/min, and blood pressure is 115/58 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 88%. Examination shows decreased breath sounds and dullness to percussion over the left lung base. There is a 3-cm (1.2-in) hematoma over the left lower chest. An x-ray of the chest shows fractures of the left 8th and 9th rib, increased opacity of the left lung, and mild tracheal deviation to the right. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
hint: Chest pain, dyspnea, decreased breath sounds, and dullness to percussion over the left lung base following a rib fracture in conjunction with this patient's x-ray findings (increased opacity and tracheal deviation to the contralateral side) suggest a large hemothorax.
learning_objective: Recognize a large hemothorax, and choose the most appropriate intervention for chest drainage.

answers.content: Admission to the ICU and observation
answers.explanation_why: Most patients with a hemothorax will require admission to the ICU. However, a large hemothorax must be drained immediately because blood in the pleural cavity may clot if not evacuated, resulting in a trapped lung (impaired lung expansion due to the clot) or an empyema (due to clot infection).

answers.content: Needle thoracostomy in the second intercostal space at the midclavicular line
answers.explanation_why: Insertion of a needle in the second intercostal space at the midclavicular line can be used as an emergency treatment for tension pneumothorax because it allows the trapped air in the pleural cavity to escape. Tension pneumothorax may develop if a rib fracture causes a pulmonary laceration that fails to seal and can manifest with chest pain, dyspnea, decreased breath sounds, and contralateral deviation of the trachea. However, a patient with pneumothorax would have hyperresonant lung fields on percussion instead of dullness on the affected site. Also, a chest x-ray would show increased radiolucency and decreased lung markings rather than increased opacity.

images.title: Tension pneumothorax
images.description: X-ray chest (PA view)A large pneumothorax (green overlay) has resulted in collapse of the right lung along the mediastinum (edge marked by white dashed line). No bronchovascular markings are seen in the right hemithorax. Additionally, the mediastinum has shifted to the contralateral left side (blue line and arrows), the right hemidiaphragm is depressed (red line and arrow), and the right intercostal spaces are widened (example indicated by white arrows).These findings are characteristic of tension pneumothorax.

answers.content: Needle thoracentesis in the eighth intercostal space at the posterior axillary line
answers.explanation_why: Needle thoracocentesis in the eighth intercostal space at the posterior axillary line, with the patient in a supine position, is used for diagnostic pleural taps. Needle aspiration is not the treatment of choice for a hemothorax because a drain with a larger caliber is required for complete evacuation of blood from the pleural cavity. Incomplete evacuation of blood may lead to clot formation and subsequently a trapped lung (impaired lung expansion due to the clot) or an empyema (due to clot infection).

In a patient with a hemothorax, urgent thoracotomy is indicated if more than 1500 mL of blood has been drained from the pleural cavity, if the rate of blood loss exceeds 200 mL/hour for 2–4 hours, and/or if multiple transfusions are required. However, thoracotomy is not the first-line therapy because a different procedure should first be employed to improve lung expansion and to assess the amount of blood loss.

Pericardiocentesis is the treatment of choice for cardiac tamponade, which can result from hemopericardium following thoracic trauma and manifests with dyspnea and chest pain. However, a hemopericardium usually develops following penetrating injuries to the chest wall and is unlikely in a patient with low-energy blunt chest trauma. Moreover, this patient has none of the classical clinical manifestations of cardiac tamponade, which include low systolic blood pressure (due to decreased stroke volume), distention of neck veins (due to impaired right ventricular filling), and/or muffled heart sounds. Tracheal deviation and increased lung opacity are not associated with isolated cardiac tamponade. Instead, a chest x-ray is likely to reveal an enlarged cardiac silhouette.

answers.content: Chest tube insertion in the fifth intercostal space at the midaxillary line
answers.explanation_why:
Chest tube insertion into the 4^th to 5^th intercostal space at the midaxillary line is the treatment of choice for all patients with moderate to large hemothoraces. Alternatively, the chest tube can be inserted into lower intercostal spaces with ultrasound guidance. The chest tube should be placed posteriorly for optimal fluid drainage. A hemothorax must be drained in most cases because blood in the pleural cavity will clot if not evacuated, resulting in a trapped lung (impaired lung expansion due to the clot) or an empyema (due to clot infection). Conservative management may be considered to treat small hemothoraces in consultation with a specialist but has a significant failure rate.

Thoracotomy is indicated if chest tube output is > 1500 mL directly after placement, 200 mL/hour for 2–4 hours, or if multiple transfusions are required.

images.title: Hemothorax following rib fracture
images.description: X-ray chest (PA view) of patient with history of rib fracture from a fall 10 days prior and left-sided chest pain accompanied by new dyspnea and orthopneaThe margins of the descending thoracic aorta (dashed line) and left hemidiaphragm are obscured by extensive air space disease (green overlay) and pleural effusion; a meniscus (red line) helps confirm the presence of the effusion. In view of the trauma history, the likely causes are pulmonary contusion and hemothorax. The slightly high position of the gastric bubble (GB) also suggests the presence of left lower lobe atelectasis. The right lung and cardiac silhouette are normal.Circle: fracture of the anterior left seventh rib

question_text: A 29-year-old man is brought to the emergency department 20 minutes after sustaining a gunshot wound to the abdomen. On arrival, he is awake and oriented to person, place, and time. He appears agitated. His pulse is 102/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 115/70 mm Hg. The pupils are equal and reactive to light. Abdominal examination shows an entrance wound in the right upper quadrant above the umbilicus. There is an exit wound on the right lower back next to the lumbar spine. Breath sounds are normal bilaterally. There is diffuse mild tenderness to palpation with no guarding or rebound. Cardiac examination shows no abnormalities. Intravenous fluid therapy is begun. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
content_preview: A 29-year-old man is brought to the emergency department 20 minutes after sustaining a gunshot wound to the abdomen. On arrival, he is awake and oriented to person, place, and time. He appears agitated. His pulse is 102/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 115/70 mm Hg. The pupils are equal and reactive to light. Abdominal examination shows an entrance wound in the right upper quadrant above the umbilicus. There is an exit wound on the right lower back next to the lumbar spine. Breath sounds are normal bilaterally. There is diffuse mild tenderness to palpation with no guarding or rebound. Cardiac examination shows no abnormalities. Intravenous fluid therapy is begun. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
hint: This hemodynamically stable patient with penetrating abdominal trauma and no guarding or rebound tenderness on abdominal examination requires evaluation of the extent of injury.
learning_objective: Choose the most appropriate diagnostic test for a hemodynamically stable patient with penetrating abdominal trauma and no signs of peritonitis.

answers.explanation_why:
In patients with penetrating abdominal trauma, the presence of hemodynamic instability, hematemesis, rectal bleeding, signs of peritonitis (e.g., rebound tenderness and/or guarding), or evisceration warrant immediate surgical intervention. This patient's blood pressure and mental state are normal, and the examination of the abdomen does not reveal guarding, rebound tenderness, or evisceration. An abdominal CT scan is therefore indicated to assess the extent of injury and detect intraabdominal bleeding. A CT scan is also helpful for subsequent planning of surgical procedures and identifying patients who can be managed conservatively.

Patients with penetrating abdominal trauma may undergo FAST prior to a CT scan. Although FAST is highly specific for hemopericardium and hemoperitoneum, this test has low sensitivity (especially for hollow organ or diaphragmatic injuries with minimal bleeding).
This patient's condition warrants close observation, including monitoring of vital signs. However, the extent of injury should be evaluated first with a different intervention.

Diagnostic laparoscopy may be used for the evaluation of patients with penetrating abdominal trauma secondary to gunshot. However, this procedure does not allow for complete visualization of the posterior portion of the diaphragm or retroperitoneal injuries.

In patients with penetrating abdominal trauma (e.g., resulting from a gunshot wound), immediate laparotomy should be performed if a reliable assessment cannot be made or if one or more of the following are present: hemodynamic instability, hematemesis, rectal bleeding, signs of peritonitis, evisceration. This patient is hemodynamically stable and examination of the abdomen does not reveal guarding, rebound tenderness, or evisceration. Further examination is warranted at this time.

Diagnostic peritoneal lavage was once considered the gold standard for the evaluation of patients with penetrating abdominal trauma, but it is now seldom performed and has been replaced by newer diagnostic tools that can provide more detailed information about the structures involved.

question_text: A 3-year-old boy is brought to the physician because of arm pain following a fall that took place 5 hours ago. According to his mother, the boy was running in the yard when he fell and injured his right arm. The boy is crying and clutching his arm. During the past year, he has been brought in 4 other times for extremity pain following falls, all of which have been diagnosed as long bone fractures. He is at the 10^th percentile for height and 25^th percentile for weight. His temperature is 37.3°C (99.1°F), pulse is 95/min, respirations are 21/min, and blood pressure is 97/68 mm Hg. His right forearm is diffusely erythematous. The patient withdraws and yells when his forearm is touched. His left arm has two small ecchymotic regions overlying the elbow and wrist. A photograph of his eyes is shown. An x-ray of the right forearm shows a transverse mid-ulnar fracture with diffusely decreased bone density. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?
content_preview: A 3-year-old boy is brought to the physician because of arm pain following a fall that took place 5 hours ago. According to his mother, the boy was running in the yard when he fell and injured his right arm. The boy is crying and clutching his arm. During the past year, he has been brought in 4 other times for extremity pain following falls, all of which have been diagnosed as long bone fractures. He is at the 10th percentile for height and 25th percentile for weight. His temperature is 37.3°C (99.1°F), pulse is 95/min, respirations are 21/min, and blood pressure is 97/68 mm Hg. His right forearm is diffusely erythematous. The patient withdraws and yells when his forearm is touched. His left arm has two small ecchymotic regions overlying the elbow and wrist. A photograph of his eyes is shown. An x-ray of the right forearm shows a transverse mid-ulnar fracture with diffusely decreased bone density. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?
hint: This patient presents with short stature, recurrent bone fractures, blue sclera, and osteopenia, all of which are consistent with the diagnosis of osteogenesis imperfecta.
learning_objective: Recognize osteogenesis imperfecta, and recall its genetic basis.

answers.explanation_why: Type 5 collagen is a regulator of type 1 collagen fibrillogenesis. Type 5 collagen defects usually manifest as classic Ehlers-Danlos syndrome, which is characterized by chronic joint and bone issues. Rather than frequent bone fractures, the major symptoms are joint instability, early onset of osteoarthritis, hyperflexible joints, and scoliosis.

Non-accidental injury, i.e., child abuse, must always be considered in the differential diagnosis of children with growth retardation and concomitant fractures, especially those with multiple or recurrent fractures such as this boy. However, the presence of osteopenia suggests a metabolic disease as the cause. Additionally, the finding of blue sclerae is unique to patients with osteogenesis imperfecta, who have sclerae that are thinner than usual and allow the underlying choroidal veins to shine through.

Type 2 collagen defects predominantly affect tissues such as cartilage and vitreous humor. Various conditions are associated with type 2 collagen defects (e.g., hypochondrogenesis, Kniest dysplasia, or osteoarthritis) and these differ substantially in presentation and age of onset. While some conditions could explain the growth retardation observed in this patient (e.g., hypochondrogenesis, Kniest dysplasia), blue sclerae and recurrent bone fractures in an otherwise healthy child would not be consistent with any type 2 collagen defect.

The vascular type of Ehlers-Danlos syndrome (type 4) arises from an autosomal mutation in type 3 collagen. This condition manifests predominantly in the cardiovascular system and often goes undiagnosed until it becomes apparent through some sort of vascular damage/injury (e.g., aortic dissection, ruptures arterial aneurysm, subarachnoid hemorrhage). The child presents with easy bruising, as evidenced by the ecchymosis, which is also a feature of Ehlers-Danlos type 4. However, the child's history of frequent fractures after minor trauma, the blue sclerae, and growth retardation are not consistent with this condition.

Vitamin D deficiency can cause rickets in children, which manifests with growth retardation, bone deformities, and osteopenia. However, blue sclerae and recurrent bone fractures are not seen in rickets. Patients at risk for developing vitamin D deficiency include premature infants, dark-skinned children on vegetarian and unusual diets, children living at higher latitudes, and children with malabsorption conditions. This patient has none of these risk factors.

images.title: Rickets secondary to vitamin D deficiency fact sheet

answers.explanation_why: Mutations to the genes encoding type 4 collagen can manifest as Alport syndrome. This disorder usually affects boys, who present with intermittent gross hematuria, hearing loss, and ocular disturbances, none of which are seen here. Recurrent bone fractures, growth retardation, and blue sclerae are not features of Alport syndrome.

A mutation in type 1 collagen causes osteogenesis imperfecta type 1, the mildest and most common form of osteogenesis imperfecta. In fact, some patients with osteogenesis imperfecta type 1 appear normal and without obvious deformities to the casual observer despite requiring special accommodations for their bone fragility.

The prognosis depends heavily on the type of osteogenesis imperfecta. People with type 1 often have a normal life expectancy, no long-bone deformities, and few childhood fractures. Type 2 osteogenesis imperfecta is the most severe form, with most affected children dying in utero or within the first year of life due to respiratory failure secondary to underdeveloped lungs or intracerebral hemorrhage.

Scleral manifestations of osteogenesis imperfecta

question_text: An 11-year-old girl is brought to the emergency department 1 hour after falling from her bicycle. The girl was racing with her cousin when she lost control and fell onto her right side. She has nausea and severe pain in the right shoulder. She is in acute distress. Her temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 85/min, respirations are 15/min, and blood pressure is 135/85 mm Hg. Examination shows swelling and tenderness over the right clavicle and pain exacerbated by movement; range of motion is limited. The skin over the clavicle is intact. The radial pulse in the right arm is intact. Sensory examination of the right upper limb shows no abnormalities. An x‑ray of the chest is shown. In addition to analgesia, which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management for this patient's shoulder?
content_preview: An 11-year-old girl is brought to the emergency department 1 hour after falling from her bicycle. The girl was racing with her cousin when she lost control and fell onto her right side. She has nausea and severe pain in the right shoulder. She is in acute distress. Her temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 85/min, respirations are 15/min, and blood pressure is 135/85 mm Hg. Examination shows swelling and tenderness over the right clavicle and pain exacerbated by movement; range of motion is limited. The skin over the clavicle is intact. The radial pulse in the right arm is intact. Sensory examination of the right upper limb shows no abnormalities. An x‑ray of the chest is shown. In addition to analgesia, which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management for this patient's shoulder?
hint: This patient has shoulder pain, limited range of motion, and tenderness and swelling over the clavicle. The skin is intact, and there is no evidence of neurovascular damage. The x-ray shows a nondisplaced midshaft fracture of the clavicle.
learning_objective: Recognize a nondisplaced midshaft fracture of the clavicle, and choose the most appropriate management.

answers.explanation_why: Tension band wiring using K-wires is performed for unstable lateral clavicle fractures, which have an increased risk of nonunion. Tension band wiring is not the treatment of choice for midshaft fractures.

In a patient with a midclavicular fracture, open reduction and internal fixation (ORIF) with a clavicular plate is indicated only in the presence of one of the following: tenting and blanching of the overlying skin, open fracture, severe displacement or > 2 cm of shortening, neurovascular injury, floating shoulder injury, or established nonunion. For nondisplaced midclavicular fractures, ORIF is not indicated; these fractures typically heal well, and surgery might actually increase the incidence of delayed union or nonunion.

A shoulder spica cast is not the technique of choice for shoulder immobilization in a patient with a clavicular fracture. This cast is bulky, difficult to apply, does not allow early physiotherapy, and is associated with an increased risk of adhesive capsulitis (frozen shoulder).

Conservative treatment with a simple shoulder sling for 4–8 weeks is the treatment of choice for nondisplaced midshaft fractures of the clavicle because these fractures typically heal very well without significant intervention. After 2–4 weeks, physiotherapy should be initiated. Excessively shortened or displaced fractures require surgery.

images.title: Broad arm sling using triangular bandage

answers.content: Obtain an MRI of the right shoulder
answers.explanation_why: For unstable clavicular fractures, a plain MRI of the shoulder is used to assess the conoid and trapezoid ligaments (coracoclavicular ligaments), the acromioclavicular joint, and the sternoclavicular joint. However, injury to these structures is unlikely in this patient, since she has an isolated midclavicular fracture from low-energy trauma.

Arteriography is only indicated if injury to the subclavian vessels is suspected (e.g., if radial or brachial pulses are weak or a bruit over the fracture site is heard). Since peripheral pulses are intact in this patient, arteriography is not required. In addition, injury to subclavian vessels following a clavicular fracture due to blunt trauma is extremely rare.

images.title: Acute nondisplaced fracture of the right clavicle
images.description: X-ray right clavicle (AP view) of a child after a recent fall on an outstretched armA subtle nondisplaced fracture (green overlay) is seen at the mid to medial third of the right clavicle. There is no callus formation.Arrowheads: overlying artefact; red overlay: growth plate

question_text: A 73-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department after she sustained a fall 3 hours ago. The patient was walking down the stairs when she lost her balance and fell onto the right side of her body. She did not lose consciousness. She has nausea, pain in her right hip, and has not been able to walk since the fall. She has hypertension, type 2 diabetes mellitus, and osteoporosis. She lives with her daughter. She is independent in all of her activities of daily living and instrumental activities of daily living. She walks 2 miles every other day. She smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 30 years but quit 10 years ago. Current medications include atorvastatin, ramipril, metformin, and a multivitamin. She is 163 cm (5 ft 4 in) tall and weighs 50 kg (110 lb); BMI is 19 kg/m^2. She appears pale. Vital signs are within normal limits. The right leg seems shorter than the left and is rotated externally. Pulses are intact in both lower extremities. Palpation of the right hip causes severe pain and the range of motion is limited. An x-ray of the right hip is shown. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
content_preview: A 73-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department after she sustained a fall 3 hours ago. The patient was walking down the stairs when she lost her balance and fell onto the right side of her body. She did not lose consciousness. She has nausea, pain in her right hip, and has not been able to walk since the fall. She has hypertension, type 2 diabetes mellitus, and osteoporosis. She lives with her daughter. She is independent in all of her activities of daily living and instrumental activities of daily living. She walks 2 miles every other day. She smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 30 years but quit 10 years ago. Current medications include atorvastatin, ramipril, metformin, and a multivitamin. She is 163 cm (5 ft 4 in) tall and weighs 50 kg (110 lb); BMI is 19 kg/m2. She appears pale. Vital signs are within normal limits. The right leg seems shorter than the left and is rotated externally. Pulses are intact in both lower extremities. Palpation of the right hip causes severe pain and the range of motion is limited. An x-ray of the right hip is shown. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
hint: This patient's x-ray shows an intertrochanteric fracture.
learning_objective: Recognize an intertrochanteric fracture, and choose the most appropriate surgical treatment.

answers.explanation_why: Nonweightbearing would be appropriate management for an older, nonambulatory patient who has poor physical function and is not a candidate for operative management. Since this patient was physically active and independent in her activities of daily living as well as instrumental activities of daily living with a walking routine, nonweightbearing conservative management is not an appropriate option here.

External fixation may be appropriate for unstable polytrauma patients in whom more critical interventions are prioritized, in patients with vascular injury, or in patients with severe open fractures. This patient's presentation is consistent with an isolated closed intertrochanteric femoral fracture. In addition, as her lower extremity pulses are intact bilaterally, she has no signs of vascular injury. Therefore, management with external fixation is inappropriate for this patient.

images.title: External fixation of a comminuted fracture of the tibia
images.description: External fixation is a method of immobilizing a fracture using devices (e.g., pins, screws, etc) that are secured outside the skin (in contrast to internal fixation, in which the devices are placed completely inside the body).

answers.explanation_why:
Definitive surgical treatment is indicated for active, independent patients. First-line surgical treatment for a stable intertrochanteric fracture is internal fixation using either an intramedullary nail or a dynamic hip screw.

Femoral fractures are only considered a surgical emergency if there is vascular compromise, which is limb-threatening. This patient does not require emergent surgery.

images.title: Intramedullary nail (gamma locking nail)
images.description: Osteosynthesis of an intertrochanteric fracture using a gamma locking nail: An intramedullary nail is placed directly into the bone marrow through the greater trochanter and held in position using a distal fixation screw. A lag screw is then placed through the nail, which enters the neck and head of the femur. This nail also allows for compression (weight-bearing) of the fracture site. The combination of intramedullary nail and lag screw resembles the Greek letter "γ" (gamma), which is why it is called a gamma locking nail.

answers.explanation_why: Early weightbearing with physical therapy would be appropriate management for someone with soft tissue injury. However, as this patient has the hallmark clinical signs and x-ray findings consistent with intertrochanteric fracture, early mobility would be inappropriate. Without appropriate prior fixation of the fracture, ambulation could displace the fracture and lead to malunion or nonunion. This physically active patient needs fixation of her fracture first, followed by ambulation with physical therapy.

Total hip replacement may be considered for injuries of both the femur and the pelvis, or for femoral neck fractures in older patients in which arthritic changes or poor bone quality affect the acetabulum. However, this patient has an isolated intertrochanteric fracture rather than a fracture of the femoral neck or pelvis.

images.title: Total hip replacement
images.description:
(1) Removal of the damaged femoral head from the acetabulum and resection of the femoral head and neck along the line between the greater and the lesser trochanter (red line)
(2) Enlargement of the acetabulum and the medullary cavity of the femur
(3) Insertion of the prosthesis stem into the femoral canal and insertion of the artificial socket and inlay into the widened acetabulum
4) Reduction of the prosthetic head into the prosthetic socket

answers.explanation_why: Hip hemiarthroplasty is the appropriate management for a femoral head fracture close enough to the hip joint for the free femoral bone fragment to likely have compromised blood supply, resulting in avascular necrosis. This would also be appropriate for an older patient with a femoral neck fracture that is displaced or has poor bone quality. However, as this patient has an intertrochanteric fracture, she will likely only need arthroplasty as second-line treatment or if the fracture is significantly unstable.

Traction screws are used to counteract the opposing pull of the thigh muscles on bone fragments. This serves to both prevent displacement of the fracture and to decrease bleeding and pain. This treatment method, combined with other conservative treatments (e.g., stabilization using a splint, analgesia), would be appropriate in older patients with too many comorbidities to safely undergo surgery, or in very young patients. However, since this older patient is relatively healthy and active, she is a safe candidate for definitive surgical management.

images.title: Intertrochanteric femoral fracture
images.description: X-ray right hip (AP view)A comminuted intertrochanteric fracture (fragments indicated by green, white, and yellow overlay) of the right femur is accompanied by superior displacement of the femoral shaft and distraction (indicated by red dashed lines and arrows) of the main fracture fragments.

question_text:
A 56-year-old man is brought to the emergency department after falling 16 feet from a ladder. He has severe pain in both his legs and his right arm. He appears pale and diaphoretic. He is 165 cm (5 ft 5 in) tall and weighs 70 kg (154 lb); BMI is 26 kg/m^2. His temperature is 37.5°C (99.5°F), pulse is 120/min and weak, respirations are 26/min, and blood pressure is 80/50 mm Hg. He opens his eyes and withdraws in response to painful stimuli and makes incomprehensible sounds. The abdomen is soft and nontender. All extremities are cold, with 1+ pulses distally. Arterial blood gas analysis on room air shows:

pH
7.29

PCO_2

33 mm Hg

PO_2

65 mm Hg

HCO_3^-

15 mEq/L

A CT scan shows displaced fractures of the pelvic ring, as well as fractures of both tibiae, the right distal radius, and right proximal humerus. The patient undergoes emergent open reduction and is admitted to the intensive care unit. Which of the following best indicates inadequate fluid resuscitation?
content_preview: A 56-year-old man is brought to the emergency department after falling 16 feet from a ladder. He has severe pain in both his legs and his right arm. He appears pale and diaphoretic. He is 165 cm (5 ft 5 in) tall and weighs 70 kg (154 lb); BMI is 26 kg/m2. His temperature is 37.5°C (99.5°F), pulse is 120/min and weak, respirations are 26/min, and blood pressure is 80/50 mm Hg. He opens his eyes and withdraws in response to painful stimuli and makes incomprehensible sounds. The abdomen is soft and nontender. All extremities are cold, with 1+ pulses distally. Arterial blood gas analysis on room air shows: pH 7.29 PCO2 33 mm Hg PO2 65 mm Hg HCO3- 15 mEq/L A CT scan shows displaced fractures of the pelvic ring, as well as fractures of both tibiae, the right distal radius, and right proximal humerus. The patient undergoes emergent open reduction and is admitted to the intensive care unit. Which of the following best indicates inadequate fluid resuscitation?
hint: There are many ways that physicians monitor volume status, but some are more reliable than others in the absence of confounding medications or illnesses.
learning_objective: Recognize indicators of inadequate fluid resuscitation, and recall the expected urine output for adequate end-organ perfusion.

answers.explanation_why: High pulse pressure is usually caused by an increase in stroke volume (e.g., normal exercise, aortic regurgitation) or a decrease in arterial compliance (e.g., atherosclerosis) and would likely increase following fluid resuscitation. However, pulse pressure is an indicator of stroke volume and not a direct indicator of end-organ perfusion. Fluid resuscitation aims to achieve adequate end-organ perfusion, so a change in pulse pressure is not the best indicator to evaluate fluid resuscitation.

answers.content: Urine output of 25 mL in 3 hours
answers.explanation_why:
The goal of fluid resuscitation is to maintain adequate end-organ perfusion and to restore intravascular volume. Since renal blood flow (and therefore GFR) is highly sensitive to changes in blood pressure and intravascular volume, urine output can serve as a surrogate measure to determine if fluid resuscitation is adequate. Ideally, urine output in adults should be greater than 0.5 mL/kg/hr. Therefore, a 70-kg man should have a urine output of 35–70 mL/hr. A urine output of 25mL in 3 hours suggests that his kidneys are not receiving adequate blood flow and therefore that he has not received adequate fluid resuscitation.

With adequate fluid resuscitation, an increase in some of the other indices, such as pulse pressure and Glasgow coma scale, might occur before a change in urine output is apparent. However, these parameters are not specific indicators of end-organ perfusion. Other parameters, such as lactate and a base deficit, are more useful for determining the prognosis than for guiding fluid therapy.

Confusion, lethargy, and even coma can be seen in patients with severe shock. However, a low Glasgow coma score (GCS) following trauma may be caused by a number of factors, including hypotension, hypoxia, and intracranial hemorrhage. Therefore, the GCS should not be used as a guide for fluid therapy.

An increase in serum lactate (> 4 mEq/L) may indicate tissue hypoxia due to inadequate tissue perfusion. However, serum lactate levels are not used to determine whether fluid resuscitation is inadequate because, even after adequate fluid resuscitation and correction of tissue hypoperfusion, lactate levels may not reach normal levels (< 2 mEq/L) for a few hours. Lactate clearance may take even longer in critically ill patients as a result of a prolonged lactate half-life (due to hepatic and/or renal dysfunction) and/or increased glycolysis. In trauma patients, elevated lactate levels are associated with increased mortality and are used to evaluate the prognosis.

A prolonged capillary refill time (≥ 3 seconds) is seen as a result of peripheral vasoconstriction in patients with hypotension. However, capillary refill is not the most direct measure of organ perfusion and adequate volume resuscitation, as it can be affected by confounding factors (e.g., ambient temperature, lighting, physical exam techniques, peripheral artery disease, blood viscosity).

This patient has an increased base deficit (> 2 mEq/L), which indicates metabolic acidosis (most likely due to lactic acidosis from inadequate perfusion and fluid resuscitation). Normalization of the base deficit (< 2 mmol/L) following fluid resuscitation would suggest an improvement in tissue perfusion and a more favorable prognosis, not inadequate fluid resuscitation.

question_text: A 44-year-old woman comes to the physician for the evaluation of right knee pain for 1 week. The pain began after the patient twisted her knee during basketball practice. At the time of the injury, she felt a popping sensation and her knee became swollen over the next few hours. The pain is exacerbated by walking up or down stairs and worsens throughout the day. She also reports occasional locking of the knee. She has been taking acetaminophen during the past week, but the pain is worse today. Her mother has rheumatoid arthritis. The patient is 155 cm (4 ft 11 in) tall and weighs 75 kg (165 lb); BMI is 33 kg/m^2. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows effusion of the right knee; range of motion is limited by pain. There is medial joint line tenderness. Knee extension with rotation results in an audible snap. Further evaluation is most likely to show which of the following?
content_preview: A 44-year-old woman comes to the physician for the evaluation of right knee pain for 1 week. The pain began after the patient twisted her knee during basketball practice. At the time of the injury, she felt a popping sensation and her knee became swollen over the next few hours. The pain is exacerbated by walking up or down stairs and worsens throughout the day. She also reports occasional locking of the knee. She has been taking acetaminophen during the past week, but the pain is worse today. Her mother has rheumatoid arthritis. The patient is 155 cm (4 ft 11 in) tall and weighs 75 kg (165 lb); BMI is 33 kg/m2. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows effusion of the right knee; range of motion is limited by pain. There is medial joint line tenderness. Knee extension with rotation results in an audible snap. Further evaluation is most likely to show which of the following?
hint: Given the acute onset knee pain with a history of locking and popping, joint line tenderness, and a positive McMurray test, a meniscal tear is the most likely diagnosis.
learning_objective: Recognize a meniscal tear, and recall its diagnostic MRI finding.

answers.content: Joint space narrowing and sclerotic changes on x-ray
answers.explanation_why: Joint space narrowing and sclerotic changes (along with osteophytes and subchondral cysts) are characteristic x-ray findings in patients with osteoarthritis (OA), which most commonly affects the knee. Although osteoarthritis, for which this patient is at risk (obese, middle-aged), is a common cause of knee pain that is exacerbated by walking up or down stairs and worsens throughout the day, it causes chronic pain and is not commonly associated with a locking sensation during movements. A large or complex meniscal injury that is left untreated or treated inadequately is a risk factor for the development of future osteoarthritis of the knee.

answers.content: Hyperintense line in the meniscus on MRI
answers.explanation_why:
A hyperintense line in the meniscus on MRI is diagnostic of meniscal tear. MRI is the first-line imaging test to identify and assess the extent of meniscal tears.

Arthroscopy is the definitive diagnostic test for meniscal tear, but it is invasive, so arthroscopy is rarely used to make an initial diagnosis of meniscal tear. Instead, arthroscopy is therapeutic in patients with MRI evidence of meniscal tear who have an indication for surgery (e.g., failed conservative therapy, joint instability, or a complex meniscal tear).

images.title: Horizontal tear of the medial meniscus
images.description: MRI knee (upper image: T1-weighted, coronal plane; lower image: T1-weighted, sagittal plane)There is horizontal linear intermediate signal (white outline), parallel to the tibial plateau, within the posterior horn of the medial meniscus (green overlay).This is consistent with a horizontal meniscal tear.Red overlay: anterior horn of the medial meniscus

answers.explanation_why: Medial joint laxity suggests medial collateral ligament (MCL) injury, which is the most common ligamentous knee injury. High-grade tears of the MCL commonly manifest with a concomitant injury to the anterior cruciate ligament or the medial meniscus. Although MCL injury can cause acute posttraumatic knee pain and manifest with medial joint line tenderness, it typically occurs after valgus stress (sometimes with external rotation) and significant effusion would be uncommon. Additionally, patients with MCL injury typically feel as though their knee is “giving out” rather than locking.

Anterior tibial translation (e.g., anterior drawer sign or Lachman sign) is consistent with anterior cruciate ligament (ACL) injury, which is a common sports injury involving twisting mechanisms and can cause posttraumatic knee pain. However, ACL injuries cause rapid knee effusion from hemarthrosis (due to the significant vascularity of the ligament) and are not associated with a locking sensation or popping/clicking on examination. ACL injuries are usually associated with significant knee instability, and patients often complain of the knee “giving out.” Instead, this patient had a gradual knee effusion, is able to walk, and her knee movement is associated with popping and locking.

images.title: Anterior cruciate ligament injury
images.description: MRI knee (STIR; sagittal view)The anterior cruciate ligament is discontinuous. The distal part of the ligament demonstrates normal hypointense signal (red overlay), but the proximal half ligament demonstrates heterogenous hyperintense signal (yellow overlay). There is a gap between these two areas. There is also a large suprapatellar joint effusion (demonstrated as a white area due to high signal intensity; blue overlay). The partially imaged posterior cruciate ligament (green overlay) appears intact.This is an example of an anterior cruciate ligament rupture. The gap between the proximal and distal half of the ligament indicates it is a full-thickness tear. The heterogeneous hyperintense signal of the proximal half indicates partial thickness tearing of that component.

answers.content: Erosions and synovial hyperplasia on MRI
answers.explanation_why: Erosions and synovial hyperplasia are late findings of rheumatoid arthritis (RA), for which this patient is at risk given that she is a middle-aged female with a positive family history. RA can manifest with joint pain and effusion, but it is associated with chronic joint pain and inflammation (often involving multiple joints; classically the metacarpophalangeal and proximal interphalangeal joints) and does not occur acutely following trauma. Classically, RA symptoms are worst in the morning (i.e., morning stiffness for > 30 min) and improve throughout the day, whereas this patient's symptoms worsened throughout the day. Additionally, even in aggressive cases of RA, it often takes months to years until erosions become evident on imaging.

Posterior tibial translation (positive posterior drawer test) is indicative of posterior cruciate ligament (PCL) injury, which can cause sudden onset of posttraumatic knee pain. However, PCL injury is rare and typically caused by hyperflexion of the knee with a plantarflexed foot and causes rapid knee effusion (due to the significant vascularity of the ligament). In addition, it is associated with neither medial joint line tenderness nor popping/clicking/locking.

question_text: A 32-year-old man is brought to the emergency department 15 minutes after falling 7 feet onto a flat-top wooden post. On arrival, he is in severe pain and breathing rapidly. His pulse is 135/min, respirations are 30/min, and blood pressure is 80/40 mm Hg. There is an impact wound in the left fourth intercostal space at the midaxillary line. Auscultation shows tracheal deviation to the right and absent breath sounds over the left lung. There is dullness to percussion over the left chest. Neck veins are flat. Cardiac examination shows no abnormalities. Chest x-ray is shown. Two large-bore intravenous catheters are placed and intravenous fluid resuscitation is begun. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
content_preview: A 32-year-old man is brought to the emergency department 15 minutes after falling 7 feet onto a flat-top wooden post. On arrival, he is in severe pain and breathing rapidly. His pulse is 135/min, respirations are 30/min, and blood pressure is 80/40 mm Hg. There is an impact wound in the left fourth intercostal space at the midaxillary line. Auscultation shows tracheal deviation to the right and absent breath sounds over the left lung. There is dullness to percussion over the left chest. Neck veins are flat. Cardiac examination shows no abnormalities. Chest x-ray is shown. Two large-bore intravenous catheters are placed and intravenous fluid resuscitation is begun. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
hint: This patient's chest x-ray shows left-sided opacity and blunting of the costophrenic angle.
learning_objective: Recognize a hemothorax.

answers.explanation_why: Cardiac tamponade may manifest with tachycardia, tachypnea, and hypotension. However, neck veins would be distended instead of collapsed, and heart sounds would be muffled on auscultation. Also, tracheal deviation would not be present in an isolated case of cardiac tamponade.

Bronchial rupture would manifest with subcutaneous emphysema and hemoptysis. Clinical features of a pneumothorax such as hyperresonant lung fields would also be present in distal tracheobronchial tree injuries. The absence of any of these findings suggests a different diagnosis.

images.title: Traumatic pneumothorax and pneumomediastinum with subcutaneous emphysema
images.description: X-ray chest (PA view)Extensive subcutaneous emphysema is seen as linear lucencies throughout the soft tissues of the thorax, neck, and upper abdomen (examples indicated by green overlay). A small residual right pneumothorax (arrowheads) is visible and pneumomediastinum is seen along the trachea, main bronchi, and cardiac silhouette (red overlay and arrows). A chest tube (yellow overlay) is in place, with its tip in the apex of the right hemithorax.Pneumomediastinum and pneumothorax can result from blunt or penetrating thoracic injury and various other conditions (e.g., lung disease, intestinal perforation, medical procedure). Air that escapes from the lungs, airways, or bowel can track into the mediastinal and subcutaneous soft tissues.

answers.explanation_why: Tension pneumothorax may manifest with tachycardia, tachypnea, hypotension, decreased breath sounds on the affected side, and deviation of the trachea to the opposite side. However, neck veins would be distended instead of collapsed because the mediastinal shift that occurs with a tension pneumothorax compresses the superior vena cava. Also, lung fields on the affected side would be hyperresonant instead of dull on percussion.

A flail chest could manifest with respiratory distress and tachypnea. A patient with flail chest classically exhibits paradoxical movement of a part of the chest wall on respiration. Although this sign may be absent due to respiratory splinting, a mediastinal shift (tracheal deviation), decreased breath sounds, and a dull note on percussion are not characteristic signs of a flail chest. The absence of bony crepitus also suggests that the patient does not have a rib fracture. A different diagnosis must be considered.

images.title: Pathomechanism of flail chest
images.description: Paradoxical movement of a separate chest wall segment that moves inward during inspiration and outward during expiration. Caused by detachment of a segment of the rib cage from the chest wall due to fracture of three or more adjacent ribs in at least two places.

answers.explanation_why: Hemothorax can develop following blunt chest trauma. This patient exhibits all the signs and symptoms of a massive hemothorax, i.e., tachycardia, hypotension, tachypnea, flat neck veins, decreased breath sounds, and dullness on percussion on the affected side, as well as tracheal deviation to the opposite side. A hemothorax must be drained in most cases because blood in the pleural cavity may clot if not evacuated, resulting in a trapped lung (impaired lung expansion due to the clot) or an empyema (due to clot infection). Treatment usually consists of chest tube insertion into the 4^th–5^th intercostal space at the midaxillary line in order to allow the blood to drain away and improve lung ventilation. Conservative management may be considered to treat small hemothoraces in consultation with a specialist but has a significant failure rate.

images.title: Pleural effusion and passive atelectasis
images.description: X-ray chest (PA view)There is marked opacification (green overlay) of the middle and lower left hemithorax from pleural effusion and passive atelectasis of the adjacent lung. No gastric air bubble is seen projecting over the lower left hemithorax to suggest marked elevation of the left hemidiaphragm from a large amount of atelectasis, but concave upper lateral borders, or menisci (white dashed lines), help confirm the presence of effusion extending to the mid thorax.The margins of the cardiac silhouette and left hemidiaphragm are obscured. Additionally, the cardiac silhouette is shifted slightly to the right (indicated by blue line and arrow) and the left bronchial tree is slightly elevated (indicated by black lines and arrow).In the right hemithorax, a small meniscus from effusion is seen laterally (indicated by red line). Additionally, increased opacification projects through the right hemidiaphragm indicating effusion in the posterior sulcus (red overlay).

question_text: A 43-year-old man is brought to the emergency department 25 minutes after being involved in a high-speed motor vehicle collision in which he was a restrained passenger. On arrival, he has shortness of breath and is in severe pain. His pulse is 130/min, respirations are 35/min, and blood pressure is 90/40 mm Hg. Examination shows superficial abrasions and diffuse crepitus at the left shoulder level. Cardiac examination shows tachycardia with no murmurs, rubs, or gallops. The upper part of the left chest wall moves inward during inspiration. Breath sounds are absent on the left. He is intubated and mechanically ventilated. Two large-bore intravenous catheters are placed and infusion of 0.9% saline is begun. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?
content_preview: A 43-year-old man is brought to the emergency department 25 minutes after being involved in a high-speed motor vehicle collision in which he was a restrained passenger. On arrival, he has shortness of breath and is in severe pain. His pulse is 130/min, respirations are 35/min, and blood pressure is 90/40 mm Hg. Examination shows superficial abrasions and diffuse crepitus at the left shoulder level. Cardiac examination shows tachycardia with no murmurs, rubs, or gallops. The upper part of the left chest wall moves inward during inspiration. Breath sounds are absent on the left. He is intubated and mechanically ventilated. Two large-bore intravenous catheters are placed and infusion of 0.9% saline is begun. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?
hint: Mechanical ventilation with positive end-expiratory pressure helps counter the paradoxical breathing described here.
learning_objective: Recognize flail chest as a cause of paradoxical chest movement.

answers.explanation_why: Diaphragmatic rupture can occur after high-energy trauma and, in case of herniation of abdominal organs into the chest, cause respiratory distress with decreased breath sounds in the affected hemithorax. However, in such a scenario, bowel sounds would be heard during auscultation of the affected hemithorax. In addition, diaphragmatic rupture would not explain the paradoxical motion of a segment of the left chest wall.

Phrenic nerve damage may be caused by trauma, malignancy, or surgery and result in partial or complete paralysis of the diaphragm. Phrenic nerve paralysis may be asymptomatic or manifest with dyspnea. Unilateral phrenic nerve paralysis leads to the paradoxical upward movement of the affected hemidiaphragm. The condition would not explain the paradoxical motion of a segment of the left chest wall.

Cardiac tamponade typically presents with hypotension, tachycardia, jugular venous distention, and pulsus paradoxus. Although this patient is hypotensive and tachycardic, no other signs of cardiac tamponade are present. In addition, cardiac tamponade would not explain the paradoxical motion of the chest wall.

Sternal fracture classically occurs after blunt anterior chest trauma such as that caused by a motor vehicle collision. It is often associated with myocardial contusions. Although this patient may have an associated sternal fracture, this type of injury does not sufficiently explain his respiratory distress and the paradoxical movement of the chest wall.

A flail chest is the detachment of a segment of the rib cage from the chest wall as a result of ≥ 3 adjacent rib fractures in ≥ 2 places. This floating rib cage segment is decoupled from the chest wall and causes paradoxical chest movement. Upon inspiration, as the intrathoracic pressure drops, the unstable segment will be pulled inwards by the negative pressure, and during expiration, the floating segment moves outward. This condition usually results from high-energy blunt trauma to the chest (e.g., motor vehicle collision). Patients with flail chest commonly present with features of respiratory distress (e.g., dyspnea, tachypnea), which can be due to hypoventilation (as a result of pain), pulmonary contusions, pneumothorax, and/or hemothorax.

images.title: Pathomechanism of flail chest
images.description: Paradoxical movement of a separate chest wall segment that moves inward during inspiration and outward during expiration. Caused by detachment of a segment of the rib cage from the chest wall due to fracture of three or more adjacent ribs in at least two places.

question_text: A 36-year-old man is brought to the emergency department 25 minutes after being involved in a high-speed motor vehicle collision in which he was an unrestrained passenger. He has acute myeloid leukemia and is currently receiving chemotherapy. On arrival, his temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 63/min, respirations are 10/min, and blood pressure is 100/70 mm Hg. The pupils are equal and sluggish. There are multiple bruises over the face, trunk, and right upper and lower extremities. There is a 4-cm (1.6-in) laceration over his right cheek. He does not respond to any commands but does groan. Painful stimuli cause him to open his eyes and withdraw all extremities. There are decreased breath sounds over the right lung base. There is tenderness to palpation over the left chest wall. Cardiac examination shows no abnormalities. The abdomen is soft and shows diffuse tenderness to palpation with no guarding or rebound. There is swelling of the right elbow and wrist. The right lower extremity is shorter than the left lower extremity. There are 2 lacerations around 2 cm (0.8 in) each on the right leg. The right knee is swollen. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
content_preview: A 36-year-old man is brought to the emergency department 25 minutes after being involved in a high-speed motor vehicle collision in which he was an unrestrained passenger. He has acute myeloid leukemia and is currently receiving chemotherapy. On arrival, his temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 63/min, respirations are 10/min, and blood pressure is 100/70 mm Hg. The pupils are equal and sluggish. There are multiple bruises over the face, trunk, and right upper and lower extremities. There is a 4-cm (1.6-in) laceration over his right cheek. He does not respond to any commands but does groan. Painful stimuli cause him to open his eyes and withdraw all extremities. There are decreased breath sounds over the right lung base. There is tenderness to palpation over the left chest wall. Cardiac examination shows no abnormalities. The abdomen is soft and shows diffuse tenderness to palpation with no guarding or rebound. There is swelling of the right elbow and wrist. The right lower extremity is shorter than the left lower extremity. There are 2 lacerations around 2 cm (0.8 in) each on the right leg. The right knee is swollen. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
hint: This patient has a Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) of 8 (groans = 2; opens eyes to pain = 2; withdraws extremities to pain = 4).
learning_objective: Recognize the need for airway protection in a patient with a Glasgow Coma Scale score of 8, and choose the most appropriate management.

answers.explanation_why: The patient does have abdominal tenderness and will require some form of assessment for intraabdominal bleeding such as a FAST scan, but only after implementing a very critical measure from the advanced trauma life support-recommended approach to trauma resuscitation (following the ABCDE approach).

A pelvic binder would address critical blood loss and help stabilize potential pelvic fractures, but it would not address the primary concern as dictated by the ABCDE approach to treating trauma patients.

An intercostal chest tube is indicated for treating tension pneumothorax (TP). The patient has decreased breath sounds at the right lung base, a finding associated with TP, but does not show other signs like tachypnea, tracheal deviation away from the affected lung, or jugular venous distention, making TP an unlikely diagnosis. The first priority for this patient with a GCS score of 8 is another very critical measure of the ATLS-recommended approach to trauma resuscitation (following the ABCDE approach).

answers.content: CT scan of the head and neck
answers.explanation_why: The patient will require imaging of the head to assess intracranial bleeding and other damage to the head and neck area. Imaging of the neck is especially important for assessment of cervical spine integrity. However, head and neck imaging can take place only after implementing a very critical measure from the advanced trauma life support-recommended approach to trauma resuscitation (following the ABCDE approach).

This patient will need evaluation of his extremities for bone and soft tissue damage, but only after implementation of a very critical measure from the advanced trauma life support-recommended approach to trauma resuscitation (following the ABCDE approach).

As a general rule, patients with a GCS score of 8 or below as a result of traumatic brain injury require intubation and mechanical ventilation to protect the airway and ensure adequate ventilation. Such patients are at risk of airway obstruction via aspiration because they lack a gag reflex. They are also at risk of hypoxia from poor ventilation because brainstem damage can decrease the respiratory drive.
