question_text: A 24-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of left shoulder pain after falling from a height of approximately 10 feet while rock climbing 5 hours ago. He initially thought the pain would resolve with rest but it became more severe over the last 2 hours. Last year while rock climbing he fell onto his right shoulder and “needed a sling to fix it.” He has psoriasis. His only medication is topical clobetasol. His pulse is 95/min, respirations are 16/min, and blood pressure is 114/70 mm Hg. Examination shows full passive and active range of motion of the left shoulder. There is no tenderness to palpation at the acromioclavicular joint. There are silvery plaques over both knees and elbows. Abdominal examination shows severe tenderness to palpation in the left upper quadrant with voluntary guarding. A complete blood count and serum concentrations of electrolytes are within the reference range. Chest x-ray is normal. Focused assessment with sonography for trauma shows no evidence of free intraperitoneal fluid. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
content_preview: A 24-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of left shoulder pain after falling from a height of approximately 10 feet while rock climbing 5 hours ago. He initially thought the pain would resolve with rest but it became more severe over the last 2 hours. Last year while rock climbing he fell onto his right shoulder and “needed a sling to fix it.” He has psoriasis. His only medication is topical clobetasol. His pulse is 95/min, respirations are 16/min, and blood pressure is 114/70 mm Hg. Examination shows full passive and active range of motion of the left shoulder. There is no tenderness to palpation at the acromioclavicular joint. There are silvery plaques over both knees and elbows. Abdominal examination shows severe tenderness to palpation in the left upper quadrant with voluntary guarding. A complete blood count and serum concentrations of electrolytes are within the reference range. Chest x-ray is normal. Focused assessment with sonography for trauma shows no evidence of free intraperitoneal fluid. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
hint: Left upper quadrant abdominal pain, voluntary guarding, and referred shoulder pain (Kehr sign) in a patient who has fallen from a significant height indicates splenic injury.
learning_objective: Recognize splenic injury, and choose the most appropriate diagnostic test.

answers.content: Serial vital signs for at least nine hours
answers.explanation_why: The severity of abdominal injury determines whether hemodynamically stable patients can be managed nonoperatively with serial monitoring of vital signs. Although unsupported by high-quality evidence, serial monitoring of vital signs for a period of 9 hours without imaging may be a reasonable approach following trauma for hemodynamically stable patients with a low risk of abdominal injury. This patient, however, has fallen from a height of 10 feet and has left upper quadrant pain and guarding, as well as a positive Kehr sign, all of which indicate a splenic injury that requires additional abdominal imaging.

Abdominal CT with contrast is the most appropriate next step, following a negative FAST scan, in the management of a hemodynamically stable patient with a suspected splenic injury. CT scan has greater specificity than ultrasonography for diagnosing splenic lacerations because it can visualize the vasculature and parenchyma of the spleen in high resolution. Findings on the CT scan are used to grade splenic injury and guide further management. CT scan can also rule out other concomitant injuries in cases of abdominal trauma, especially injuries involving retroperitoneal structures.

images.title: Lacerated spleen
images.description:
Click on the overlay icon below the taskbar on the left to toggle the overlay on and off.

CT abdomen (with contrast; axial plane; portal venous phase) of a 24 year-old patient after a high-speed front-impact crashThe spleen has an irregular contour (dashed outline) and heterogeneous enhancement. Intrasplenic low-attenuation rounded and linear areas are sites of laceration and hematoma formation. Multiple small high-density foci along the inferior aspect of the spleen indicate contrast extravasation (arrows) from active bleeding.Hemorrhage (green overlay) into the peritoneal space extends from the spleen inferiorly along the paracolic gutter. Hemorrhagic fluid is also seen along the liver (yellow overlay) and within the right paracolic gutter and pelvis (yellow overlay).Multiple thoracic spine fractures (examples indicated by arrowheads) are accompanied by paravertebral hematoma (red overlay).

answers.explanation_why: Diagnostic peritoneal lavage (DPL) is a procedure that can be used in patients with blunt abdominal trauma to determine the presence of blood within the peritoneum. DPL should only be considered in hemodynamically unstable patients who have an inconclusive FAST scan. However, this patient is hemodynamically stable and a FAST scan was negative for free intraperitoneal fluid. In addition, although highly sensitive, DPL has largely fallen out of favor because it is an invasive procedure; it may, however, be necessary in some cases (e.g., in resource-poor settings).

Shoulder radiographs are the first-line imaging modality in the diagnostic workup of traumatic shoulder injury (i.e., clavicle, proximal humerus, or scapula fractures; acromioclavicular or glenohumeral dislocations). However, the combination of left upper quadrant tenderness and guarding, onset of left shoulder pain a few hours after the initial trauma, and a normal shoulder joint examination indicates that this patient's acute shoulder pain is most likely the result of referred pain due to diaphragmatic irritation (Kehr sign) rather than a traumatic shoulder injury.

An exploratory laparotomy is a surgical procedure that encompasses examination and treatment of the intraabdominal cavity for sources of bleeding in patients with blunt abdominal trauma. It is typically performed in hemodynamically unstable patients following the confirmation of free intraperitoneal fluid. This patient is hemodynamically stable and initial diagnostic imaging shows no evidence of intraabdominal bleeding. Therefore, an exploratory laparotomy is not appropriate at this time.

Left upper quadrant tenderness and guarding, the onset of left shoulder pain a few hours after the initial trauma, as well as a normal shoulder joint examination, indicate that the shoulder pain in this patient most likely results from referred pain due to diaphragmatic irritation (Kehr sign), and is not the result of a traumatic shoulder injury. If shoulder injury were suspected, a shoulder MRI could be useful to image soft tissue of the shoulder such as the rotator cuff and acromioclavicular ligaments. However, MRI is not the first-line of imaging in a patient with a suspected traumatic shoulder injury.

question_text: A 27-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department after falling from her bicycle 1 hour ago. The patient was on her way to work as she lost her balance, hitting her head on the sidewalk. She had an initial loss of consciousness for a couple of minutes following the accident. She currently has nausea and a headache. She has vomited twice during the last 30 minutes. She has no history of a serious illness. The patient does not smoke or drink alcohol. She has never used illicit drugs. She takes no medications. Her temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 50/min, respirations are 10/min, and blood pressure is 160/90 mm Hg. She is oriented to person, place, and time. Her lungs are clear to auscultation. Cardiac examination shows bradycardia but no murmurs, rubs, or gallops. The abdomen is soft and nontender. There is a bruise on the right temporal side of the head. While the remainder of the physical examination is being performed, the patient starts having a seizure. Intravenous lorazepam is administered and she is admitted to the intensive care unit. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?
content_preview: A 27-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department after falling from her bicycle 1 hour ago. The patient was on her way to work as she lost her balance, hitting her head on the sidewalk. She had an initial loss of consciousness for a couple of minutes following the accident. She currently has nausea and a headache. She has vomited twice during the last 30 minutes. She has no history of a serious illness. The patient does not smoke or drink alcohol. She has never used illicit drugs. She takes no medications. Her temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 50/min, respirations are 10/min, and blood pressure is 160/90 mm Hg. She is oriented to person, place, and time. Her lungs are clear to auscultation. Cardiac examination shows bradycardia but no murmurs, rubs, or gallops. The abdomen is soft and nontender. There is a bruise on the right temporal side of the head. While the remainder of the physical examination is being performed, the patient starts having a seizure. Intravenous lorazepam is administered and she is admitted to the intensive care unit. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?
hint: This patient had a brief recovery of consciousness (lucid interval) after experiencing head trauma, but now has signs of elevated intracranial pressure (ICP), including nausea, headache, vomiting, seizure, and Cushing triad (hypertension, bradycardia, and bradypnea). All of these features suggest intracranial hemorrhage most likely due to rupture of the middle meningeal artery.
learning_objective: Recognize an epidural hematoma.

answers.explanation_why: Symptoms of ischemic stroke depend on the affected area of the brain. Patients typically present with focal neurological deficits like hemiparesis and have risk factors such as diabetes or hypercholesterolemia. Additionally, seizures, elevated ICP, and a traumatic origin are all unusual findings for ischemic stroke.

Onset of symptoms in patients with subdural hematoma (SDH) depends on the size, location, and rate of growth of the SDH. In acute onset, the patient may also present with headache and signs of increased ICP immediately following head trauma. In rare cases, patients may also experience a lucid interval. However, the temporary recovery of consciousness is more commonly associated with a different diagnosis.

Intracerebral hemorrhage typically results from a spontaneous (i.e., nontraumatic) rupture of vessels secondary to structural changes of the vessel walls, e.g., in chronic hypertension or cerebral amyloid angiopathy. Patients present with headache and focal neurologic deficits, such as hemiparesis. Rarely, it is caused by a head trauma with direct damage of the vessel. Signs of increased ICP and a lucid interval are more suggestive of another diagnosis.

Subarachnoidal hemorrhages may occur spontaneously or after head trauma. Patients typically present with sudden, excruciating headaches (thunderclap headache), meningism, and loss of consciousness. While this patient also experienced headache and a loss of consciousness, signs of elevated ICP and the momentary recovery of consciousness point to another diagnosis.

Idiopathic intracranial hypertension (IIH) usually presents with chronic headaches and visual symptoms (e.g., transient loss of vision) that gradually worsens over months to years. It is not associated with head trauma. While this patient is in the peak age group of IIH (15–45 years of age), she developed her symptoms rapidly following a traumatic event and does not have any visual symptoms.

An epidural hematoma should be suspected in any patient with severe head trauma and initial loss of consciousness that is followed by a lucid interval and then soon after by a new decline in mental status with signs of elevated ICP. The lucid interval represents the time it takes for blood to accumulate in the epidural space before compressing the brain and resulting in clinical deterioration. The length of the lucid interval depends on the severity of the trauma and the intensity of the bleeding and is typically shorter in patients with bleeding from the meningeal arteries compared to patients who bleed from a torn bridging vein (as seen with subdural hematomas).

images.title: Pathophysiology of an epidural hematoma
images.description: Most epidural hematomas (EDH) are caused by a rupture/tear of the middle meningeal artery secondary to a traumatic head injury, typically associated with a skull fracture. The resulting hemorrhage separates the dura mater from the inner aspect of the calvarium and accumulates within the epidural space. As the dura mater is tightly adherent at the skull suture lines, an EDH does not extend beyond the sutures. An EDH would be seen on neuroimaging as a biconvex hyperdense lesion that does not cross the suture lines.

question_text: Shortly after undergoing a bipolar prosthesis for a displaced femoral neck fracture of the left hip acquired after a fall the day before, an 80-year-old woman suddenly develops dyspnea. The surgery under general anesthesia with sevoflurane was uneventful, lasting 98 minutes, during which the patient maintained oxygen saturation readings of 96–100% on 8 L of oxygen. She has a history of hypertension, osteoporosis, and osteoarthritis of her right knee. Her medications include ramipril, naproxen, ranitidine, and a multivitamin. She appears cyanotic, drowsy, and is oriented only to person. Her temperature is 38.6°C (101.5°F), pulse is 135/minute, respirations are 36/min, and blood pressure is 155/95 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 81%. There are several scattered petechiae on the anterior chest wall. Laboratory studies show a hemoglobin concentration of 10.5 g/dL, a leukocyte count of 9000/mm^3, a platelet count of 145,000/mm^3, and a creatine kinase of 190 U/L. An ECG shows sinus tachycardia. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
content_preview: Shortly after undergoing a bipolar prosthesis for a displaced femoral neck fracture of the left hip acquired after a fall the day before, an 80-year-old woman suddenly develops dyspnea. The surgery under general anesthesia with sevoflurane was uneventful, lasting 98 minutes, during which the patient maintained oxygen saturation readings of 96–100% on 8 L of oxygen. She has a history of hypertension, osteoporosis, and osteoarthritis of her right knee. Her medications include ramipril, naproxen, ranitidine, and a multivitamin. She appears cyanotic, drowsy, and is oriented only to person. Her temperature is 38.6°C (101.5°F), pulse is 135/minute, respirations are 36/min, and blood pressure is 155/95 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 81%. There are several scattered petechiae on the anterior chest wall. Laboratory studies show a hemoglobin concentration of 10.5 g/dL, a leukocyte count of 9000/mm3, a platelet count of 145,000/mm3, and a creatine kinase of 190 U/L. An ECG shows sinus tachycardia. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
hint: This patient presents with features of hypoxia (dyspnea, cyanosis, tachypnea, decreased oxygen saturation), neurologic symptoms, and a petechial rash one day after a femoral fracture.
learning_objective: Recognize fat embolism syndrome.

answers.explanation_why: Myocardial infarction (MI) typically manifests with acute chest pain. While an atypical presentation with dyspnea is possible, especially in older patients, women, or patients with diabetes mellitus, the development of neurological abnormalities and a petechial rash in the setting of a borderline low platelet count suggests a different diagnosis. Additionally, in a patient with acute MI, the ECG is expected to show signs of ischemia (e.g., ST-elevations, ST-depression, T-wave inversion) rather than just sinus tachycardia.

Traumatic rhabdomyolysis typically results from severe crushing traumas, e.g., after being trapped under a collapsed building or a car accident. Rhabdomyolysis usually causes myalgia, generalized weakness, and darkened urine from excess myoglobin. While this patient has a slight increase in the creatine kinase (CK) level, it is likely induced by fracture-associated muscle trauma. Rhabdomyolysis may be suspected if the CK is ≥ 5 times the normal range, but levels often exceed 100,000 U/L. While this patient experienced trauma, she lacks the aforementioned symptoms, making rhabdomyolysis less likely. Acute dyspnea and altered mental status following a bone fracture suggest a different diagnosis.

This patient presents with the classic triad of fat embolism (hypoxia, neurological abnormalities, and upper body petechial rash), which is thought to be caused by the entry of bone marrow fat cells into the circulatory system. Therefore, fat embolism most commonly occurs after fractures of marrow-containing bones, such as closed long bone and pelvic fractures. Symptoms usually develop within 12–72 hours of the inciting event. Neurological symptoms result either from paradoxical embolism or from fatty microemboli that are small enough to pass through the pulmonary circulation and enter the arterial circulation in the CNS. The petechial rash is caused by fatty occlusion of dermal capillaries with subsequent extravasation of erythrocytes. Fat embolism is mainly a clinical diagnosis, and treatment consists of supportive care (e.g., supplemental oxygen, mechanical ventilation, vasopressors) in an intensive care unit.

In addition to anemia, thrombocytopenia, and fever, patients may present with other nonspecific features such as lipiduria, hypotension, and right ventricle dysfunction.

images.title: Pulmonary fat embolism
images.description: X-ray chest (PA view) of a patient after physical traumaParenchymal opacities (green overlay) are seen in both lungs, predominantly in the lower zones. No pleural effusions are visible (indicated by red overlay). The cardiac silhouette is not enlarged. A right central line is present (yellow outline). The radiopaque line on a nasogastric tube (blue overlay) can be traced into the mid-thorax, beyond which it is not well seen.Nonspecific homogeneous or heterogeneous opacities may become visible on chest radiographs in various locations about 24–48 hours after an insult that results in pulmonary fat embolism. A normal cardiac silhouette size and absence of Kerley lines, pleural effusions, and pulmonary venous hypertension can help exclude a diagnosis of cardiogenic edema.

answers.explanation_why: Thyrotoxic crisis may be precipitated by a stress-related surge in catecholamines, e.g., during anesthesia induction or surgery. Patients often have a history of hyperthyroidism and typically present with tachycardia, high fever, nausea, and altered mental status. While thyrotoxic crisis cannot be entirely excluded, sudden onset respiratory dysfunction in this patient with a bone fracture and no history of thyroid disease makes another diagnosis more likely.

Malignant hyperthermia may also manifest with tachycardia, tachypnea, and increased body temperature and may occur either intraoperatively or, less commonly, during the early postoperative period. However, the cardinal symptoms of malignant hyperthermia are muscle rigidity and a rapid increase in body temperature. While this patient is febrile, the rise in body temperature in patients with malignant hyperthermia is usually much more dramatic, sometimes at a rate of 1–2°C every 5 minutes, often exceeding 42°C. Although this patient has a slight increase in the creatine kinase (CK) level, it is likely induced by the fracture-associated muscle trauma, rather than rhabdomyolysis secondary to malignant hyperthermia. In malignant hyperthermia, CK levels usually exceed 10,000 U/L. The presence of severe respiratory failure, neurologic abnormalities, and a petechial rash of the chest make another diagnosis more likely.

Meningitis is typically associated with fever, headache, and neck stiffness. In particular, meningococcal meningitis also often manifests with a petechial rash, and in rare cases leads to the devastating Waterhouse-Friderichsen syndrome. Although this patient presents with fever and petechiae, she does not have a headache or neck stiffness. In addition, she presents with sudden dyspnea directly after a surgical procedure of a long bone, making another diagnosis more likely.

question_text: An 87-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department 30 minutes after a fall onto a hardwood floor. She landed on her left side and hit the left side of her head. She did not lose consciousness. She has a mild headache over the left temple and severe left hip pain. She has had nasal congestion, a sore throat, and a productive cough for the last 2 days. She has a history of atrial fibrillation, coronary artery disease, hypertension, and osteoporosis. She underwent two coronary artery bypass grafts 5 years ago. Her current medications include aspirin, apixaban, diltiazem, omeprazole, and vitamin D supplementation. The patient is oriented to person, place, and time. There is a 2-cm ecchymosis over the left temple. Examination of the left hip shows swelling and tenderness; range of motion is limited. Intravenous morphine 2 mg is started. During further examination, the patient complains of dizziness and palpitations. She is diaphoretic and pale. Her skin is cold and clammy. Her pulse is 110/min and faint, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 70/30 mm Hg. Cranial nerves are intact. Cardiac examination shows no murmurs, rubs, or gallops. An ECG shows absent P waves and nonspecific changes of the ST segment and the T wave. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's sudden decline in her condition?

She did not lose consciousness. She has a mild headache over the left temple and severe left hip pain. She has had nasal congestion, a sore throat, and a productive cough for the last 2 days. She has a history of atrial fibrillation, coronary artery disease, hypertension, and osteoporosis. She underwent two coronary artery bypass grafts 5 years ago. Her current medications include aspirin, apixaban, diltiazem, omeprazole, and vitamin D supplementation. The patient is oriented to person, place, and time. There is a 2-cm ecchymosis over the left temple. Examination of the left hip shows swelling and tenderness; range of motion is limited. Intravenous morphine 2 mg is started. During further examination, the patient complains of dizziness and palpitations. She is diaphoretic and pale. Her skin is cold and clammy. Her pulse is 110/min and faint, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 70/30 mm Hg. Cranial nerves are intact. Cardiac examination shows no murmurs, rubs, or gallops. An ECG shows absent P waves and nonspecific changes of the ST segment and the T wave. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's sudden decline in her condition?
hint: This patient's tachypnea, tachycardia, and severe hypotension after a recent fall as well as her physical examination findings (hip swelling, head ecchymosis, cold and clammy skin) and current drug regimen (dual antithrombotic therapy) are suggestive of a certain type of shock.
learning_objective: Recognize hypovolemic shock due to blood loss.

answers.explanation_why: Pulmonary embolism (PE), for example, due to fat embolism in long hip fracture (which this patient most likely has), may lead to obstructive shock, resulting in insufficient cardiac output and increased systemic vascular resistance (clinically manifesting with cold and clammy skin). However, severe PE leading to obstructive shock would also manifest with dyspnea and signs of right ventricular pressure overload (e.g., distended neck veins). In addition, while tachycardia and nonspecific ST-wave changes may be the only ECG changes seen in PE, signs of right heart strain (e.g., right axis deviation, right bundle branch block, S1Q3T3-pattern) are the more characteristic findings, especially in large PEs that could cause obstructive shock.

Cardiac tamponade can lead to obstructive shock characterized by insufficient cardiac output and increased systemic vascular resistance (clinically detected by the presence of cold and clammy skin). However, heart sounds in cardiac tamponade are typically muffled and an ECG characteristically shows low voltage QRS complexes and electric alternans. In addition, signs of heart failure (e.g., distended neck veins, peripheral edema) would be expected.

This patient received morphine, which can cause anaphylactic shock and/or opioid-related hypotension. However, both of these reactions lead to decreased systemic vascular resistance, which manifests with warm skin. In addition, patients with anaphylaxis usually present with additional symptoms such as urticaria, angioedema, wheezing, nausea, and vomiting.

Brain herniation may arise secondary to a mass effect of traumatic brain injury or intracranial bleeding and lead to neurogenic shock. However, this patient's cold, clammy skin and tachycardia are inconsistent with neurogenic shock. Instead, flushed, warm skin and bradycardia would be expected. Also, the conditions that lead to brain herniation would likely manifest with additional neurologic signs, such as headaches, changes in mental status, and/or focal findings.

Sepsis can lead to septic shock. This patient presents with an ongoing infection (nasal congestion, sore throat, and productive cough) and no fever, most likely due to a common cold rather than a severe infection with sepsis. Also, the early stages of septic shock are characterized by warm, flushed skin due to vasodilation.

Myocardial infarction (MI) may lead to cardiogenic shock, manifesting with decreased cardiac output and increased systemic vascular resistance that results in cold and clammy skin. However, severe myocardial infarction leading to low cardiac output would also cause heart failure. This backward failure manifests with dyspnea (due to pulmonary edema caused by left heart failure) and/or peripheral edema and jugular venous distension (due to right heart failure). Additionally, MI typically manifests with chest pain and specific ECG changes, such as peaked T waves, ST elevations, and ST depressions.

Hemodynamically relevant blood loss can lead to hypovolemic shock, resulting in low cardiac output and increased systemic vascular resistance that manifests with cold and clammy skin. This patient most likely suffered blood loss due to a hip fracture, which is indicated by swelling, pain, and limited range of motion of her left hip. Dual antithrombotic therapy also puts her at increased risk for bleeding.

Management of hemorrhagic shock includes aggressive fluid resuscitation, transfusion of blood products (packed red blood cells plus, if massive transfusion is expected, fresh frozen plasma and platelet concentrate), and hemostatic control (e.g., surgery).

question_text: A 32-year-old man is brought to a small community health center after being stabbed in the abdomen during an altercation. The physician is working alone. The patient has shortness of breath, abdominal pain, and bleeding. He is alert and active. He appears uncomfortable. His temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 120/min, respirations are 20/min and shallow, and blood pressure is 89/61 mm Hg. Examination shows a deep 4-cm wound at the right subcostal region with active bleeding. The knife is still in the wound. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial action by the physician?
content_preview: A 32-year-old man is brought to a small community health center after being stabbed in the abdomen during an altercation. The physician is working alone. The patient has shortness of breath, abdominal pain, and bleeding. He is alert and active. He appears uncomfortable. His temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 120/min, respirations are 20/min and shallow, and blood pressure is 89/61 mm Hg. Examination shows a deep 4-cm wound at the right subcostal region with active bleeding. The knife is still in the wound. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial action by the physician?
hint: This hemodynamically unstable patient presents to a small community health center after a penetrating abdominal trauma that requires immediate surgery.
learning_objective: Recognize penetrating abdominal trauma with hemodynamic instability, and choose the most appropriate initial action.

answers.explanation_why: Bilateral tube thoracostomy is indicated in a patient with pneumothorax, pleural effusion, or intrathoracic hemorrhage. These conditions are associated with absent or decreased breath sounds, whereas this patient's lungs are clear to auscultation. Additionally, the stab wound is below the costal margin and therefore less likely to injure the lungs.

answers.content: Remove the knife carefully and apply pressure to the wound
answers.explanation_why: The knife might be acting as a tamponade on the wound, thereby concealing vascular damage and preventing further hemorrhage. Although emergency surgery is indicated, impaled foreign bodies should be removed under direct visualization in an operating room where bleeding can be controlled.

answers.content: Type and cross for transfusion of packed red blood cells
answers.explanation_why: Although this patient shows signs of active bleeding and will likely need blood transfusions, a type and cross is a blood test that takes time and would not address his primary problem of intraabdominal bleeding from a stab wound.

Rapid sequence intubation (RSI) is the preferred method of endotracheal intubation in emergency settings because it obviates the need for bag valve mask ventilation and decreases the risk of vomiting and aspiration in patients who have not fasted. Although RSI may be indicated in this patient prior to undergoing surgery, immediate RSI is not indicated as he is conscious, has a patent airway, and is not at impending risk of respiratory failure or aspiration.

answers.content: Arrange for transport to the nearest trauma center
answers.explanation_why: In this patient with penetrating abdominal trauma, hypotension and tachycardia suggest intraabdominal hemorrhage, which needs to be controlled immediately. Although other lifesaving measures (i.e., fluid resuscitation) should also be conducted as soon as possible and might be done in parallel if more personnel were present, this physician is working alone. To prevent the patient from potentially bleeding to death, immediate transfer to an operating room is indicated. Establishing IV access and setting up fluids may be conducted after arranging transport or on the way to a trauma center. Once the patient is transferred, an exploratory laparotomy should be performed.

question_text: A 24-year-old man is brought to the emergency department because of severe left shoulder pain following a fall onto his left shoulder while skiing. He took 400 mg of ibuprofen on his way to the emergency department. He appears in acute distress. His temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 85/min, respirations are 14/min, and blood pressure is 115/78 mm Hg. Examination of the left shoulder shows a visibly elevated left clavicle with tenderness and crepitus on palpation. Left shoulder active and passive range of motion are limited by pain. The radial pulses are palpable, and there is no loss of sensation to light touch in the left arm, hand, or shoulder. An x-ray of the left shoulder is shown. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in the management of this patient?
content_preview: A 24-year-old man is brought to the emergency department because of severe left shoulder pain following a fall onto his left shoulder while skiing. He took 400 mg of ibuprofen on his way to the emergency department. He appears in acute distress. His temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 85/min, respirations are 14/min, and blood pressure is 115/78 mm Hg. Examination of the left shoulder shows a visibly elevated left clavicle with tenderness and crepitus on palpation. Left shoulder active and passive range of motion are limited by pain. The radial pulses are palpable, and there is no loss of sensation to light touch in the left arm, hand, or shoulder. An x-ray of the left shoulder is shown. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in the management of this patient?
hint: As with all fractures, the severity of displacement is one of the most important factors when choosing between conservative or operative management.
learning_objective: Recognize a completely displaced clavicle fracture, and choose the most appropriate management step.

answers.content: Bed rest, ice, and ibuprofen intake
answers.explanation_why: Rest, ice, and ibuprofen are a good first measure for a number of musculoskeletal injuries (e.g., sprained ankle). This patient's x-ray, however, reveals a displaced fracture of the clavicle. Even though rest, ice, and pain management would be part of his treatment, the fracture also requires some form of stabilization, at least with an arm sling.

answers.content: CT scan of the chest and left shoulder
answers.explanation_why: A CT scan is appropriate for medial physeal clavicular, sternal injuries, or if x-ray is inconclusive. However, the x-ray findings clearly show a fracture of the lateral clavicle and the patient is 24 years old, meaning that his growth plates have already fused.

answers.content: Physical therapy with restricted range of motion
answers.explanation_why: While physical therapy will be part of the long term management of this patient's clavicle fracture (to avoid adhesions and atrophy), it should not be initiated until the fracture has been stabilized and allowed to heal.

Conservative management through immobilization with a shoulder sling is appropriate for nondisplaced clavicle fractures or a fracture with displacement of less than one bone width. The shoulder sling stabilizes the bone fragments by restricting motion of the shoulder. But the x-ray of this patient's fracture reveals a completely displaced lateral clavicle fracture, which means that conservative management would be an inadequate next step and likely result in nonunion.

images.title: Acute nondisplaced fracture of the right clavicle
images.description: X-ray right clavicle (AP view) of a child after a recent fall on an outstretched armA subtle nondisplaced fracture (green overlay) is seen at the mid to medial third of the right clavicle. There is no callus formation.Arrowheads: overlying artefact; red overlay: growth plate

answers.explanation_why: This patient has a completely displaced lateral clavicle fracture on x-ray, likely with a torn conoid ligament. A completely displaced clavicle fracture involves displacement greater than one bone width and requires surgical management. Surgical intervention for completely displaced clavicle fracture results in lower rates of nonunion when compared with conservative management through immobilization alone. Other indications for surgical intervention include open fractures, neurovascular compromise, and tenting of the skin.

images.title: Allman classification of clavicle fractures
images.description: The Allman classification divides the clavicle into three equal segments, according to which fractures are classified.

images.title: Lateral clavicle fracture
images.description: Plain x-ray (AP view) of the shoulderA distal/lateral clavicle fracture and elevation of the acromioclavicular joint can be seen. The coracoclavicular ligaments consist of the conoid ligament (A), the trapezoid ligament (B), and the coracoacromial ligament (C). The conoid ligament (A) is torn, causing the sternocleidomastoid muscle to pull the medial fragment upward, which explains the elevation of the acromioclavicular joint.

question_text: A 22-year-old man comes to the emergency department for pain and swelling of his left knee one day after injuring it while playing soccer. While sprinting on the field, he slipped as he attempted to kick the ball and landed on the anterior aspect of his knee. He underwent an appendectomy at the age of 16 years. His vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows a swollen and tender left knee; range of motion is limited by pain. The tibial tuberosity shows tenderness to palpation. The left tibia is displaced posteriorly when force is applied to the proximal tibia after flexing the knee. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. An x-ray of the left knee joint shows an avulsion fracture of the tibial condyle. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
content_preview: A 22-year-old man comes to the emergency department for pain and swelling of his left knee one day after injuring it while playing soccer. While sprinting on the field, he slipped as he attempted to kick the ball and landed on the anterior aspect of his knee. He underwent an appendectomy at the age of 16 years. His vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows a swollen and tender left knee; range of motion is limited by pain. The tibial tuberosity shows tenderness to palpation. The left tibia is displaced posteriorly when force is applied to the proximal tibia after flexing the knee. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. An x-ray of the left knee joint shows an avulsion fracture of the tibial condyle. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
hint: Further examination would likely show the tibia of the injured leg sagging posteriorly compared to the right side when both knees are flexed (posterior sag sign).
learning_objective: Recognize posterior cruciate ligament injury.

answers.explanation_why: Anterior cruciate ligament (ACL) injury manifests with knee pain, but it would not explain this patient's posterior drawer sign. Instead, ACL injury would manifest with a positive anterior drawer sign and a positive Lachman sign.

Lateral meniscus injury would manifest with knee pain, but it would not explain this patient's positive posterior drawer test and his avulsion fracture. Meniscus injury may be differentiated from ligamentous injuries by considering the mechanism of injury (axial loading in meniscal injury vs. valgus or varus stresses in ligamentous injury), effusion course (slow, gradual, and delayed in meniscal injury vs. rapid in ligamentous injury), and presence of popping/clicking/locking (present in meniscal injury vs. absent in ligamentous injury).

Posterior cruciate ligament (PCL) injuries are either noncontact injuries involving hyperflexion of the knee on a plantarflexed foot (most commonly seen in athletes) or injuries caused by a posterior blow to the flexed knee (e.g., dashboard injury, athletic contact injury). A positive posterior drawer sign is highly suggestive of PCL injury, and the diagnosis can be confirmed by MRI. Avulsion fractures are common in PCL injury. Isolated PCL injury can be treated conservatively; multiligament injuries and/or chronic symptoms typically warrant surgery.

Patients with PCL injury sometimes appear to have a positive anterior drawer sign because the affected knee seems to have significantly more anterior movement compared to the unaffected knee (due to starting from a posteriorly displaced position).

images.title: Posterior cruciate ligament tear
images.description: MRI knee (T2-weighted; sagittal plane)The posterior cruciate ligament (PCL) appears thickened and heterogeneous with an irregular and ill-defined contour (green overlay). It contains multiple areas of intermediate signal intensity, indicating tearing. A joint effusion is demonstrated by the hyperintense signal in the suprapatellar pouch (red overlay).A ligament tear does not always appear as a discrete defect and may be demonstrated by the features in this example. A normal PCL should appear as hypointense on all conventional MRI sequences and have smooth margins.

answers.explanation_why: Lateral collateral ligament (LCL) injury can cause knee pain. However, it would not explain the patient's positive posterior drawer test or tibial avulsion fracture. Isolated LCL injury is rare and manifests with lateral joint line tenderness with varus stress laxity.

Medial meniscus injury is a common cause of knee pain. However, a torn medial meniscus would not explain this patient's positive posterior drawer test or avulsion fracture. Meniscus injury may be differentiated from ligamentous injuries by considering the mechanism of injury (axial loading in meniscal injury vs. valgus or varus stresses in ligamentous injury), effusion course (slow, gradual, and delayed in meniscal injury vs. rapid in ligamentous injury), and presence of popping/clicking/locking (present in meniscal injury vs. absent in ligamentous injury).

Medial collateral ligament (MCL) injury can manifest with knee pain. However, it would not explain this patient's posterior drawer sign. MCL injury is most commonly caused by valgus stress and manifests with medial joint line tenderness and valgus stress laxity.

question_text: A 7-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department by his mother 1 hour after falling off his bike and landing head-first on the pavement. His mother says that he did not lose consciousness but has been agitated and complaining about a headache since the event. He has no history of serious illness and takes no medications. His temperature is 37.1°C (98.7°F), pulse is 115/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 100/65 mm Hg. There is a large bruise on the anterior scalp and several superficial abrasions on both hands and knees. Examination, including neurologic examination, shows no other abnormalities. A noncontrast CT scan of the head shows a nondepressed linear skull fracture with a 2-mm separation. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
content_preview: A 7-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department by his mother 1 hour after falling off his bike and landing head-first on the pavement. His mother says that he did not lose consciousness but has been agitated and complaining about a headache since the event. He has no history of serious illness and takes no medications. His temperature is 37.1°C (98.7°F), pulse is 115/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 100/65 mm Hg. There is a large bruise on the anterior scalp and several superficial abrasions on both hands and knees. Examination, including neurologic examination, shows no other abnormalities. A noncontrast CT scan of the head shows a nondepressed linear skull fracture with a 2-mm separation. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
hint: This patient presents with agitation and headache, both of which can be signs of elevated intracranial pressure (ICP).
learning_objective: Choose the most appropriate management for a child with a skull fracture and signs of potentially elevated intracranial pressure.

answers.explanation_why: Although asymptomatic patients with relatively small (< 3 mm) linear, nondepressed skull fractures may be sent home without further management, those with signs of potentially elevated ICP require further inpatient observation. Other indications for inpatient observation include evidence of traumatic brain injury on imaging (e.g., intracranial hemorrhage), signs of physical abuse, or caregivers who are unreliable or unable to return if neurological deficits develop within 24 hours after release.

Asymptomatic patients with relatively small, linear skull fractures (< 3 mm) without depression may be sent home if a caregiver is able to properly monitor the patient for signs of altered consciousness or other new neurological symptoms for 24 hours. This patient exhibits signs of potential elevated ICP (e.g., headache, agitated state), which requires another action at this time.

Contacting child protective services is not necessary because this patient does not have identifiable signs of physical abuse (e.g., subdural hemorrhages, buckle fractures, fractures showing different states of healing on x-ray) and thus his injury was most likely accidental.

A brain MRI is a costly imaging modality that would not provide additional useful information for the management of this patient based on his current presentation. It may be indicated for patients in which the clinical picture is inconsistent with the CT scan findings (e.g., a patient with a worsening condition despite a normal CT scan), or if diffuse axonal injury may be suspected (acceleration/deceleration injuries or rotational injuries). The primary clinical manifestation of diffuse axonal injury is loss of consciousness; an MRI may be indicated in this child if he develops any deficits in consciousness.
CT angiography would be indicated for the evaluation of patients with cerebral aneurysms or arteriovenous malformations but does not play a role in the management of patients with acute head trauma.

question_text: A 19-year-old man is rushed to the emergency department 30 minutes after diving head-first into a shallow pool of water from a cliff. He was placed on a spinal board and a rigid cervical collar was applied by the emergency medical technicians. On arrival, he is unconscious and withdraws all extremities to pain. His temperature is 36.7°C (98.1°F), pulse is 70/min, respirations are 8/min, and blood pressure is 102/70 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 96%. The pupils are equal and react sluggishly to light. There is a 3-cm (1.2-in) laceration over the forehead. The lungs are clear to auscultation. Cardiac examination shows no abnormalities. The abdomen is soft and nontender. There is a step-off palpated over the cervical spine. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
content_preview: A 19-year-old man is rushed to the emergency department 30 minutes after diving head-first into a shallow pool of water from a cliff. He was placed on a spinal board and a rigid cervical collar was applied by the emergency medical technicians. On arrival, he is unconscious and withdraws all extremities to pain. His temperature is 36.7°C (98.1°F), pulse is 70/min, respirations are 8/min, and blood pressure is 102/70 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 96%. The pupils are equal and react sluggishly to light. There is a 3-cm (1.2-in) laceration over the forehead. The lungs are clear to auscultation. Cardiac examination shows no abnormalities. The abdomen is soft and nontender. There is a step-off palpated over the cervical spine. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
hint: This patient has likely sustained a cervical spine injury that is compromising his respiratory function.
learning_objective: Choose the most appropriate management for a patient with suspected cervical spine injury and respiratory insufficiency.

answers.explanation_why: A CT scan of the spine is an appropriate diagnostic test for the management of suspected cervical injuries, but it should only be done after the patient has been stabilized. Although the patient's mechanism of injury and physical examination are both consistent with a cervical fracture, the patient's respiratory status is compromised (he is unconscious and his respiratory rate is 8/min). Delaying airway management in favor of imaging could be devastating if the patient were to decompensate inside the CT scanner.

An x-ray of the cervical spine can be considered in the workup of a trauma patient with a suspected cervical spine injury. However, imaging should only be performed after the airway has been secured if there is evidence of respiratory compromise (such as this patient's altered mental status and respiratory rate of 8/min). Moreover, a CT scan would usually be preferable in adult trauma patients with suspected cervical spine injury given its higher sensitivity.

answers.content: CT of the brain and spine
answers.explanation_why: This patient has a mechanism of injury and physical examination findings that are consistent with a cervical spine fracture. Given the forehead laceration and the patient's altered mental status, he is also at high risk of intracranial hemorrhage, and a CT scan of both the brain and spine would be helpful in forming a diagnosis. However, the patient's airway is compromised and he shows signs of respiratory insufficiency (respiratory rate of 8/min). Delaying airway management in favor of imaging could be devastating if the patient were to decompensate inside the CT scanner.

This patient's mechanism of injury and physical examination are both consistent with a cervical fracture that is complicated by altered mental status with respiratory insufficiency (respiratory rate of 8/min). Rapid sequence intubation is vital to secure the patient's airway and allow for proper management of his cervical injury. Cervical fractures may lead to immediate or delayed cervical spinal cord compression and/or phrenic nerve paralysis and subsequent respiratory failure. Although an oxygen saturation of 96% may seem reassuring, hypercapnic respiratory failure may manifest with normal pulse oximetry. Delaying intubation in favor of imaging could lead to respiratory arrest, seizure, and death.

See “Primary trauma survey”.

Laryngeal mask airway devices are not the recommended method of airway management in an unconscious patient with impaired respiratory status, especially in a trauma setting, where a laryngeal mask might exacerbate occult esophageal injury. They may be used in the case of failed intubation due to a difficult airway, but intubation has not yet been attempted.

Rectal tone assessment is performed during the Disability or Exposure portions of the primary trauma survey. As such, it should not be performed until after the Airway, Breathing, and Circulation portions of the primary survey have been completed, especially in a patient who is unconscious and has a respiratory rate of 8/min.

An MRI of the spine may be used for the diagnosis of traumatic spinal cord injury as well as presurgical planning. However, this patient's respiratory status is compromised (he is unconscious and his respiratory rate is 8/min). Delaying airway management in favor of imaging could be devastating if the patient were to decompensate inside the MRI scanner. Moreover, a CT scan would be preferable in most trauma patients, given its much shorter duration.

question_text: A 46-year-old man is brought to the emergency department 15 minutes after being involved in a motor vehicle collision where he was the unrestrained driver. On arrival, he is unconscious. His pulse is 141/min and irregularly irregular, respirations are 24/min, and palpable systolic blood pressure is 60 mm Hg. Examination shows multiple ecchymoses over the chest. There is a 3-cm (1.2-in) laceration over the abdomen and a 4-cm (1.6-in) laceration over the scalp. Jugular venous pressure is increased. Bilateral crackles are heard at the lung bases. Cardiac examination shows no murmurs, rubs, or gallops. The abdomen is soft. Two large-bore intravenous catheters are inserted and 0.9% saline infusion is begun. Focused assessment with sonography in trauma (FAST) results are negative. An ECG shows absent P waves. After 5 minutes, his pulse is 160/min and palpable systolic blood pressure is 50 mm Hg. Vasopressors are administered. One hour later, the patient dies. Which of the following was the most likely diagnosis?
content_preview: A 46-year-old man is brought to the emergency department 15 minutes after being involved in a motor vehicle collision where he was the unrestrained driver. On arrival, he is unconscious. His pulse is 141/min and irregularly irregular, respirations are 24/min, and palpable systolic blood pressure is 60 mm Hg. Examination shows multiple ecchymoses over the chest. There is a 3-cm (1.2-in) laceration over the abdomen and a 4-cm (1.6-in) laceration over the scalp. Jugular venous pressure is increased. Bilateral crackles are heard at the lung bases. Cardiac examination shows no murmurs, rubs, or gallops. The abdomen is soft. Two large-bore intravenous catheters are inserted and 0.9% saline infusion is begun. Focused assessment with sonography in trauma (FAST) results are negative. An ECG shows absent P waves. After 5 minutes, his pulse is 160/min and palpable systolic blood pressure is 50 mm Hg. Vasopressors are administered. One hour later, the patient dies. Which of the following was the most likely diagnosis?
hint: While hypotension following acute trauma should raise concern for blood loss, this patient's negative FAST exam makes intraabdominal or intrathoracic bleeding less likely. Instead, his profound hypotension despite an apparently normal volume status, the bibasilar lung crackles, and elevated jugular venous pressure potentially indicate cardiogenic shock.
learning_objective: Recognize cardiac contusion.

answers.explanation_why: Tracheobronchial injuries can occur as a result of severe blunt chest trauma and also present with hypotension, dyspnea, or tachypnea. However, they are usually associated with bloody oral secretions, subcutaneous emphysema, and/or pneumothorax with a positive Hamman's sign.

In the context of a serious motor vehicle collision, this patient's hypotension and tachycardia refractive to fluid resuscitation, including vasopressors, combined with atrial fibrillation on ECG and a negative FAST, are highly suspicious for cardiac contusion. Cardiac contusions may manifest with clinical features ranging from asymptomatic arrhythmias to rapidly fatal cardiac rupture. Blunt chest trauma and/or sudden deceleration can lead to decreased contractility and arrhythmias due to injury to cardiac myocytes and pacemaker cells. Decreased contractility directly contributes to cardiogenic shock with decreased cardiac output and hypotension, as in this patient.

Splenic rupture most often occurs in the setting of blunt abdominal trauma and can result in hemodynamic instability secondary to massive intraabdominal blood loss. However, an intraabdominal hemorrhage large enough to lead to deterioration would be seen on the FAST exam.

A hemothorax might manifest with dyspnea, chest pain, diminished/absent breath sounds, decreased tactile fremitus, dullness on percussion, and flat neck veins. It may also be associated with a raised jugular venous pressure. In severe cases of hemothorax, blood loss into the thoracic cavity can lead to hemorrhagic shock, with subsequent tachycardia and hypotension. However, a hemothorax is distinctly identifiable on chest x-ray or on ultrasound as part of the FAST exam. No signs of internal bleeding are apparent on this patient's FAST exam and the physical exam findings (bibasilar crackles, soft abdomen) make a significant hemothorax even more unlikely.

An aortic dissection may occur as the result of rapid deceleration (e.g., in a motor vehicle accident) and typically manifests with severe tearing chest pain that may radiate to different parts of the body. Aortic dissection is associated with hypotension either if the dissection involves the ascending aorta resulting in cardiac tamponade and/or aortic regurgitation, or if it results in aortic rupture and hemorrhage into the mediastinum. On the FAST exam, however, aortic rupture would be apparent as free fluid above the diaphragm, with secondary cardiac tamponade as fluid accumulates in the pericardium. Moreover, secondary aortic regurgitation severe enough to affect the patient's vitals would be heard on auscultation.

Pulmonary contusions can occur in the setting of chest trauma and result in chest pain, dyspnea, tachypnea, and hypoxia as “bruising” of the lung impairs gas exchange. Symptoms may then worsen following fluid administration as fluid accumulates in the damaged lung. While this patient does have chest pain and tachypnea and deteriorated after receiving fluids, pulmonary contusion would be less likely to cause the arrhythmia or fluid- and vasopressor-resistant hypotension that proved fatal in this patient.

Cardiac tamponade due to hemopericardium can occur after chest trauma due to cardiac wall rupture or aortic dissection of the ascending aorta, with accumulation of blood around the heart. Cardiac tamponade can manifest with rapidly developing hypotension and tachycardia following chest trauma, and show elevated jugular venous pressure (as part of Beck triad). However, patients with a cardiac tamponade will have a pulsus paradoxus, characteristically muffled heart sounds, and the FAST exam will show fluid around the heart.

question_text: Paramedics are called to a 35-year-old man who has accidentally cut off his left fingertip while chopping vegetables. He has no significant past medical history. His temperature is 37.2°C (99.0°F), pulse is 96/min, and blood pressure is 112/72 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 99%. His left index finger is amputated distal to the distal interphalangeal joint at the level of the nail bed, and exposed bone is visible. There is profuse bleeding from the wound site. His ability to flex, extend, abduct, and adduct the joints is preserved and sensation is intact. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step for preserving the detached fingertip prior to transporting this patient to the emergency department?
content_preview: Paramedics are called to a 35-year-old man who has accidentally cut off his left fingertip while chopping vegetables. He has no significant past medical history. His temperature is 37.2°C (99.0°F), pulse is 96/min, and blood pressure is 112/72 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 99%. His left index finger is amputated distal to the distal interphalangeal joint at the level of the nail bed, and exposed bone is visible. There is profuse bleeding from the wound site. His ability to flex, extend, abduct, and adduct the joints is preserved and sensation is intact. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step for preserving the detached fingertip prior to transporting this patient to the emergency department?
hint: In complete fingertip amputations, a specific first-aid technique is recommended to preserve the amputated tissue without causing cellular damage.
learning_objective: Choose the correct method to preserve a detached fingertip prior to transport.

answers.content: Wrap the fingertip in gauze wet with iodine in a sealed plastic bag placed on ice
answers.explanation_why: Although wrapping the fingertip in damp gauze, sealing it in a plastic bag, then placing it on ice is an appropriate approach for preserving an amputated fingertip, antiseptics such as iodine damage the finger tissue and decrease tissue viability, reducing the chances of successful reattachment (replantation).

answers.content: Wrap the fingertip in dry gauze in a sealed plastic bag placed on ice
answers.explanation_why: The fingertip should be wrapped in gauze, sealed in a plastic bag, and then placed on ice. However, dry gauze is not recommended because it compromises tissue integrity and decreases the chances of successful reattachment (replantation).

answers.content: Preserve the fingertip in cooled saline water
answers.explanation_why: Although the fingertip should be kept cool during transport, direct immersion in saline water is not recommended as it may cause maceration of tissue and decrease the likelihood of successful reattachment (replantation).

answers.content: Preserve the fingertip in warm saline water
answers.explanation_why: Warm saline water is not recommended as it may cause maceration (due to direct immersion in fluid) of open tissue and encourage microbial growth in the wound (by warming), both of which would decrease the likelihood of reattachment (replantation).

answers.content: Wrap the fingertip in gauze damp with saline in a sealed plastic bag placed in ice water
answers.explanation_why:
The amputated fingertip should be gently rinsed with water, wrapped in damp gauze, sealed in a watertight bag, and then placed in a bag with ice water. An amputated limb should never be placed directly on ice because of the potential for cold damage (i.e., frostbite). The aim is to preserve the finger as best as possible in order to maximize the chances of successful reattachment (replantation). The patient and their amputated fingertip should then be transported immediately to the emergency department.

Once in the emergency department, the patient's hand would be anesthetized and debrided. The decision to attempt reattachment is typically left to specialist consultation and is decided on a case-by-case basis, although it is not commonly attempted in adults.

answers.content: Place the fingertip on ice in a sealed plastic bag
answers.explanation_why: Directly placing the fingertip on ice is not recommended because of the risk of cold damage (i.e., frostbite).

answers.content: Wrap the fingertip in gauze wet with hydrogen peroxide in a sealed plastic bag placed on ice
answers.explanation_why: Although wrapping the fingertip in damp gauze, sealing it in a plastic bag, then placing it on ice is an appropriate approach for preserving an amputated fingertip, antiseptics such as hydrogen peroxide damage the finger tissue and decrease tissue viability, reducing the chances of successful reattachment (replantation).

answers.content: Wrap the fingertip in gauze wet with alcohol in a sealed plastic bag placed on ice
answers.explanation_why: Although wrapping the fingertip in damp gauze, sealing it in a plastic bag, then placing it on ice is an appropriate approach for preserving an amputated fingertip, antiseptics such as alcohol damage the finger tissue and decrease tissue viability, reducing the chances of successful reattachment (replantation).

question_text: A 23-year-old man is brought to the emergency department 30 minutes after being tackled while playing football. He has severe right shoulder pain and is unable to move the shoulder. He also reports nausea but has not vomited. There is no personal or family history of serious illness. His only medication is a multivitamin. On physical examination, the right upper extremity is externally rotated and slightly abducted. Palpation of the right shoulder joint shows tenderness and an empty glenoid fossa. The right humeral head is palpated below the coracoid process. The left upper extremity appears normal. Radial pulses are palpable bilaterally. An x-ray of the right shoulder is performed. The physician administers analgesia and obtains informed consent for closed reduction. This patient is at greatest risk for which of the following complications?
content_preview: A 23-year-old man is brought to the emergency department 30 minutes after being tackled while playing football. He has severe right shoulder pain and is unable to move the shoulder. He also reports nausea but has not vomited. There is no personal or family history of serious illness. His only medication is a multivitamin. On physical examination, the right upper extremity is externally rotated and slightly abducted. Palpation of the right shoulder joint shows tenderness and an empty glenoid fossa. The right humeral head is palpated below the coracoid process. The left upper extremity appears normal. Radial pulses are palpable bilaterally. An x-ray of the right shoulder is performed. The physician administers analgesia and obtains informed consent for closed reduction. This patient is at greatest risk for which of the following complications?
hint: This patient presents after trauma with external rotation and abduction of the arm, in combination with shoulder pain and palpation of the humeral head below the coracoid process, indicating anterior shoulder dislocation. This is the most common type of shoulder dislocation.
learning_objective: Recognize anterior shoulder dislocation, and recall its neurological complications.

answers.content: Paralysis of the wrist flexors and intrinsic hand muscles
answers.explanation_why: Paralysis of the wrist flexors and intrinsic hand muscles is seen in Klumpke palsy. This condition is typically caused by traumatic injury to the C8 and T1 nerve roots that form the lower trunk of the brachial plexus. The brachial plexus and its trunks lie more proximal than the nerve typically injured during a shoulder dislocation; therefore plexus injuries due to shoulder dislocation and reduction are exceedingly rare. In adults, Klumpke palsy most commonly occurs due to hyperabduction of the arm e.g., during an attempt to break a fall from a height by grabbing support.

answers.content: Decreased sensation of the dorsum of thumb, index, and middle fingers
answers.explanation_why: Decreased sensation in fingers I–III together with reduced finger extensor strength and wrist drop are characteristic of radial nerve injury, which can be caused by humeral shaft fracture. Signs of shaft fracture include severe local pain and swelling, deformity, crepitus, and shortening of the arm (if displacement is present). This patient's presentation is most consistent with anterior shoulder dislocation, in which radial nerve injury is uncommon. In addition, radial nerve injury is not a complication of closed shoulder reduction.

images.title: Radial nerve neuropathy
images.description:
Motor deficits:
- Wrist drop: inability to extend (dorsiflex) the wrist
- Inability to extend the fingers at the MCP jointsSensory deficits:
- Dorsal aspect: radial 2½ fingers (less commonly, 3½ fingers), excluding the tips of the 2^nd and 3^rd fingers. The 1^st web space is the autonomous sensory zone of the radial nerve and is highlighted in red.
- Palmar aspect: the radial border of the thumbProximal lesion: complete loss of motor and sensory function
Distal lesion (radial tunnel syndrome): partial loss of motor function; preservation of sensory function

answers.content: Decreased sensation of the lateral upper arm
answers.explanation_why:
Axillary nerve injury (ANI) is the most common nerve injury in shoulder dislocation because of the close proximity of the axillary nerve to the humeral head. ANI also rarely occurs as a complication of closed reduction, which is the first-line treatment for most patients with shoulder dislocation. Typical manifestations of ANI include decreased sensation over the lateral shoulder and impaired abduction and external rotation of the arm. In shoulder dislocation, impaired abduction and external rotation may occur because of mechanical reasons and are not necessarily a sign of ANI. Because ANI has a high rate of spontaneous recovery, patients are initially managed conservatively following closed reduction and immobilization to treat shoulder dislocation.

Other complications of shoulder dislocation include axillary artery and vein injury, fractures of the shoulder joint, and rotator cuff tears, all of which rarely also occur as a complication of reduction procedures.

images.title: Anterior shoulder dislocation surface anatomy
images.description: Lateral and ventral view of the right shoulderThe dashed line shows the normal position and the solid red line shows the pathological position that occurs with anterior dislocation. Axillary nerve palsy is a known complication of both shoulder dislocation and reduction. Axillary nerve function should be evaluated before and after attempting reduction, by testing sensation over the lateral surface of the shoulder (yellow overlay).

answers.content: Inability to flex the thumb, index, and middle fingers
answers.explanation_why: The inability to flex the thumb, index, and middle fingers results in the hand of benediction sign, which is characteristically seen in proximal median nerve injury (e.g., due to supracondylar humerus fracture). Median nerve injury is very unlikely in anterior shoulder dislocation and/or as a complication of reduction because it runs inferiorly to the shoulder joint.

images.title: Proximal and distal median nerve lesions
images.description: AI nerve: anterior interosseous nerve

answers.content: Decreased sensation of the lateral lower arm
answers.explanation_why: Decreased sensation of the lateral lower arm can result from musculocutaneous nerve injury. The musculocutaneous nerve is well-protected throughout its course and is rarely injured. Most musculocutaneous pathologies occur as a result of traumatic compression of the upper trunk of the brachial plexus. The brachial plexus and its trunks lie more proximal than the nerve typically injured during a shoulder dislocation; therefore plexus injuries due to shoulder dislocation and reduction are exceedingly rare.

question_text: A 31-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department 25 minutes after sustaining a gunshot wound to the neck. She did not lose consciousness. On arrival, she has severe neck pain. She appears anxious. Her temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 105/min, respirations are 25/min, and blood pressure is 100/70 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 96%. She is oriented to person, place, and time. Examination shows a bullet entrance wound in the right posterior cervical region of the neck. There is no exit wound. Carotid pulses are palpable bilaterally. There are no carotid bruits. Sensation to pinprick and light touch is normal. The lungs are clear to auscultation. Cardiac examination shows no murmurs, rubs, or gallops. In addition to intravenous fluid resuscitation, which of the following is the most appropriate next step in the management of this patient?
content_preview: A 31-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department 25 minutes after sustaining a gunshot wound to the neck. She did not lose consciousness. On arrival, she has severe neck pain. She appears anxious. Her temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 105/min, respirations are 25/min, and blood pressure is 100/70 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 96%. She is oriented to person, place, and time. Examination shows a bullet entrance wound in the right posterior cervical region of the neck. There is no exit wound. Carotid pulses are palpable bilaterally. There are no carotid bruits. Sensation to pinprick and light touch is normal. The lungs are clear to auscultation. Cardiac examination shows no murmurs, rubs, or gallops. In addition to intravenous fluid resuscitation, which of the following is the most appropriate next step in the management of this patient?
hint: This woman sustained a penetrating neck trauma and has stable vital signs with no signs of tracheal or esophageal injury. Nevertheless, initial evaluation of this patient involves ruling out occult injury to the trachea, esophagus, and vasculature.
learning_objective: Choose the most appropriate imaging modality for evaluating stable penetrating neck trauma.

answers.explanation_why: Surgical exploration is indicated in patients with penetrating neck injury who show signs of decompensation, an expanding hematoma, or tracheal/esophageal injury. Although this patient is tachycardic and tachypneic (most likely due to a sympathetic response to pain), she is normotensive and has normal oxygen saturation. She also has no signs of expanding hematoma, subcutaneous emphysema, or ongoing bleeding. Consequently, surgical exploration is not indicated at this time.

Stable patients with penetrating neck injuries should be evaluated for possible injuries to the trachea, larynx, and neck vessels. Multidetector CT angiography is the recommended imaging modality for the evaluation of these injuries. This test is fast, commonly available, highly specific and sensitive, and allows for comprehensive visualization of the neck, vascular, and nonvascular injuries.

Immediate intubation and surgical exploration are indicated in patients with hemodynamic instability, expanding hematoma, or clear signs of tracheal/esophageal injury.

A gunshot wound to the neck may require intubation, most commonly because of a tracheal injury or an expanding neck hematoma that compromises the airway. The patient, however, does not have an expanding hematoma and has no signs of tracheal injury (e.g., stridor, subcutaneous emphysema, hemoptysis) or respiratory distress. Her vital signs are stable, she is neurologically intact, and she has normal oxygen saturation, so there is no indication for endotracheal intubation at this time.

Barium swallow may be an appropriate test for the diagnosis of esophageal injury. Although penetrating neck injuries can cause esophageal injury, this patient shows none of the associated signs (e.g., dysphagia, hematemesis, subcutaneous emphysema), so a barium swallow study would not be indicated at this time. In addition, if there is high suspicion of esophageal perforation, a water-soluble contrast agent (such as gastrografin) is used instead of barium, which can cause mediastinitis.

Esophagoscopy is an appropriate test for the diagnosis of esophageal injury in patients with a negative barium swallow study or who are unable to participate in a barium swallow study. Although penetrating neck injuries may cause esophageal injury, this patient shows none of the associated signs (e.g., dysphagia, hematemesis, subcutaneous emphysema).

Laryngoscopy may be indicated for the diagnosis of occult injury to the larynx, but it is not the preferred initial diagnostic modality in a patient with penetrating neck injury. Moreover, this patient does not have any signs of laryngeal injury (e.g., stridor, dysphonia, hemoptysis).

A cricothyrotomy may be required if the patient is in respiratory distress and orotracheal intubation or supraglottic ventilation with a laryngeal mask device fails. This patient does not show any signs of respiratory distress.
