question_text: A 22-year-old man who is on active duty in the US Army sustains a stab wound to his chest during a military attack. He is brought to the combat medic by his unit for a primary survey. The soldier reports shortness of breath. He is alert and oriented to time, place, and person. His pulse is 99/min, respirations are 32/min, and blood pressure is 112/72 mm Hg. Examination shows a 2-cm wound at the left fourth intercostal space at the midclavicular line. Bubbling of blood is seen with each respiration at the wound site. There is no jugular venous distention. There is hyperresonance to percussion and decreased breath sounds on the left side. The trachea is at the midline. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
content_preview: A 22-year-old man who is on active duty in the US Army sustains a stab wound to his chest during a military attack. He is brought to the combat medic by his unit for a primary survey. The soldier reports shortness of breath. He is alert and oriented to time, place, and person. His pulse is 99/min, respirations are 32/min, and blood pressure is 112/72 mm Hg. Examination shows a 2-cm wound at the left fourth intercostal space at the midclavicular line. Bubbling of blood is seen with each respiration at the wound site. There is no jugular venous distention. There is hyperresonance to percussion and decreased breath sounds on the left side. The trachea is at the midline. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
hint: The presence of dyspnea and tachypnea with decreased breath sounds and hyperresonance to percussion after a penetrating chest wound with bubbling of blood indicates an open pneumothorax. The absence of hemodynamic instability, tracheal deviation, and jugular venous distention make a tension pneumothorax unlikely.
learning_objective: Recognize an open pneumothorax, and choose the most appropriate initial management.

answers.explanation_why: Emergency thoracotomy is indicated for patients with penetrating chest injury who are hemodynamically unstable and unresponsive to fluid resuscitation, or who have been pulseless and receiving CPR for < 15 minutes. Because this patient is hemodynamically stable, thoracotomy is not indicated.

A partially occlusive dressing (such as clear plastic film taped at 3 out of 4 sides of the lesion) is a temporary treatment for open pneumothorax, used to prevent further expansion of the pneumothorax until the diagnosis has been confirmed and definitive treatment is available. This dressing creates a flutter valve effect (i.e., air is free to escape from the gap in the dressing during exhalation while the dressing occludes the wound during inhalation), preventing the entry of further air via the wound into the thoracic cavity. Once the patient has been fully stabilized, a chest tube would be placed for definitive treatment of his pneumothorax. The tube should be placed through intact skin in one of the recommended anatomical locations, not through the preexisting injury.

Chest tubes alone are sufficient treatment for pneumothorax in ∼ 85% of cases; surgery is required for the remainder.

images.title: Open and closed pneumothorax
images.description:
Open pneumothorax: The entry of air into the pleural cavity through an unsealed defect in the thoracic wall (e.g., following penetrating trauma).
Closed pneumothorax: The entry of air into the pleural cavity through a breach in the visceral pleura (e.g., ruptured pulmonary bulla).

answers.explanation_why: Emergency pericardiocentesis is indicated for pericardial effusions causing hemodynamic instability (i.e., cardiac tamponade.) Although this patient is at risk for cardiac tamponade because of his penetrating thoracic trauma, he is hemodynamically stable and he has no evidence of tamponade (Beck triad: hypotension, muffled heart sounds, and distended neck veins). Therefore, emergency pericardiocentesis is not indicated at this time.

images.title: Pericardial effusion with water bottle configuration
images.description: X-ray chest (PA view) of a patient with lupus pericarditisThe cardiac silhouette is enlarged and demonstrates a globular, or water bottle, configuration due to pericardial effusion (green hatched overlay).

answers.explanation_why: Echocardiography is part of the FAST exam, which is used in the penetrating trauma primary examination. The ATLS-recommended approach to trauma resuscitation follows the ABCDE algorithm; Airway → Breathing → Circulation → Disability → Exposure → adjunctive tests (e.g., FAST exam). This patient has airway/breathing injuries that require treatment before resuscitation can continue to the adjunctive treatments. Although echocardiography would likely be performed on this patient at a later point, this test is not readily available in a combat field and this patient has another injury that takes precedence in trauma resuscitation.

Needle thoracostomy is a temporary, stabilizing treatment for tension pneumothorax, as it causes hemodynamic instability. Although this patient is at risk for tension pneumothorax given his penetrating chest wound, he is currently hemodynamically stable. Additionally, tension pneumothorax is caused by a chest wound acting as a one-way valve, allowing air into the pleural space but not allowing it to escape, which builds up pressure. Blood is seen bubbling from this patient's wound, which means that air is escaping from the wound.

images.title: Tension pneumothorax
images.description: X-ray chest (PA view)Much of the left hemithorax is hyperlucent, with a lack of vascular markings when compared to the right hemithorax. Lobulated opacities that project through the cardiac silhouette and along the left heart border represent collapsed lobes of the left lung (green overlay).Accompanying depression of the left hemidiaphragm (arrowheads), mass effect on the mediastinum, and widening of some intercostal spaces (double-headed arrows) are signs of tension pneumothorax, which requires immediate intervention.

question_text: A 36-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department 20 minutes after being involved in a high-speed motor vehicle collision. On arrival, she is unconscious. Her pulse is 140/min, respirations are 12/min and shallow, and blood pressure is 76/55 mm Hg. 0.9% saline infusion is begun. A focused assessment with sonography shows blood in the left upper quadrant of the abdomen. Her hemoglobin concentration is 7.6 g/dL and hematocrit is 22%. The surgeon decides to move the patient to the operating room for an emergency explorative laparotomy. Packed red blood cell transfusion is ordered prior to surgery. A friend of the patient asks for the transfusion to be held as the patient is a Jehovah's Witness. The patient has no advance directive and there is no documentation showing her refusal of blood transfusions. The patient's husband and children cannot be contacted. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
content_preview: A 36-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department 20 minutes after being involved in a high-speed motor vehicle collision. On arrival, she is unconscious. Her pulse is 140/min, respirations are 12/min and shallow, and blood pressure is 76/55 mm Hg. 0.9% saline infusion is begun. A focused assessment with sonography shows blood in the left upper quadrant of the abdomen. Her hemoglobin concentration is 7.6 g/dL and hematocrit is 22%. The surgeon decides to move the patient to the operating room for an emergency explorative laparotomy. Packed red blood cell transfusion is ordered prior to surgery. A friend of the patient asks for the transfusion to be held as the patient is a Jehovah's Witness. The patient has no advance directive and there is no documentation showing her refusal of blood transfusions. The patient's husband and children cannot be contacted. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
hint: Even though this patient's friend claims the patient is a Jehovah's Witness, there is no documentation to verify this claim nor the patient's wishes under these circumstances. In such emergency situations without a suitable surrogate decision-maker, the physician can make a decision based solely on the patient's safety and well-being.
learning_objective: Choose the most appropriate management in the absence of an advance directive or appropriate surrogate decision-maker.

answers.explanation_why: Hydroxyethyl starch is a volume expander formerly used in patients requiring volume resuscitation. Most regulatory bodies worldwide have moved towards suspending the use of hydroxyethyl starch since multiple studies have shown increased risks of death because of coagulopathy and acute kidney injury. For this patient in need of emergency medical intervention, other therapeutic options are safer, cheaper, and more likely to increase chances of survival.

answers.content: Transfusion of packed red blood cells
answers.explanation_why: While a surrogate decision-maker, such as a family member, can make treatment decisions on the patient's behalf if no advance directive exists, a friend is usually not an appropriate surrogate. In some states, a “close friend” may be considered as a surrogate. Physicians must make their decisions with consideration for the patient's preferences. However, as this patient's preferences are not clearly documented, it would be inappropriate to withhold lifesaving treatment based on the unverifiable claims of a friend. This patient is in shock from internal bleeding and transfusion with packed red blood cells is the best means of restoring volume and stabilizing the patient.

Consulting the hospital ethics committee can be useful in navigating ethical conflicts between providers, patients, families, and the law. However, this patient is in critical condition and delaying emergent treatment for a consult could endanger the patient further.

Iron therapy in patients with chronic anemia can help promote erythrogenesis. Iron would not provide any benefit to this critically ill patient who requires immediate repletion of intravascular volume and blood.

A blood transfusion would maximize this trauma patient's chances of survival. While a surrogate decision maker can make treatment decisions on the patient's behalf, decisions should still be made with consideration to the patient's preferences and the best interests of this patient. As this patient's preferences are not clearly documented, it would be inappropriate to withhold life-saving treatment based on the claims of a surrogate that cannot be verified and may result in the patient's death.

question_text: An 18-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department by her coach 30 minutes after injuring her left knee while playing field hockey. She was tackled from the left side and has been unable to bear weight on her left leg since the accident. She fears the left knee may be unstable upon standing. There is no personal or family history of serious illness. The patient appears uncomfortable. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows a swollen and tender left knee; range of motion is limited by pain. The medial joint line is tender to touch. The patient's hip is slightly flexed and abducted, and the knee is slightly flexed while the patient is in the supine position. Gentle valgus stress is applied across the left knee and medial joint laxity is noted. The remainder of the examination shows no further abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
content_preview: An 18-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department by her coach 30 minutes after injuring her left knee while playing field hockey. She was tackled from the left side and has been unable to bear weight on her left leg since the accident. She fears the left knee may be unstable upon standing. There is no personal or family history of serious illness. The patient appears uncomfortable. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows a swollen and tender left knee; range of motion is limited by pain. The medial joint line is tender to touch. The patient's hip is slightly flexed and abducted, and the knee is slightly flexed while the patient is in the supine position. Gentle valgus stress is applied across the left knee and medial joint laxity is noted. The remainder of the examination shows no further abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
hint: The patient's injury is likely to be one of the injuries that comprise the unhappy triad.
learning_objective: Recognize medial collateral ligament injury.

answers.explanation_why: Patients with posterior cruciate ligament injury often present with knee swelling. However, physical examination usually shows posterior knee instability rather than medial instability, and affected individuals usually experience minimal or no pain. In addition, injury caused by lateral direct force to the knee is an uncommon cause of posterior cruciate ligament injury, which is most commonly caused by noncontact injuries involving hyperflexion of the knee with a plantarflexed foot or contact injuries with force applied from the posterior side of the knee.

images.title: Posterior cruciate ligament tear
images.description: MRI knee (T2-weighted; sagittal plane)The posterior cruciate ligament (PCL) appears thickened and heterogeneous with an irregular and ill-defined contour (green overlay). It contains multiple areas of intermediate signal intensity, indicating tearing. A joint effusion is demonstrated by the hyperintense signal in the suprapatellar pouch (red overlay).A ligament tear does not always appear as a discrete defect and may be demonstrated by the features in this example. A normal PCL should appear as hypointense on all conventional MRI sequences and have smooth margins.

answers.explanation_why: Knee swelling and medial knee pain may be caused by medial meniscus injury. However, meniscus tears do not usually cause knee instability. Moreover, a lesion of the medial meniscus would typically lead to pain during adduction of the knee (varus stress), not during abduction (valgus stress), making the diagnosis unlikely.

images.title: Horizontal tear of the medial meniscus
images.description: MRI knee (upper image: T1-weighted, coronal plane; lower image: T1-weighted, sagittal plane)There is horizontal linear intermediate signal (white outline), parallel to the tibial plateau, within the posterior horn of the medial meniscus (green overlay).This is consistent with a horizontal meniscal tear.Red overlay: anterior horn of the medial meniscus

answers.explanation_why: Symptoms of anterior cruciate ligament (ACL) injury include knee swelling, pain, and instability after an inciting trauma. However, ACL injury most frequently occurs in the setting of noncontact sports injuries with a twisting mechanism, not a direct blow to the knee. In addition, valgus stress test would show anterior knee instability, not medial knee instability.

images.title: Anterior cruciate ligament injury
images.description: MRI knee (STIR; sagittal view)The anterior cruciate ligament is discontinuous. The distal part of the ligament demonstrates normal hypointense signal (red overlay), but the proximal half ligament demonstrates heterogenous hyperintense signal (yellow overlay). There is a gap between these two areas. There is also a large suprapatellar joint effusion (demonstrated as a white area due to high signal intensity; blue overlay). The partially imaged posterior cruciate ligament (green overlay) appears intact.This is an example of an anterior cruciate ligament rupture. The gap between the proximal and distal half of the ligament indicates it is a full-thickness tear. The heterogeneous hyperintense signal of the proximal half indicates partial thickness tearing of that component.

answers.explanation_why: Lateral collateral ligament (LCL) injury typically manifests with knee swelling, pain, and instability. However, affected individuals typically have a positive varus stress test, not a positive valgus stress test. LCL injury is typically caused by varus stress with possible external rotation, not a lateral force to the knee (valgus stress).

This patient has the characteristic features of medial collateral ligament (MCL) injury, including medial joint line tenderness and medial joint laxity, as confirmed by a positive valgus stress test. Knee swelling and pain are also commonly seen in this condition. Contact injury involving valgus stress on the knee, such as a tackle from the side, is the mechanism that most commonly causes MCL injury.

MCL injury is frequently associated with a medial meniscus tear, which can be assessed on physical exam. In this case, the remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities, which makes a concurrent meniscus injury less likely.

images.title: Unhappy triad
images.description: A triad of medial meniscus, anterior cruciate ligament, and medial collateral ligament tears. This injury typically occurs due to excessive valgus and external rotational stress with a fixed foot position.

answers.explanation_why: Individuals with lateral meniscus injury may present with knee swelling and tenderness as well as pain in the joint line when applying valgus stress to the affected knee. However, the pain is located in the lateral, not the medial joint line, making the diagnosis unlikely in this patient. In addition, isolated meniscus tears are usually not associated with knee instability.

question_text: A 24-year-old man is brought to the emergency department 30 minutes after being involved in a high-speed motor vehicle collision in which he was a restrained driver. On arrival, he is alert and oriented. His pulse is 112/min, respirations are 29/min, and blood pressure is 100/60 mm Hg. The pupils are equal and reactive to light. There is a 3-cm laceration over the forehead and multiple bruises over the trunk. The lungs are clear to auscultation. Cardiac examination shows no abnormalities. The abdomen is soft and nontender. The right knee is swollen and tender; range of motion is limited by pain. Infusion of 0.9% saline is begun and intravenous acetaminophen is administered. Two hours later, blood-tinged fluid spontaneously drains from both nostrils and is made worse by leaning forward. On a piece of gauze, it shows up as a rapidly expanding clear ring of fluid surrounding blood. Further evaluation of this patient over the next 24 hours is most likely to show which of the following findings?
content_preview: A 24-year-old man is brought to the emergency department 30 minutes after being involved in a high-speed motor vehicle collision in which he was a restrained driver. On arrival, he is alert and oriented. His pulse is 112/min, respirations are 29/min, and blood pressure is 100/60 mm Hg. The pupils are equal and reactive to light. There is a 3-cm laceration over the forehead and multiple bruises over the trunk. The lungs are clear to auscultation. Cardiac examination shows no abnormalities. The abdomen is soft and nontender. The right knee is swollen and tender; range of motion is limited by pain. Infusion of 0.9% saline is begun and intravenous acetaminophen is administered. Two hours later, blood-tinged fluid spontaneously drains from both nostrils and is made worse by leaning forward. On a piece of gauze, it shows up as a rapidly expanding clear ring of fluid surrounding blood. Further evaluation of this patient over the next 24 hours is most likely to show which of the following findings?
hint: This man has blood-tinged fluid draining from his nose after trauma that shows a halo sign (rapidly expanding clear ring of fluid surrounding blood), indicating cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) rhinorrhea. The most likely explanation is a basilar skull fracture of the anterior cranial fossa.
learning_objective: Recognize cerebrospinal fluid rhinorrhea after trauma, and recall the diagnostic finding of a basilar skull fracture.

answers.explanation_why: Basilar skull fracture can be associated with cranial nerve palsies. Anterior basilar skull fracture can cause cranial nerve (CN) I palsies, as well as palsies in CN V, VI, VII, or VIII. However, CN XII exits the skull at the hypoglossal canal of the occipital bone (in the posterior fossa) and thus is associated with posterior basilar skull fractures, not anterior basilar skull fractures. Additionally, most cranial nerve palsies associated with basilar skull fracture are not present until 1–3 days after injury, because the palsy is the result of compression or contusion of the nerve, which does not occur acutely. If a nerve is transected by trauma (which is uncommon), then the palsy would be present immediately.

This patient presents with CSF rhinorrhea, which is a classic sign of anterior basilar skull fracture. The positive halo sign confirms that the leakage contains CSF. Bilateral periorbital ecchymosis (“raccoon eyes”) is another typical sign of basilar skull fracture involving the anterior cranial fossa. "Raccoon eyes" is not seen immediately after an injury but rather develops after 1–3 days.

If basilar skull fracture is suspected, the next best steps in management are noncontrast CT scan of the head to confirm the diagnosis and neurosurgical consultation.

images.title: Bilateral periorbital ecchymosis
images.description: Face of a 54-year-old man after a fall on the back of his head 2 days earlierBilateral, symmetrical, dark purplish discoloration around the eye sockets is visible.This appearance, also referred to as "raccoon eyes," is a typical sign of basilar skull fractures involving the anterior fossa and typically develops 1–3 days after injury. Nontraumatic causes include neuroblastoma, plasma cell proliferative disorders (e.g., amyloidosis), and hematological malignancies. Periorbital ecchymosis may occur unilaterally or bilaterally.

answers.explanation_why: Upper cheek numbness is caused by damage to the infraorbital nerve, which is a complication of orbital fracture. Basilar skull fracture can in rare cases cause facial numbness by damaging cranial nerve V, but this would be seen in middle cranial fossa fracture. This patient's CSF rhinorrhea is indicative of anterior fossa fracture.

Trismus is most commonly associated with tetanus but may also be caused by zygomatic arch or mandibular fracture. Other signs of zygomatic arch or mandibular fracture include facial paresthesias, intraoral lacerations, and orbital edema. However, this patient has signs of anterior basilar skull fracture, not zygomatic or mandibular fracture, making trismus unlikely.

Carotid artery dissection is a rare complication of basilar skull fracture, specifically fractures involving injury to the carotid canal. Another finding would be much more likely. Additionally, this patient's CSF rhinorrhea suggests damage to the anterior fossa, while the carotid canal is in the middle fossa.

Retroauricular ecchymosis (“Battle sign”) involves the petrous part of the temporal bone specifically and is a classic sign of basilar skull fracture. However, petrous temporal fracture would cause CSF otorrhea, not rhinorrhea.

question_text:
Ten days after a motor vehicle collision, a 28-year-old man develops jaundiced skin. Upon initial presentation for his injuries, the patient was taken for an emergency laparotomy, which revealed significant internal hemorrhage from blunt abdominal trauma to the spleen. He required rapid transfusion with a total of 7 units of packed red blood cells. He has recovered well from the procedure until this morning, when he began to develop jaundiced skin and sclerae. He does not have pruritus. He has had no prior surgeries and takes no other medications. He is sexually active with one female partner. Prior to the accident, he drank 4 beers per day. His vital signs are within normal limits. Abdominal examination is limited due to pain. There are no palpable abdominal masses. There is a midline surgical scar with no erythema, purulence, or drainage. He has healing abrasions on the upper left side of his face and bruises over the anterior abdomen. CT scan shows a resolving hematoma in the peritoneal cavity. Laboratory studies show:

Hemoglobin
9.7 g/dL

Hematocrit
30%

Leukocyte count
7000/mm^3

Platelet count
135,000/mm^3

Serum

 Total bilirubin
3.9 mg/dL

 Indirect bilirubin

3.7 mg/dL

 Direct bilirubin
0.2 mg/dL

 Aspartate aminotransferase (AST)
60 U/L

 Alanine aminotransferase (ALT)
92 U/L

Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's jaundice?
content_preview: Ten days after a motor vehicle collision, a 28-year-old man develops jaundiced skin. Upon initial presentation for his injuries, the patient was taken for an emergency laparotomy, which revealed significant internal hemorrhage from blunt abdominal trauma to the spleen. He required rapid transfusion with a total of 7 units of packed red blood cells. He has recovered well from the procedure until this morning, when he began to develop jaundiced skin and sclerae. He does not have pruritus. He has had no prior surgeries and takes no other medications. He is sexually active with one female partner. Prior to the accident, he drank 4 beers per day. His vital signs are within normal limits. Abdominal examination is limited due to pain. There are no palpable abdominal masses. There is a midline surgical scar with no erythema, purulence, or drainage. He has healing abrasions on the upper left side of his face and bruises over the anterior abdomen. CT scan shows a resolving hematoma in the peritoneal cavity. Laboratory studies show: Hemoglobin 9.7 g/dL Hematocrit 30% Leukocyte count 7000/mm3 Platelet count 135,000/mm3 Serum Total bilirubin 3.9 mg/dL Indirect bilirubin 3.7 mg/dL Direct bilirubin 0.2 mg/dL Aspartate aminotransferase (AST) 60 U/L Alanine aminotransferase (ALT) 92 U/L Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's jaundice?
hint: This patient has unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia 10 days after significant internal hemorrhage from blunt abdominal trauma. The underlying cause involves reabsorption of the hematoma in his peritoneal cavity.
learning_objective: Recognize increased formation of bilirubin as a cause of jaundice.

answers.explanation_why: Biliary obstruction, which can be caused by choledocholithiasis, pancreatic masses, or primary sclerosing cholangitis, leads to an increase in conjugated, rather than unconjugated, bilirubin. In addition, blunt abdominal trauma rarely causes biliary obstruction.

The liver and spleen are the most commonly injured solid organs in patients who have sustained blunt abdominal trauma. Though this patient has a mild increase in transaminase concentrations, which may indicate some injury to the liver, hepatocellular injury generally results in a mixed conjugated and unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia due to interference in uptake, conjugation, and excretion of bilirubin.

Reabsorption of blood from a hematoma (e.g., in trauma patients or postsurgical patients) involves the breakdown of hemoglobin, which is metabolized into bilirubin before being transported to the liver to be conjugated with glucuronic acid to become water-soluble. Increased formation of bilirubin results in unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia, as seen in this patient.

Intrahepatic cholestasis is caused by various conditions, including viral hepatitis, alcohol-associated hepatitis, and primary biliary cholangitis. Intrahepatic cholestasis causes an increase in conjugated bilirubin, not unconjugated bilirubin.

Impaired conjugation of bilirubin is seen in patients with Crigler-Najjar syndrome and Gilbert syndrome, both of which are congenital conditions that impair intrahepatic conjugation of bilirubin with glucuronic acid. Crigler-Najjar syndrome is a rare disease that typically causes severe jaundice and neurologic impairment in newborns; this condition is unlikely in this adult patient with asymptomatic jaundice. Gilbert syndrome can manifest later in life, but this patient's recent history of blunt abdominal trauma with a resolving hematoma on CT scan makes another cause of jaundice more likely.

answers.content: Decreased hepatic uptake of unconjugated bilirubin
answers.explanation_why: Decreased hepatic uptake of unconjugated bilirubin can occur in patients with congestive heart failure, portosystemic shunts, and, rarely, Gilbert syndrome. Although these conditions can also cause an isolated increase in unconjugated bilirubin, they are unlikely in this young patient who has no history of cardiovascular or hepatobiliary disease.

question_text: A 58-year-old man comes to the physician because of burning pain in his neck and arms for a year. He has also had paresthesias in his hands during this period. He has had increasing weakness in both hands during the past 3 months. He has type 2 diabetes mellitus, hypercholesterolemia, and hypertension. He was involved in a motor vehicle collision 3 years ago. Current medications include metformin, sitagliptin, enalapril, atorvastatin, and aspirin. He has had 7 sexual partners in his lifetime; he uses condoms inconsistently. He is oriented to time, place, and person. Vital signs are within normal limits. The pupils are equal and reactive to light. Examination of the upper extremities shows decreased muscle strength, absent reflexes, and decreased hand grip with fasciculations bilaterally. Sensation to temperature and pain is absent over the chest and bilateral upper arms. Vibration and joint position sensations are present in the upper limbs. Cranial nerve examination shows no focal findings. Examination of the lower extremities show no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
content_preview: A 58-year-old man comes to the physician because of burning pain in his neck and arms for a year. He has also had paresthesias in his hands during this period. He has had increasing weakness in both hands during the past 3 months. He has type 2 diabetes mellitus, hypercholesterolemia, and hypertension. He was involved in a motor vehicle collision 3 years ago. Current medications include metformin, sitagliptin, enalapril, atorvastatin, and aspirin. He has had 7 sexual partners in his lifetime; he uses condoms inconsistently. He is oriented to time, place, and person. Vital signs are within normal limits. The pupils are equal and reactive to light. Examination of the upper extremities shows decreased muscle strength, absent reflexes, and decreased hand grip with fasciculations bilaterally. Sensation to temperature and pain is absent over the chest and bilateral upper arms. Vibration and joint position sensations are present in the upper limbs. Cranial nerve examination shows no focal findings. Examination of the lower extremities show no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
hint: The presence of pain along with sensory deficits to pain and temperature in a cape-like distribution over the neck and upper extremities while sparing more distal sensory levels suggests injury to decussating fibers in the cervical and upper thoracic spinal cord. A history of motor vehicle collision and progressive symptoms point to a traumatic etiology.
learning_objective: Recognize syringomyelia.

answers.explanation_why: Tabes dorsalis, a manifestation of tertiary syphilis, manifests with progressive loss of vibration and proprioception in the lower extremity by affecting the dorsal column of the spinal cord. While this patient may have a sexually transmitted disease such as syphilis as a result of inconsistent condom use, his lower extremities are unaffected, making tabes dorsalis unlikely.

Cervical disc prolapse can lead to nerve root compression (radiculopathy), which may manifest with paresthesias as well as sensory and/or motor deficits. However, neurological symptoms produced by disc prolapse are usually unilateral and localized to the distribution of the compressed nerve root. It is very unlikely that nerve root compression is the cause of this patient's symmetrical distribution of deficits; many nerve roots would have to be compressed simultaneously on both sides. In addition, all sensations are usually affected by nerve root compression, and the preservation of vibration and positional sense suggests a different diagnosis.

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) may manifest with a combination of upper and lower motor neuron weakness that progresses over time. However, ALS is more typically asymmetric and does not present with sensory deficits.

images.title: Clinical features and pathophysiology of amyotrophic lateral sclerosis
images.description: Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis is a neurodegenerative disease that affects the entire motor neuron system (degeneration of the upper motor neuron in the precentral gyrus and lower motor neuron in the brainstem or anterior horn of the spinal cord). The disease most commonly manifests between 50 and 70 years of age, often beginning with unilateral weakness in the hands or feet, which then progresses to the contralateral side (asymmetric limb weakness). However, initial manifestations are highly variable and individuals may have atypical or nonspecific symptoms such as subtle vocal changes. As the disease progresses, most individuals eventually develop one or both of the life-threatening symptoms: respiratory impairment and dysphagia.

answers.explanation_why: Brown-Séquard syndrome, which results from a hemisection of the spinal cord, presents with dissociated sensory loss and unilateral motor deficits below the level of the injury. This patient has deficits affecting only his arms and chest, without involvement of the remaining trunk and lower extremities. In addition, Brown-Séquard syndrome typically occurs immediately following spinal cord injury and is not likely to develop three years later.

Multiple sclerosis (MS) manifests with multiple demyelinating lesions affecting the brain and spinal cord. Although this patient's sensory deficit and arm weakness may be explained by demyelinating lesions in the spinal cord and the medulla, MS is unlikely given this patient's lower motor neuron findings (e.g., fasciculations, loss of reflexes). In addition, unlike this patient's gradual progression, MS more typically manifests with a relapsing-remitting course (though in rare cases, may also be rapidly progressive).

Subacute combined degeneration (SCD) of the spinal cord affects the posterior and posterolateral columns of the spinal cord, presenting with upper motor neuron pattern weakness of the extremities and impaired fine touch and proprioception. This patient has preserved fine touch and proprioception along with fasciculations and areflexia of the upper extremities, which are more characteristic of lower motor neuron pattern weakness.

Posttraumatic syringomyelia can occur months to years after whiplash injury to the neck and manifests with the classical findings of a central cord syndrome. Patients experience a symmetric cape-like distribution of pain and temperature sensory loss around the upper trunk, shoulders, and upper limbs. Vibration and position sense are selectively spared because fibers of the posterior columns decussate higher up in the medulla. As syringomyelia progresses, lower motor neuron weakness develops symmetrically in the upper limbs (evident by hand weakness, areflexia, and fasciculations in this patient) because the fluid-filled cavity begins to compress the anterior horn cells of the spinal cord at the level of the lesion. As the lesion expands, patients develop an upper motor neuron palsy of the lower extremities and lower half of the trunk (due to involvement of the corticospinal tracts), as well as complete sensory loss below the level of the lesion (including loss of vibration and position sense). However, sensations around the sacral region are usually spared.

question_text:
A 43-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department 30 minutes after she sustained a gunshot wound to the abdomen. On arrival, she is alert and oriented. Her temperature is 36.5°C (97.7°F), pulse is 115/min and regular, respirations are 30/min, and blood pressure is 90/70 mm Hg. Examination shows cool and damp extremities. Abdominal examination shows a 3-cm entrance wound in the left upper quadrant at the midclavicular line below the left costal margin. Focused ultrasound shows free fluid in the left upper quadrant. Intravenous fluid resuscitation is begun. Which of the following are the most likely hemodynamic findings in this patient?

Cardiac output (CO)
Pulmonary capillary wedge pressure (PCWP)
Systemic vascular resistance (SVR)
Central venous pressure (CVP)

A
↓
↑
↑
↑

B
↓
↓
↑
↓

C
↓
↓
↓
↓

D
↓
↓
↑
↑

E
↑
↓
↓
↓
content_preview: A 43-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department 30 minutes after she sustained a gunshot wound to the abdomen. On arrival, she is alert and oriented. Her temperature is 36.5°C (97.7°F), pulse is 115/min and regular, respirations are 30/min, and blood pressure is 90/70 mm Hg. Examination shows cool and damp extremities. Abdominal examination shows a 3-cm entrance wound in the left upper quadrant at the midclavicular line below the left costal margin. Focused ultrasound shows free fluid in the left upper quadrant. Intravenous fluid resuscitation is begun. Which of the following are the most likely hemodynamic findings in this patient? Cardiac output (CO) Pulmonary capillary wedge pressure (PCWP) Systemic vascular resistance (SVR) Central venous pressure (CVP) A ↓ ↑ ↑ ↑ B ↓ ↓ ↑ ↓ C ↓ ↓ ↓ ↓ D ↓ ↓ ↑ ↑ E ↑ ↓ ↓ ↓
hint: Hypotension, tachycardia, cool extremities, and free fluid in the abdomen after sustaining a gunshot wound are consistent with hypovolemic shock.
learning_objective: Recognize hypovolemic shock, and recall its hemodynamic findings.

answers.explanation_why: The combination ↓ CO, ↑ PCWP, ↑ SVR, and ↑ CVP is characteristic of cardiogenic shock. If the heart is unable to pump adequately, CO decreases. Blood then “backs up” into the left atrium (LA), causing increased LA pressure (and thus ↑ PCWP). Increased LA pressure leads to increased right heart pressures, causing high CVP. Decreased CO leads to hypotension, so the peripheral vasculature constricts (↑ SVR) in an attempt to maintain adequate blood pressure for organ perfusion. This patient has no history to suggest pump dysfunction (e.g., history of heart failure or arrhythmia), so this form of shock is unlikely.

The combination of ↓ CO, ↓ PCWP, ↑ SVR, and ↓ CVP is characteristic of hypovolemic shock. Hemorrhage (e.g., after sustaining a gunshot wound) leads to intravascular volume depletion, which decreases blood return to the right atrium (as evidenced by ↓ CVP). Low right heart blood volume results in decreased blood delivery to the left atrium (shown by ↓ PCWP), and consequently low left ventricular end-diastolic volume (i.e., decreased preload), which in turn causes decreased CO. Low CO leads to hypotension, so the peripheral vasculature constricts (↑ SVR) in an attempt to maintain adequate blood pressure for organ perfusion.

The treatment of choice for hypovolemic shock is correction of the underlying cause (e.g., hemostatic control in cases of hemorrhage) and intravascular volume repletion with IV fluids. Vasopressors are not beneficial in hypovolemic shock because the SVR is already elevated.

The combination of ↓ CO, ↓ PCWP, ↓ SVR, and ↓ CVP is seen in some cases of distributive shock (especially neurogenic shock). Neurogenic shock typically results from severe CNS trauma (e.g., spinal cord transection) and is associated with other neurologic abnormalities (e.g., paralysis). Neurogenic shock is believed to result from loss of autonomic control of cardiovascular parameters due to CNS damage. Heart rate is characteristically low in neurogenic shock (likely due to excessive vagal tone), which leads to decreased CO. SVR is low due to peripheral vasodilation due to loss of sympathetic tone. Peripheral vasodilation causes decreased venous return to the heart, leading to low CVP and consequently low left atrial pressure (and PCWP). This patient has no history or physical findings suggestive of neurologic injury and she is tachycardic on examination. Another form of shock is more likely.

The combination of ↓ CO, ↓ PCWP, ↑ SVR, and ↑ CVP is characteristic of obstructive shock (e.g., massive pulmonary embolism). In most forms of obstructive shock, blood flow from the right heart to the left heart is blocked, so blood “backs up” into the right atrium, causing increased CVP. Insufficient blood is delivered to the left atrium (LA), leading to decreased LA pressure (and thus ↓ PCWP), and little preload for the left ventricle (causing ↓ CO). Low CO results in hypotension, which induces peripheral vascular constriction (and thus ↑ SVR) in an attempt to maintain adequate blood pressure. This patient's history of a gunshot to the abdomen with free fluid in the abdomen suggests a different form of shock.

In certain cases of obstructive shock (e.g., due to cardiac tamponade), PCWP can also be increased.

The combination of ↑ CO, ↓ PCWP, ↓ SVR, and ↓ CVP is seen in some cases of distributive shock (e.g., early septic shock). Distributive shock is classically referred to as warm shock, because there is inappropriate peripheral vasodilation (causing ↓ CVP, ↓ SVR, and thus ↓ PCWP) and increased CO leading to excessive blood delivery to the limbs, resulting in inappropriately warm limbs in a hypotensive patient. This patient's limbs are cool, which indicates appropriate peripheral vasoconstriction in an attempt to maintain adequate blood pressure. This patient has no history of infection and presents in hyperacute shock after penetrating trauma, which suggests an alternative shock physiology.

question_text: A 46-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department because of pain and swelling in her right ankle after falling from her horse. She did not lose consciousness. She appears to be in acute distress. Her temperature is 36.7°C (98°F), pulse is 80/min, and blood pressure is 138/76 mm Hg. She is oriented to person, place, and time. The pupils are equal and reactive to light. Examination shows an abrasion on the left knee. The right ankle is swollen and tender; range of motion is limited by pain. Peripheral pulses and sensation are intact over the right foot. A lateral x-ray of the right ankle shows a fracture of the posterior malleolus. An anteroposterior x-ray of the right ankle is shown. In addition to analgesia, which of the following is the most appropriate management?
content_preview: A 46-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department because of pain and swelling in her right ankle after falling from her horse. She did not lose consciousness. She appears to be in acute distress. Her temperature is 36.7°C (98°F), pulse is 80/min, and blood pressure is 138/76 mm Hg. She is oriented to person, place, and time. The pupils are equal and reactive to light. Examination shows an abrasion on the left knee. The right ankle is swollen and tender; range of motion is limited by pain. Peripheral pulses and sensation are intact over the right foot. A lateral x-ray of the right ankle shows a fracture of the posterior malleolus. An anteroposterior x-ray of the right ankle is shown. In addition to analgesia, which of the following is the most appropriate management?
hint: The x-rays show a trimalleolar ankle fracture, which is an unstable fracture that involves the medial, lateral, and posterior malleoli.
learning_objective: Recognize a trimalleolar ankle fracture, and choose the most appropriate management.

answers.explanation_why: Closed reduction is used for stable fractures, including isolated or nondisplaced malleolar fractures, in which reduction can be achieved nonsurgically. A short leg cast is usually applied for 4–6 weeks after closed reduction. Closed reduction and casting of an unstable ankle fracture, like the one seen here, does not allow the misaligned bone fragments to heal properly.

Conservative measures, such as bed rest and cooling, can be used to treat stable, nondisplaced fractures, such as an isolated malleolar fracture. This patient has an unstable fracture that requires definitive management.

answers.content: Limited weight bearing with use of crutches
answers.explanation_why: Conservative measures, such as limited weight bearing with use of crutches, can be used to treat stable, nondisplaced fractures, such as an isolated malleolar fracture. This patient has an unstable fracture that requires definitive management.

Closed reduction and percutaneous pinning are usually used with displaced fractures of the hand or the distal end of the radius. The severity, instability, and location of the patient's fracture require a different approach to achieve proper repair.

Open reduction and internal fixation (ORIF) is indicated to realign and fixate a fractured bone into the normal position. Unstable fractures, such as trimalleolar and most bimalleolar ankle fractures, require strong fixation, which can be achieved with ORIF. This patient will also require an ankle cast for external immobilization and rest after surgery, and she should be discharged on crutches to minimize weight-bearing on the healing bones.

images.title: Trimalleolar ankle fracture
images.description: X-ray ankle (right; AP view) after supination-external rotation injuryAn oblique fracture of the distal fibula (yellow overlay and red line) is accompanied by an avulsion fracture (red lines) of the medial malleolus (green overlay). The ankle mortise has been disrupted. There is widening of the medial compartment (indicated by white arrow) and lateral displacement of the talus (indicated by a black arrow). A lateral view (not included here) showed a fracture of the posterior malleolus.The findings indicate an unstable trimalleolar fracture that requires operative treatment. If classified based on the location of the fibular fracture (Danis-Weber classification), this would be a Weber type B injury.

question_text: A 25-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department after being involved in a rear-end collision, in which she was the restrained driver of the back car. On arrival, she is alert and active. She reports pain in both knees and severe pain over the right groin. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 116/min, respirations are 19/min, and blood pressure is 132/79 mm Hg. Physical examination shows tenderness over both knee caps. The right groin is tender to palpation. The right leg is slightly shortened, flexed, adducted, and internally rotated. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
content_preview: A 25-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department after being involved in a rear-end collision, in which she was the restrained driver of the back car. On arrival, she is alert and active. She reports pain in both knees and severe pain over the right groin. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 116/min, respirations are 19/min, and blood pressure is 132/79 mm Hg. Physical examination shows tenderness over both knee caps. The right groin is tender to palpation. The right leg is slightly shortened, flexed, adducted, and internally rotated. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
hint: This patient has a typical dashboard injury.
learning_objective: Recognize posterior hip dislocation.

answers.explanation_why: A dashboard injury can result in a femoral neck fracture, which manifests with hip and groin pain. A displaced femoral neck fracture also results in limb shortening. However, the leg of a patient with a femoral neck fracture would be either in the neutral position or externally rotated, not internally rotated.

images.title: Clinical presentation of femoral neck fracture

answers.explanation_why: Patients with an anterior hip dislocation may present with pain in the groin, and a mild flexion deformity of the hip. However, the leg would be lengthened, externally rotated, and mildly abducted.

Femoral shaft fractures usually occur following high-energy trauma (e.g., motor vehicle accidents) and may manifest with shortening of the injured limb and leg pain. However, the pain is usually localized to the mid-thigh, and the thigh would be swollen.

Posterior hip dislocation is the most common type of hip dislocation (approx. 90% of cases) and classically occurs following high-energy trauma, in which a posteriorly directed force (e.g., dashboard during a motor vehicle accident) is directed towards the hip. The affected leg is typically shortened, mildly flexed, internally rotated, and adducted. Given the considerable amount of force required for posterior hip dislocation, associated fractures of the femoral head or the acetabulum are common.

Hip dislocation is diagnosed with the help of an AP view x-ray of the hip. In the case of posterior hip dislocation, the femoral head on the dislocated side usually appears smaller than the normal side, the lesser trochanter may not be visible as a result of internal hip joint rotation, and Shenton's line is typically disrupted.

images.title: Dashboard injury
images.description: Dashboard injuries occur when a force is directed posteriorly towards an internally rotated, flexed, and adducted hip. Potentially resulting damage includes posterior dislocation of the hip; damage to the posterior cruciate ligament of the knee; fracture of the acetabulum, femoral head, or patella; and sciatic nerve injury.

answers.explanation_why: Pelvic ring fractures usually occur following high-energy trauma (e.g., road traffic accident) and may present with hip or groin pain and leg-length discrepancy. However, there is no evidence of pelvic instability, perineal hemorrhage, or swelling on physical examination. Moreover, in a patient with pelvic ring fracture, the limbs are usually externally (rather than internally) rotated.

question_text: X-rays of the pelvis, right hip, and both knee caps are performed. The pelvic ring, including the right acetabulum, is intact. The knee caps are normal. An x-ray of the right hip shows posterior dislocation. The femoral neck and shaft on the right side are both intact and there are no signs of a fracture. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
content_preview: X-rays of the pelvis, right hip, and both knee caps are performed. The pelvic ring, including the right acetabulum, is intact. The knee caps are normal. An x-ray of the right hip shows posterior dislocation. The femoral neck and shaft on the right side are both intact and there are no signs of a fracture. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
hint: Posterior hip dislocation requires prompt treatment to avoid further complications.
learning_objective: Choose the most appropriate next step in managing a posterior hip dislocation.

answers.explanation_why: Observation is not recommended in this patient because prompt treatment is required to avoid further complications. Additionally, open reduction is only indicated if closed reduction fails, when the dislocation is associated with femoral neck or head fracture, or if bony fragments/tissue are found within the joint space, and none of these conditions apply.

Immediate treatment is indicated in patients with posterior hip dislocation. Open reduction, however, is only indicated if closed reduction fails, dislocation is associated with femoral neck or head fracture, or bony fragments/tissue are found within the joint space, and none of these conditions apply.

Observation is not recommended in this patient because prompt treatment is required to avoid further complications. Although this patient's dislocation needs to be reduced, it should be done as soon as possible and not as an elective procedure.

answers.content: Reassurance and follow-up in two weeks
answers.explanation_why: Reassurance and follow-up in two weeks is not a recommended strategy because spontaneous resolution is very unlikely to occur. The risk of complications (e.g., osteonecrosis, nerve injury) warrants further treatment.

Emergency closed reduction, usually carried out under procedural sedation, is the recommended treatment for simple posterior hip dislocation. This intervention should be performed as soon as possible (usually within 6 hours) to improve blood flow to the femoral head and thus minimize the risk of complications (e.g., osteonecrosis, degenerative joint disease).

question_text: A 66-year-old man is brought to the emergency department 20 minutes after being involved in a high-speed motor vehicle collision in which he was the unrestrained passenger. His wife confirms that he has hypertension, atrial fibrillation, and chronic lower back pain. Current medications include metoprolol, warfarin, hydrochlorothiazide, and oxycodone. On arrival, he is lethargic and confused. His pulse is 112/min, respirations are 10/min, and blood pressure is 172/78 mm Hg. The eyes open spontaneously. The pupils are equal and sluggish. He moves his extremities in response to commands. There is a 3-cm scalp laceration. There are multiple bruises over the right upper extremity. Cardiopulmonary examination shows no abnormalities. The abdomen is soft and nontender. Neurologic examination shows no focal findings. Two large-bore peripheral intravenous catheters are inserted. A 0.9% saline infusion is begun. A focused assessment with sonography in trauma is negative. Plain CT of the brain shows a 5-mm right subdural hematoma with no mass effect. Fresh frozen plasma is administered. Which of the following is most likely to reduce this patient's cerebral blood flow?
content_preview: A 66-year-old man is brought to the emergency department 20 minutes after being involved in a high-speed motor vehicle collision in which he was the unrestrained passenger. His wife confirms that he has hypertension, atrial fibrillation, and chronic lower back pain. Current medications include metoprolol, warfarin, hydrochlorothiazide, and oxycodone. On arrival, he is lethargic and confused. His pulse is 112/min, respirations are 10/min, and blood pressure is 172/78 mm Hg. The eyes open spontaneously. The pupils are equal and sluggish. He moves his extremities in response to commands. There is a 3-cm scalp laceration. There are multiple bruises over the right upper extremity. Cardiopulmonary examination shows no abnormalities. The abdomen is soft and nontender. Neurologic examination shows no focal findings. Two large-bore peripheral intravenous catheters are inserted. A 0.9% saline infusion is begun. A focused assessment with sonography in trauma is negative. Plain CT of the brain shows a 5-mm right subdural hematoma with no mass effect. Fresh frozen plasma is administered. Which of the following is most likely to reduce this patient's cerebral blood flow?
hint: Reducing this patient's cerebral blood flow can lower intracranial pressure (ICP) but also lead to ischemia. Cerebral autoregulation is controlled by the partial pressure of carbon dioxide (PaCO_2).
learning_objective: Choose the most appropriate intervention to reduce cerebral blood flow in the context of intracranial pressure management.

answers.explanation_why:
Hyperventilation blows off CO_2, which lowers PaCO_2 levels and results in arterial smooth muscle constriction. Based on Poiseuille's law, small decreases in the arterial radius from vasoconstriction can profoundly decrease cerebral blood flow. Since the cranial vault has a finite amount of space, decreasing cerebral blood flow allows more room for brain tissue and reductions in ICP.

Although hyperventilation was commonly used to reduce ICP, studies have failed to show long-term outcome advantages. Prophylactic hyperventilation is no longer recommended and should only be used as a temporary measure for elevated ICP refractory to medical therapy.

Decompressive craniectomy can increase blood flow by creating more space for brain swelling and thus reducing intracranial pressure. This reduction in intracranial pressure can improve cerebral perfusion pressure and blood flow. However, this technique is controversial, as the efficacy of decompressive craniectomy in traumatic brain injury is unclear and would not be the most appropriate first step in management for this patient.

Lumbar puncture can increase cerebral blood flow by removing CSF, thus creating more space for brain tissue and vessels. This technique is most commonly used to lower ICP in patients with hydrocephalus (e.g., normal pressure hydrocephalus). However, lumbar puncture is contraindicated in any patient with increased intracranial pressure due to brain swelling, as CSF removal can release pressure in the lower spinal cord causing downward brain herniation and death.

Hypertonic saline increases blood osmolality, which draws water from brain tissue into the intravascular space and thereby reduces ICP. Decreases in ICP can increase cerebral perfusion pressure and cerebral blood flow by creating more space for vessels. Unless there is evidence of brain herniation, hypertonic saline is reserved for patients with confirmed increases in ICP.

Mannitol acts by rapidly expanding circulating blood volume and decreasing blood viscosity. This causes an increase in cerebral blood flow and the subsequent compensatory cerebral vasoconstriction results in an initial fall in ICP. After about 15–30 minutes, it further increases cerebral blood flow by increasing cerebral perfusion pressure. Because prolonged mannitol therapy can increase ICP, it should only be used in the acute phase in patients with signs of significant increases in ICP (e.g., mass effect, impending brain herniation).

question_text: A 28-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department 1 hour after being involved in a motor vehicle collision. She was riding a bike when she lost control and hit a car on the opposite side of the road. On arrival, she is unconscious. She has a history of intravenous heroin use. Her pulse is 56/min, respirations are 8/min and irregular, and blood pressure is 196/85 mm Hg. Examination shows a 2-cm laceration over the left cheek and a 3-cm laceration over the left chest. There are multiple abrasions over her face and chest. She opens her eyes and flexes her extremities to painful stimuli. The pupils are dilated and react sluggishly to light. There are decreased breath sounds over the left lung. The trachea is central. There is no jugular venous distention. Cardiac examination shows no abnormalities. The abdomen is soft and nontender. The left knee and right ankle are swollen; range of motion is limited. Two large-bore peripheral intravenous catheters are inserted. The patient is intubated and mechanical ventilation is initiated. A focused assessment with sonography in trauma is negative. An occlusive dressing is applied over the left chest wound. She is scheduled for a noncontrast CT scan of the brain. Which of the following is the underlying cause of this patient's hypertension?
content_preview: A 28-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department 1 hour after being involved in a motor vehicle collision. She was riding a bike when she lost control and hit a car on the opposite side of the road. On arrival, she is unconscious. She has a history of intravenous heroin use. Her pulse is 56/min, respirations are 8/min and irregular, and blood pressure is 196/85 mm Hg. Examination shows a 2-cm laceration over the left cheek and a 3-cm laceration over the left chest. There are multiple abrasions over her face and chest. She opens her eyes and flexes her extremities to painful stimuli. The pupils are dilated and react sluggishly to light. There are decreased breath sounds over the left lung. The trachea is central. There is no jugular venous distention. Cardiac examination shows no abnormalities. The abdomen is soft and nontender. The left knee and right ankle are swollen; range of motion is limited. Two large-bore peripheral intravenous catheters are inserted. The patient is intubated and mechanical ventilation is initiated. A focused assessment with sonography in trauma is negative. An occlusive dressing is applied over the left chest wound. She is scheduled for a noncontrast CT scan of the brain. Which of the following is the underlying cause of this patient's hypertension?
hint: This patient presents with Cushing triad (hypertension, bradycardia, and irregular respiration) as a result of increased intracranial pressure (ICP) due to traumatic brain injury (TBI).
learning_objective: Recognize Cushing's triad, and recall its association with elevated intracranial pressure.

answers.explanation_why:
Elevated ICP in this patient has led to a decrease in cerebral perfusion pressure (CPP). The sympathetic nervous system is activated in order to maintain CPP by increasing systolic blood pressure, which explains this patient's hypertension and widening pulse pressure. The increased arterial pressure stimulates aortic arch baroreceptors that activate the parasympathetic nervous system, resulting in bradycardia. A further increase in ICP leads to brain stem compression, which further promotes bradycardia and causes dysfunction of the respiratory center (bradypnea and irregular breathing).

Clinical features of elevated ICP warrant urgent neuroimaging (CT or MRI) to evaluate for intracerebral pathologies and guide further treatment, and potentially invasive ICP monitoring to confirm the diagnosis.

Elevated ICP results in decreased cerebral perfusion pressure, to which the body responds with an increased, not decreased, parasympathetic response. Autoregulatory mechanisms in the CNS result in increased systolic blood pressure to maintain cerebral blood flow. The stimulation of aortic arch baroreceptors then leads to activation of the parasympathetic nervous system and consequent bradycardia.

Patients involved in motor vehicle collisions are at risk for traumatic tension pneumothorax, which causes a rise in intrathoracic pressure. However, tension pneumothorax results in decreased cardiac output leading to hypotension, not hypertension. While this patient does have decreased unilateral breath sounds, which can be a sign of tension pneumothorax, other important findings, such as distended neck veins (due to reduced venous return), tracheal deviation, or tachycardia are absent.

Brainstem compression and the consequent disruption of centers responsible for autonomic function (circulation, respiration) plays an important role in the pathophysiology of Cushing reflex and is likely responsible for this patient's bradycardia, bradypnea, and irregular breathing. Hypertension in ICP does not, however, result from brainstem compression; instead, it is the result of an autoregulatory mechanism that maintains adequate cerebral perfusion pressure.

Vasospasm is a common complication of subarachnoid hemorrhages, that typically appears 3 to 10 days after SAH. Symptoms include new-onset neurological deficits such as speech difficulties, unilateral weakness, or focal seizures, none of which this patient has. Posttraumatic vasospasm is not a cause of systemic hypertension.

question_text: A 27-year-old man is brought to the emergency department because of pain and an inability to move his left shoulder for the past 45 minutes. He says the symptoms started after he had a tonic-clonic seizure. He has autism spectrum disorder and epilepsy. There is no family history of serious illness. His current medications include sodium valproate and levetiracetam. He appears uncomfortable. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows that the left arm is adducted and internally rotated. The anterior left shoulder is flattened with prominence of the coracoid process. The right upper extremity shows no abnormalities. Sensation over the lateral surface of both shoulders is normal. Radial pulses are palpable bilaterally. Oropharyngeal examination shows a tongue laceration. An anteroposterior view x-ray of this patient's left shoulder and arm is most likely to show which of the following?
content_preview: A 27-year-old man is brought to the emergency department because of pain and an inability to move his left shoulder for the past 45 minutes. He says the symptoms started after he had a tonic-clonic seizure. He has autism spectrum disorder and epilepsy. There is no family history of serious illness. His current medications include sodium valproate and levetiracetam. He appears uncomfortable. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows that the left arm is adducted and internally rotated. The anterior left shoulder is flattened with prominence of the coracoid process. The right upper extremity shows no abnormalities. Sensation over the lateral surface of both shoulders is normal. Radial pulses are palpable bilaterally. Oropharyngeal examination shows a tongue laceration. An anteroposterior view x-ray of this patient's left shoulder and arm is most likely to show which of the following?
hint: This patient presents with left shoulder pain after experiencing violent muscle contractions during a tonic-clonic seizure, which can be forceful enough to cause a fracture and/or dislocation. An adducted, internally rotated arm and a flattened shoulder with a prominent coracoid process suggest posterior shoulder dislocation.
learning_objective: Recognize posterior shoulder dislocation, and recall its radiographic appearance.

answers.content: Posterolateral depression fracture of the humeral head
answers.explanation_why: Posterolateral depression fracture of the humeral head, known as Hill-Sachs defect, is caused by impaction of the humeral head on the glenoid rim during anterior shoulder dislocation. In patients with anterior dislocation, the affected arm is typically held in external rotation and slight abduction. Reverse Hill-Sachs defect (a depressed fracture in the anteromedial portion of the humeral head) may be seen in posterior shoulder dislocation.

images.title: Posterior shoulder dislocation
images.description: X-ray of the right shoulder (transcapular view) of a patient with locked posterior dislocationThe humeral head has posteriorly dislocated from the glenoid (green overlay) and the arm is locked in a raised position. An impaction fracture (reverse Hill-Sachs lesion) is seen as a large trough-like defect in the humeral head (red line).A: acromion, C: clavicula, H: humeral head, S: scapula

answers.content: Circular appearance of the humeral head
answers.explanation_why:
Circular appearance of the humeral head, or the light bulb sign, is a diagnostic radiographic sign of posterior shoulder dislocation. As the humeral head dislocates posteriorly, it is forced into internal rotation and appears circular, producing a contour resembling a lightbulb on anteroposterior (AP) view x-ray. Other findings suggestive of posterior shoulder dislocation include the rim sign, trough line, reverse Hill-Sachs defect, and reverse Bankart lesion. Uncomplicated posterior dislocations should be managed conservatively with closed reduction.

AP, scapular Y view, and axillary view x-rays are typically obtained for a suspected posterior shoulder dislocation. However, in some cases, a posterior dislocation may not be detected on AP view, therefore, an axillary lateral view is preferred for diagnosis.

images.title: Lightbulb sign (posterior dislocation of the humerus)
images.description: X-ray shoulder (AP view; left: dislocation; right: post reduction)Internal rotation of the humerus during posterior dislocation produces a contour resembling a lightbulb on the AP radiograph (overlay). In addition, poor congruency of the humeral head with the glenoid is seen in this patient. After reduction, the greater tubercle (tuberosity) is visible laterally and the humeral head is well-aligned with the glenoid fossa.

answers.content: Anteroinferior lesion of the glenoid labrum
answers.explanation_why: Anteroinferior lesion of the glenoid labrum, known as a Bankart lesion, can occur as a result of anterior shoulder dislocation. In patients with anterior dislocation, the affected arm is typically held in external rotation and slight abduction. Reverse Bankart lesions (posteroinferior lesions of the glenoid labrum) may be seen in posterior shoulder dislocation.

images.title: Anterior shoulder dislocation
images.description:
Click on the overlay icon below the taskbar on the left to toggle the overlay on and off.

MRI left shoulder (STIR and T1, coronal plane; PD FS, axial and sagittal plane)On the fat-saturated sequences (STIR and both PD images), there is hyperintensity in the posterolateral humeral head and anteroinferior glenoid rim with corresponding hypointensity on the T1 image. These findings indicate contusion. In addition, a depression in the cortex of the affected region of the humeral head (Hill-Sachs depression fracture) is seen. There is also a fracture through the affected anteroinferior glenoid (osseous or bony Bankart Lesion).This pattern of injury occurs during anterior dislocation as the humeral head externally rotates and descends inferiorly, impacting the anteroinferior glenoid rim with its posterolateral surface.

answers.explanation_why: Midshaft humeral fracture can manifest with severe local pain and limitation of movement. However, proximal (e.g., anatomical neck) rather than midshaft fractures are associated with posterior shoulder dislocation. Moreover, there are no other signs of a midshaft humeral fracture (e.g., swelling, bruising, upper arm deformity, extremity shortening).

answers.content: Superior subluxation of the humeral head
answers.explanation_why: Superior subluxation of the humeral head, also known as high-riding humeral head, can manifest with shoulder pain and a restricted range of motion. However, this is typically found in patients with rotator cuff tears rather than posterior shoulder dislocation.

question_text: A 22-year-old man comes to the physician because of a progressive swelling and pain in his right ring finger for the past 2 days. The pain began while playing football, when his finger got caught in the jersey of another player who forcefully pulled away. Examination shows that the right ring finger is extended. There is pain and swelling at the distal interphalangeal joint. When the patient is asked to make a fist, his right ring finger does not flex at the distal interphalangeal joint. There is no joint laxity. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
content_preview: A 22-year-old man comes to the physician because of a progressive swelling and pain in his right ring finger for the past 2 days. The pain began while playing football, when his finger got caught in the jersey of another player who forcefully pulled away. Examination shows that the right ring finger is extended. There is pain and swelling at the distal interphalangeal joint. When the patient is asked to make a fist, his right ring finger does not flex at the distal interphalangeal joint. There is no joint laxity. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
hint: This patient's injury is a common sports injury caused by forceful hyperextension of the distal interphalangeal joint (DIP).
learning_objective: Recognize rupture of the flexor digitorum profundus tendon.

answers.content: Rupture of the flexor digitorum profundus tendon at its point of insertion
answers.explanation_why: Rupture of the flexor digitorum profundus (FDP) tendon, also known as “jersey finger,” is a common sports injury and most commonly affects the right ring finger. The FDP, along with the flexor digitorum superficialis (FDS), is responsible for finger flexion. The tendons from the FDP muscle run through the carpal tunnel and insert on the palmar side of the distal phalanges of each finger, whereas the FDS tendons insert on the middle phalanx. This patient's inability to flex the DIP combined with the pain over the DIP joint, which is distal to the attachment of the FDS, indicate that he has ruptured his FDP tendon.

images.title: Extensor and flexor tendons of the finger
images.description: The extensor tendons are connected by the intertendinous connection. Annular ligaments stabilize the flexor tendons, which cross one another. The superficial flexor tendons attach to the middle phalanx and the deep flexor tendons to the distal phalanx.

answers.content: Closed fracture of the distal phalanx
answers.explanation_why: The distal phalanges are the most commonly fractured bones in the hand. Distal phalanx fracture is a common sports-related injury, but it would present with pain over the phalanx itself, rather than over one of the interphalangeal joints. While deformity of the distal phalanx and nail is common with distal phalanx fractures, a specific deficit in either flexion or extension over a particular joint would be less common.

answers.content: Rupture of the extensor digitorum tendon at its point of insertion
answers.explanation_why: The extensor digitorum (ED) tendons extend the fingers of the hand. Rupture of the ED tendons leads to a pathology known as “mallet finger” or “baseball finger.” This injury often occurs when a ball hits the tip of the finger and hyperflexes the distal interphalangeal joint (DIP). Patients with this injury would be unable to extend the DIP of the affected finger and would likely have more pain on the dorsal aspect of the finger over the DIP.

images.title: Mallet finger with avulsion fracture
images.description: X-ray finger (lateral view) of a patient with inability to extend finger after traumaAn avulsion fracture of the dorsal aspect of the base of the distal phalanx (green overlay) shows intraarticular extension into the distal interphalangeal (DIP) joint. The injury to the extensor mechanism has resulted in a flexion deformity (indicated by arrow and lines) at the DIP joint (mallet finger).Mallet finger may be an isolated tendinous injury or may occur in combination with an avulsion fracture of the dorsal base of the distal phalanx of a finger.

answers.content: Inflammation of the flexor digitorum profundus tendon sheath
answers.explanation_why: Inflammation of the flexor tendon sheath is a condition known as “trigger finger.” The inflammation causes a stenosing tenosynovitis that leads to a locking or catching sensation during active flexion-extension activity, which can progress to the extent that the digit can only be extended through passive manipulation. Patients may also have a palpable nodule along the axis of the flexor tendon. The cause of trigger finger is unknown but may be related to repeated digital flexion.

answers.content: Slipping of the central band of the extensor digitorum tendon
answers.explanation_why: Slipping or disruption of the central band of the extensor digitorum (ED) tendon is a condition known as Boutonniere deformity. This can be caused by sharp or blunt trauma, such as jamming a finger in a door. It can also be caused by rheumatoid arthritis, in which case the inflammation of the joint space pushes the central band of the ED out of its normal anatomical position. Patients with Boutonniere deformity present with hyperextension of the distal interphalangeal joint and flexion of the proximal interphalangeal joint.
