question_text: A 53-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 3-month history of intermittent severe left neck, shoulder, and arm pain and paresthesias of the left hand. The pain radiates to the radial aspect of her left forearm, thumb, and index finger. She first noticed her symptoms after helping a friend set up a canopy tent. There is no family history of serious illness. She appears healthy. Vital signs are within normal limits. When the patient extends and rotates her head to the left and downward pressure is applied, she reports paresthesias along the radial aspect of her left forearm and thumb. There is weakness when extending the left wrist against resistance. The brachioradialis reflex is 1+ on the left and 2+ on the right. The radial pulse is palpable bilaterally. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
content_preview: A 53-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 3-month history of intermittent severe left neck, shoulder, and arm pain and paresthesias of the left hand. The pain radiates to the radial aspect of her left forearm, thumb, and index finger. She first noticed her symptoms after helping a friend set up a canopy tent. There is no family history of serious illness. She appears healthy. Vital signs are within normal limits. When the patient extends and rotates her head to the left and downward pressure is applied, she reports paresthesias along the radial aspect of her left forearm and thumb. There is weakness when extending the left wrist against resistance. The brachioradialis reflex is 1+ on the left and 2+ on the right. The radial pulse is palpable bilaterally. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
hint: The pattern of symptoms and exam findings indicate that a nerve root has been damaged.
learning_objective: Recognize C5-C6 disk herniation.

answers.explanation_why: Carpal tunnel syndrome (CTS) typically manifests with radiating pain, paresthesias, and weakness. However, these symptoms are generally confined to the hand, specifically the palmar radial aspect, the first three digits, and the radial half of the fourth digit. Symptoms are often worse at night or after repetitive movements of the hand. The patient here does not have this pattern of symptoms. Additionally, a patient with CTS would not have pain in the neck or arm, weakness when extending the wrist (a sign of damage to the radial nerve or its corresponding cervical nerve roots), nor pain with Spurling's test.

images.title: Sensory innervation areas of the peripheral nerves (arm, ventral view)

answers.explanation_why: A patient with degeneration of the spine between vertebral bodies C3 and C4 may experience damage to the C4 nerve root. If the C4 nerve root were damaged, a patient might describe pain and paresthesia in the lateral aspect of the neck or the interscapular region, difficulty elevating the shoulder, and/or dyspnea or shortness of breath, as C4 also innervates the diaphragm muscle.

A patient with syringomyelia would also likely present with radiating radicular pain, paresthesias, diminished reflexes, and weakness of the upper extremities. However, symptoms would be bilateral and usually include decreased sensation in a “cape-like” distribution secondary to the progressive compression and damage to crossing neural fibers of the lateral spinothalamic tract. It would also manifest as flaccid paralysis and muscle atrophy due to damage to the medial part of the corticospinal tract.

A patient with thoracic outlet syndrome (TOS) may present with pain, paresthesias, and weakness of the upper extremity, often following overhead activity. However, rather than causing symptoms to one specific nerve root, TOS usually compresses the lower trunk (C8–T1 nerve roots) of the brachial plexus. In a patient with TOS, Spurling's test would not recreate the patient's symptoms because the test is relatively specific for damage/irritation of the cervical nerve roots rather than the brachial plexus. Furthermore, TOS often affects vascular structures as well; patients present with arm pallor, coldness, decreased pulses, and/or cyanosis of the affected extremity, none of which is present in this patient.

This patient has some characteristic symptoms of amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS). She is in the typical age range for symptom onset (50–70 years) and presents with unilateral paresthesias and weakness. Classically, ALS manifests with symptoms of both upper motor neuron (e.g., increased muscle tone, spasticity, increased reflexes) and lower motor neuron dysfunction (e.g., flaccid paralysis, decreased reflexes, atrophy). Although possible, the majority of the patients do not report sensory dysfunction. This patient has pain and paresthesia that radiates from the neck distally to the arm and hand, indicating selective nerve root compression.

images.title: Clinical features and pathophysiology of amyotrophic lateral sclerosis
images.description: Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis is a neurodegenerative disease that affects the entire motor neuron system (degeneration of the upper motor neuron in the precentral gyrus and lower motor neuron in the brainstem or anterior horn of the spinal cord). The disease most commonly manifests between 50 and 70 years of age, often beginning with unilateral weakness in the hands or feet, which then progresses to the contralateral side (asymmetric limb weakness). However, initial manifestations are highly variable and individuals may have atypical or nonspecific symptoms such as subtle vocal changes. As the disease progresses, most individuals eventually develop one or both of the life-threatening symptoms: respiratory impairment and dysphagia.

answers.explanation_why:
This patient has cervical radiculopathy, most likely from a C5–C6 spinal disk herniation. Her radiating pain and paresthesias are caused by damage and/or irritation of the C6 nerve root, which innervates the radial aspect of the forearm and the thumb. These symptoms are reproduced with Spurling's maneuver, which has a high specificity for cervical radiculopathy. This patient's weakness results from damage to the same nerve root, as C6 provides motor function to the wrist extensors. C6 nerve root damage is also causing the decreased brachioradialis reflex in this patient, as C6 supplies motor function to that muscle.

Other possible causes of the patient's radiculopathy include cervical spondylosis or a tumor causing nerve root compression. Her neurologic symptoms may also be caused by infections that affect the peripheral nervous system such as herpes zoster and Lyme disease. The diagnostic workup includes MRI, which would show a laterally prolapsed disk with surrounding edema in the case of disk herniation.

images.title: Cervical disk herniation
images.description: MRI cervical spine (T2-weighted; sagittal plane) of a patient with symptoms of cervical myelopathyA herniated disk at C5–6 (red overlay) effaces the dural sac and compresses the spinal cord. Hyperintense compression-induced edema (green overlay) is seen within the cord.

question_text: A 44-year-old man is brought to the emergency department 25 minutes after a bicycle accident. He was cycling downhill at approximately 30 miles per hour when he lost control at a curve in the road. He was wearing a helmet and did not lose consciousness. There is no personal history of serious illness and he takes no medications. On arrival, the patient is alert and oriented. He is placed on a backboard with a cervical collar around his neck. Pulse is 96/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 118/78 mm Hg. Examination shows multiple bruises over the forehead and right cheek. The pupils are equal and reactive to light. There is a 2-cm laceration below the right ear. Both ear canals show no abnormalities. The right wrist is swollen and tender; range of motion is limited by pain. The lungs are clear to auscultation. There is mild midline cervical spine tenderness as well as tenderness along the 2^nd and 3^rd ribs on the right side. The abdomen is mildly tender to palpation. Neurological examination shows no focal findings. Focused assessment with sonography for trauma (FAST) shows no free intraperitoneal fluid. Bedside chest x-ray shows a fracture of the 3^rd rib on the right side and no other abnormalities. ECG is normal. Two peripheral venous catheters are placed. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
content_preview: A 44-year-old man is brought to the emergency department 25 minutes after a bicycle accident. He was cycling downhill at approximately 30 miles per hour when he lost control at a curve in the road. He was wearing a helmet and did not lose consciousness. There is no personal history of serious illness and he takes no medications. On arrival, the patient is alert and oriented. He is placed on a backboard with a cervical collar around his neck. Pulse is 96/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 118/78 mm Hg. Examination shows multiple bruises over the forehead and right cheek. The pupils are equal and reactive to light. There is a 2-cm laceration below the right ear. Both ear canals show no abnormalities. The right wrist is swollen and tender; range of motion is limited by pain. The lungs are clear to auscultation. There is mild midline cervical spine tenderness as well as tenderness along the 2nd and 3rd ribs on the right side. The abdomen is mildly tender to palpation. Neurological examination shows no focal findings. Focused assessment with sonography for trauma (FAST) shows no free intraperitoneal fluid. Bedside chest x-ray shows a fracture of the 3rd rib on the right side and no other abnormalities. ECG is normal. Two peripheral venous catheters are placed. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
hint: This patient's midline cervical tenderness raises concern for a possible cervical spine injury.
learning_objective: Recognize the potential for cervical spine injury in a trauma patient, and choose the appropriate imaging modality to rule out injury.

answers.explanation_why: Abdominal CT scan is an important diagnostic tool for patients with blunt abdominal trauma. This patient presents with abdominal tenderness but does not require CT scan at this time because he has no signs of abdominal injury, is hemodynamically stable, and has a negative FAST scan.
X-ray of the neck may be used to initially assess for cervical spine injury, which must be ruled out in this patient, but another test has a higher sensitivity and is preferred whenever available.

Brain imaging may be indicated for patients with blunt head injury to assess for traumatic intracranial lesions (e.g., intracranial hemorrhage). This patient did not lose consciousness, has a normal mental status, no focal neurological deficits, and no risk factors for intracranial hemorrhage (e.g., bleeding disorder, anticoagulation), making a traumatic intracranial lesion unlikely. Additionally, if this patient did require brain imaging, a CT scan of the head without contrast would be the initial test of choice because it is more readily available and results can be rapidly obtained.

answers.content: CT scan of the cervical spine
answers.explanation_why:
In patients with blunt neck trauma, cervical spine imaging is required to rule out injury if at least one of the NEXUS cervical spine criteria is met: focal neurological deficit, posterior midline cervical spinal tenderness, altered consciousness, intoxication, and/or distracting injury. A CT scan of the cervical spine is the preferred imaging modality to rule out cervical spine injury in adult trauma patients.

If none of the NEXUS criteria are present, the risk of cervical spine injury is low, meaning that imaging is not indicated and the cervical collar can be removed.

An x-ray of the wrist can be used to rule out an underlying fracture. Although this patient has signs of potential wrist fracture (wrist pain, tenderness, limited range of motion), more severe injuries must be ruled out first. The patient's wrist will eventually require imaging and treatment. In trauma resuscitation, management of nonlethal injuries such as a wrist fracture is often deferred until all life threats are stabilized. Until that time, fractured limbs are often splinted for patient comfort.

question_text: A 23-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department 20 minutes after being involved in a high-speed motor vehicle collision where she was the unrestrained driver. She was found thrown across the dashboard of the car. On arrival, she appears lethargic. She is unable to provide a history. Her pulse is 133/min, respirations are 23/min, and blood pressure is 82/54 mm Hg. Examination shows a 2-cm laceration over the right upper extremity. There are multiple bruises over the chest and abdomen. The pupils are equal and reactive to light. The lungs are clear to auscultation. Cardiac examination shows no abnormalities. The abdomen is soft and not distended. Neurologic examination shows no focal findings. An intravenous infusion of 0.9% saline infusion is begun. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
content_preview: A 23-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department 20 minutes after being involved in a high-speed motor vehicle collision where she was the unrestrained driver. She was found thrown across the dashboard of the car. On arrival, she appears lethargic. She is unable to provide a history. Her pulse is 133/min, respirations are 23/min, and blood pressure is 82/54 mm Hg. Examination shows a 2-cm laceration over the right upper extremity. There are multiple bruises over the chest and abdomen. The pupils are equal and reactive to light. The lungs are clear to auscultation. Cardiac examination shows no abnormalities. The abdomen is soft and not distended. Neurologic examination shows no focal findings. An intravenous infusion of 0.9% saline infusion is begun. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
hint: Intraabdominal bleeding should be ruled out in an unstable trauma patient initially with a noninvasive, easily accessible imaging modality.
learning_objective: Choose the most appropriate initial imaging modality for a hemodynamically unstable trauma patient.

answers.explanation_why: Observation is inappropriate in the management of this patient, who presents after blunt abdominal trauma with altered mental status, multiple bruises, and unstable vital signs. This patient needs urgent workup and treatment for the cause of her hemodynamic instability.

Exploratory laparotomy is the first step in managing blunt abdominal trauma if signs of peritoneal irritation are present. However, this patient has no signs of peritoneal irritation, and other diagnostic approaches must first be considered to investigate why this patient is hemodynamically unstable. In the case that no other diagnostic resources are readily available, exploratory laparotomy should be performed if there is high clinical suspicion of intraperitoneal hemorrhage.

A CT scan of the abdomen would not be the next best step for managing this unstable patient. Although a CT scan can also show the presence of a hemoperitoneum, it takes time and unnecessarily exposes the patient to radiation when other more rapid diagnostic studies are available.

Focused Assessment with Sonography for Trauma (FAST) is an essential component of management for blunt abdominal trauma. This patient presents after a motor vehicle collision and is hemodynamically unstable, which is concerning for intraperitoneal bleeding. The FAST exam screens for free fluid, especially blood, in the right upper quadrant, left upper quadrant, pericardial space, and pelvis.

Diagnostic peritoneal lavage (DPL) would not be the most appropriate next step because other less invasive and more readily available diagnostic studies should be available to assess for intraabdominal bleeding. A DPL can be considered when other diagnostic studies are unavailable or equivocal.

question_text: A 52-year-old man is brought to the emergency department 30 minutes after he was involved in a high-speed motor vehicle collision. He was the unrestrained driver. On arrival, he is lethargic. His pulse is 112/min, respirations are 10/min and irregular, and blood pressure is 94/60 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 91%. The pupils are equal and react sluggishly to light. He withdraws his extremities to pain. There are multiple bruises over his face, chest, and abdomen. Breath sounds are decreased over the left lung base. Two large bore peripheral venous catheters are inserted, and 0.9% saline infusion is begun. Rapid sequence intubation is initiated, and orotracheal intubation via direct laryngoscopy is attempted three times without success. A laryngeal mask airway insertion also fails. Despite continuous bag-valve-mask ventilation, pulse oximetry shows an oxygen saturation of 84%. The patient has no advance directive, and family members have not arrived. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
content_preview: A 52-year-old man is brought to the emergency department 30 minutes after he was involved in a high-speed motor vehicle collision. He was the unrestrained driver. On arrival, he is lethargic. His pulse is 112/min, respirations are 10/min and irregular, and blood pressure is 94/60 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 91%. The pupils are equal and react sluggishly to light. He withdraws his extremities to pain. There are multiple bruises over his face, chest, and abdomen. Breath sounds are decreased over the left lung base. Two large bore peripheral venous catheters are inserted, and 0.9% saline infusion is begun. Rapid sequence intubation is initiated, and orotracheal intubation via direct laryngoscopy is attempted three times without success. A laryngeal mask airway insertion also fails. Despite continuous bag-valve-mask ventilation, pulse oximetry shows an oxygen saturation of 84%. The patient has no advance directive, and family members have not arrived. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
hint: This patient is in a cannot intubate-cannot ventilate (CICV) scenario with increasing hypoxemia.
learning_objective: Recognize a cannot intubate-cannot ventilate scenario, and choose the most appropriate emergency airway management.

answers.explanation_why: Video laryngoscopy allows for visualization of the oropharynx and is commonly used to facilitate orotracheal intubation in patients with a difficult airway. Although video laryngoscopy could have been used earlier in the management of this patient, several intubation attempts have been unsuccessful. Furthermore, his oxygen saturation is acutely dropping despite attempts at maintaining ventilation and oxygenation through bag-valve and laryngeal masks. If establishing an alternative airway via video laryngoscopy is unsuccessful, hypoxic brain injury may occur. Another step is more appropriate in an emergency setting.

This patient has just suffered major trauma, and his preferred code status is unknown. It would be highly inappropriate to change his code status to comfort measures only in the absence of an advance directive, a health care proxy, and before all possible treatment modalities have been exhausted.

Although an emergency tracheostomy may be performed in a CICV scenario, this approach is usually not the first-line option because it is more complex and time-consuming, and causes more bleeding than other emergency surgical airway procedures.

A nasotracheal approach can be attempted to achieve intubation in patients with a difficult airway and limited oral access (e.g., due to oropharyngeal obstruction). However, this technique is usually performed electively in the operating room under direct visualization of the pharynx with laryngoscopy. Nasopharyngeal intubation is time-consuming and is therefore inappropriate in a CICV scenario with declining oxygen saturation, which requires an emergency airway.

This patient has just experienced major trauma and presents with signs of respiratory distress (respiratory rate of 10/min, oxygen saturation of 84%), neurological compromise (lethargy, sluggish pupils), and a compromised airway (decreased breath sounds over left hemithorax, rapid decrease in oxygen saturation). After unsuccessful attempts at securing the airway and ventilation via orotracheal intubation, laryngeal mask placement, and bag-mask ventilation, immediate action is required to prevent hypoxia. A surgical airway with cricothyrotomy should be established in patients who cannot be intubated and oxygenated. Cricothyrotomy is the preferred method in an emergency when rapid airway control is needed, especially in cases where intubation is unsuccessful, and other supraglottic airway devices are ineffective.

images.title: Cricothyroidotomy
images.description: Diagram showing an emergency cricothyroidotomy, which is typically performed if attempts to intubate have been unsuccessful. An incision is made through the cricothyroid membrane, and a cuffed endotracheal tube is inserted through the incision site. Cricothyroidotomy allows ventilation of the patient until a more definitive airway is placed.

question_text: A 33-year-old man is brought to the emergency department 20 minutes after losing control of his bicycle and colliding with a parked car. He was thrown over the handlebars and hit the ground. He reports that he was wearing a helmet and that he did not lose consciousness. He has mild pain in his legs and on his right side but says that he feels well otherwise. On arrival, he is alert and oriented. His pulse is 90/min, respirations are 17/min, and blood pressure is 110/76 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 97%. The pupils are equal and reactive to light. There are a few bruises over his right chest, flank, and lower extremities. The lungs are clear to auscultation. Cardiac examination shows no abnormalities. The abdomen is soft and nontender; there is tenderness to palpation over the right thorax. There is no pelvic instability. The external genitalia appear normal. Complete blood count, prothrombin time, and serum concentrations of glucose, creatinine, and electrolytes are within the reference ranges. A voided urine specimen is clear. Microscopic examination of the urine shows 85 RBCs/hpf. A focused assessment with sonography for trauma shows no free intra-abdominal fluid. An x-ray of the chest shows a fracture of the 11^th rib on the right side. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
content_preview: A 33-year-old man is brought to the emergency department 20 minutes after losing control of his bicycle and colliding with a parked car. He was thrown over the handlebars and hit the ground. He reports that he was wearing a helmet and that he did not lose consciousness. He has mild pain in his legs and on his right side but says that he feels well otherwise. On arrival, he is alert and oriented. His pulse is 90/min, respirations are 17/min, and blood pressure is 110/76 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 97%. The pupils are equal and reactive to light. There are a few bruises over his right chest, flank, and lower extremities. The lungs are clear to auscultation. Cardiac examination shows no abnormalities. The abdomen is soft and nontender; there is tenderness to palpation over the right thorax. There is no pelvic instability. The external genitalia appear normal. Complete blood count, prothrombin time, and serum concentrations of glucose, creatinine, and electrolytes are within the reference ranges. A voided urine specimen is clear. Microscopic examination of the urine shows 85 RBCs/hpf. A focused assessment with sonography for trauma shows no free intra-abdominal fluid. An x-ray of the chest shows a fracture of the 11th rib on the right side. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
hint: The combination of a fracture of the 11^th rib on the right side and microscopic hematuria in a patient with a history of blunt abdominal trauma (BAT) should raise concern for renal injury.
learning_objective: Recognize suspected renal trauma in the setting of blunt abdominal trauma, and choose the most appropriate diagnostic imaging.

answers.explanation_why: Placement of a suprapubic catheter is indicated to relieve and prevent urinary retention. Indications of suprapubic catheter placement include urethral injuries requiring surgical repair, urethral obstruction, acute prostatitis, or prostate cancer in which transurethral catheterization is contraindicated or technically not possible. Microscopic hematuria, as seen in this patient, can be a sign of a mild urethral injury, but it would need to be confirmed before a suprapubic catheterization is considered. In addition, the patient has no signs of urinary retention such as abdominal pain or a palpable suprapubic mass.

Intravenous pyelography (IVP) is used for the evaluation of possible renal disease, detection of renal stones, or to assess potential contrast extravasation if contrast-enhanced CT images are not diagnostic. IVP was formerly a preferred imaging modality for renal trauma; however, a different test has supplanted IVP as the imaging modality of choice.

Exploratory laparotomy after BAT is indicated in hemodynamically unstable patients with signs of peritonitis and hemodynamically stable patients with evidence of free intra-abdominal fluid on imaging. This patient is hemodynamically stable and focused assessment with sonography for trauma is normal.

answers.content: CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis
answers.explanation_why: In patients with BAT, a CT scan with contrast of the abdomen and pelvis is the imaging modality of choice for evaluating abdominal injuries, including those of the genitourinary tract. BAT is a major cause of mortality and requires a high degree of clinical suspicion, even if a patient's initial presentation does not suggest any significant intra-abdominal injury. This patient with suspected renal trauma requires a CT scan with contrast of the abdomen and pelvis to establish the diagnosis and further assess the degree of trauma.

Retrograde urethrocystography is used to evaluate the lower genitourinary tract and urinary bladder. It is indicated in patients with gross hematuria or blood at the urethral meatus following a pelvic fracture. This patient, however, only has microscopic hematuria and no signs of a pelvic fracture. Therefore, a retrograde urethrocystography is not indicated at this time.

Observation and follow-up may be appropriate in patients who are hemodynamically stable and have no signs of traumatic injury. Although mild microscopic hematuria is common following BAT and does not necessarily indicate genitourinary injury, this patient has evidence of a right rib fracture, which is concerning for a renal injury. Therefore, observation and follow-up would not be an appropriate next step.

question_text: A 5-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department for pain and swelling in the right elbow 45 minutes after he fell while playing on the monkey bars during recess. He has been unable to move his right elbow since the fall. Examination shows ecchymosis, swelling, and tenderness of the right elbow; range of motion is limited by pain. An x-ray of the right arm is shown. This patient is at greatest risk for which of the following complications?
content_preview: A 5-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department for pain and swelling in the right elbow 45 minutes after he fell while playing on the monkey bars during recess. He has been unable to move his right elbow since the fall. Examination shows ecchymosis, swelling, and tenderness of the right elbow; range of motion is limited by pain. An x-ray of the right arm is shown. This patient is at greatest risk for which of the following complications?
hint: The x-ray shows a displaced supracondylar humerus fracture, the most common elbow fracture in children.
learning_objective: Recognize supracondylar humerus fracture, and recall its vascular complications.

answers.explanation_why: Patients with open fractures are vulnerable to polymicrobial infection. Wound management for open fractures routinely involves irrigation and prophylactic antibiotics. Although this patient's fracture is displaced, it is closed. Therefore, he is unlikely to sustain a polymicrobial infection.

Distal humerus fractures, including supracondylar fractures, can lead to brachial artery injury either by entrapping or directly injuring the artery. Even if the brachial artery is not directly affected, local trauma can also induce brachial artery vasospasm, thus compromising arterial blood flow. Impaired brachial artery flow affects the distal structures supplied by this artery, so patients can have an absent or diminished radial pulse and delayed capillary refill in the affected arm. Most patients do not have a direct injury of the artery and treatment of the fracture (internal fixation) usually reduces entrapment and restores perfusion; vascular surgery is rarely needed.

images.title: Anatomical structures at risk in humerus fractures
images.description: Depending on the location of humerus fractures, different anatomical structures are at risk.Illustration indicates structures at lower risk of injury in parentheses.

answers.explanation_why: Impaired arm abduction can occur following axillary nerve injuries, which are associated with proximal humerus fracture. In contrast, this patient has a distal humerus fracture. Distal fractures can be associated with radial, ulnar, and/or median nerve injuries, but the axillary nerve is usually not injured in distal fractures (see “Humerus fracture nerve palsies” table). Nerve injuries in patients with distal humerus fractures are typically neurapraxias and most patients recover fully within 3 months.

answers.content: Avascular necrosis of the humeral head
answers.explanation_why: The humeral head is supplied by the axillary artery through the circumflex humeral arteries. Injury to these arteries most commonly occurs in patients with proximal humerus fractures (especially at the level of the surgical neck) and can lead to avascular necrosis. This patient has a distal humerus fracture, which is unlikely to injure the axillary artery.

Adhesive capsulitis (i.e., frozen shoulder) is characterized by pain, stiffness, and decreased range of motion in the shoulder joint and can occur following humeral fractures. However, adhesive capsulitis typically results from postoperative shoulder immobility or from fractures to the proximal humerus. This patient has a distal humerus fracture, which is unlikely to cause frozen shoulder.

images.title: Extension-type supracondylar humeral fracture
images.description: X-ray elbow (lateral view) of a child with a history of recent traumaA comminuted supracondylar fracture of the distal humerus (H) shows posterior displacement of the distal fragment and growth plate involvement (white arrow). Joint effusion is present, with elevation of the lucent posterior fat pad (white arrowheads).H: humerus; R: radius; U: ulna

question_text: A 38-year-old man is brought to the emergency department 35 minutes after he sustained a gunshot wound to the right thigh. He has type 1 diabetes mellitus. On arrival, his pulse is 105/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 115/69 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 98%. An entrance wound is seen on the anteromedial surface of the right thigh 2 cm below the inguinal ligament; there is no active bleeding from the wound and no exit wound. No bruit or thrill is heard on auscultation. The pedal pulse is diminished on the right side compared to the left, and the ankle-brachial index is 0.7 for the right side. The abdomen is soft and nontender. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial step in management?
content_preview: A 38-year-old man is brought to the emergency department 35 minutes after he sustained a gunshot wound to the right thigh. He has type 1 diabetes mellitus. On arrival, his pulse is 105/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 115/69 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 98%. An entrance wound is seen on the anteromedial surface of the right thigh 2 cm below the inguinal ligament; there is no active bleeding from the wound and no exit wound. No bruit or thrill is heard on auscultation. The pedal pulse is diminished on the right side compared to the left, and the ankle-brachial index is 0.7 for the right side. The abdomen is soft and nontender. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial step in management?
hint: This hemodynamically stable patient presents with signs of vascular injury (diminished pedal pulse, ankle-brachial index < 0.9) due to penetrating trauma to the extremities, which requires further evaluation.
learning_objective: Recognize vascular injury due to penetrating trauma in a hemodynamically stable patient with renal insufficiency, and choose the most appropriate initial diagnostic study.

answers.explanation_why:
In hemodynamically stable patients with suspected vascular injury but no hard signs of arterial injury, emergency imaging is indicated. CT angiography is the preferred diagnostic study. Alternatively, duplex ultrasound can be used if there are contraindications for iodinated radiocontrast.

Patients who present with hard signs of extremity vascular injury require urgent surgical repair.

In patients with unknown or insufficient tetanus and diphtheria immunization, appropriate tetanus prophylaxis with tetanus toxoid should be administered as soon as possible following an acute injury or wound. Tetanus immunoglobulin should also be administered in unvaccinated patients who have sustained a wound that might be dirty or contaminated. Wounds should be cleaned thoroughly and necrotic tissue should be debrided. Although this patient should be asked about his tetanus immunization history, potential vascular injury should be investigated first.

Patients who present with hard signs of extremity vascular injury (e.g., active hemorrhage, expanding or pulsatile hematoma, bruit or thrill over the wound) require urgent surgical repair. This patient meets none of the criteria and is hemodynamically stable; therefore, he should undergo further diagnostic testing before surgical repair is considered.

Patients with acute compartment syndrome require urgent fasciotomy to relieve the pressure and prevent tissue necrosis. Although gunshot wounds may result in compartment syndrome due to inflammation, edema, or hematoma formation, this patient does not complain of tightness or swelling in his lower extremity. Signs of compartment syndrome, such as size disparity between the two lower extremities or paresthesia, are also not revealed in the physical examination.
While digital subtraction angiography (DSA) can be used to assess a suspected arterial vascular injury, other less invasive and equally effective diagnostic tests are widely available.

question_text: A 43-year-old man is brought to the emergency department 40 minutes after falling off a 3-m (10-ft) ladder. He has severe pain and swelling of his right ankle and is unable to walk. He did not lose consciousness after the fall. He has no nausea. He appears uncomfortable. His temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 98/min, respirations are 16/min, and blood pressure is 110/80 mm Hg. He is alert and oriented to person, place, and time. Examination shows multiple abrasions over both lower extremities. There is swelling and tenderness of the right ankle; range of motion is limited by pain. Dorsalis pedis and tibialis posterior pulses are palpable bilaterally. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. An x-ray of the ankle shows an extra-articular calcaneal fracture. Intravenous analgesia is administered. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
content_preview: A 43-year-old man is brought to the emergency department 40 minutes after falling off a 3-m (10-ft) ladder. He has severe pain and swelling of his right ankle and is unable to walk. He did not lose consciousness after the fall. He has no nausea. He appears uncomfortable. His temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 98/min, respirations are 16/min, and blood pressure is 110/80 mm Hg. He is alert and oriented to person, place, and time. Examination shows multiple abrasions over both lower extremities. There is swelling and tenderness of the right ankle; range of motion is limited by pain. Dorsalis pedis and tibialis posterior pulses are palpable bilaterally. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. An x-ray of the ankle shows an extra-articular calcaneal fracture. Intravenous analgesia is administered. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
hint: 10–15% of calcaneal fractures are associated with another pathology due to the axial transmission of force.
learning_objective: Recognize the association of calcaneal fractures with high-energy trauma, and choose the most appropriate diagnostic test to rule out concurrent injuries.

answers.explanation_why: Although an MRI might provide more information about the fracture (which may be useful for deciding on a treatment approach, especially in the case of an intra-articular fracture) and any associated soft tissue damage, there is a different intervention that should take precedence.
This patient sustained a high-energy trauma injury, which warrants further study and treatment.
A long leg cast may be indicated for some fractures, particularly of the distal femur, patella, tibia, and/or fibula, none of which are the case in this patient.
Open reduction and internal fixation are indicated in cases of displaced, open, or pathologic fractures, or fractures involving neurovascular compromise, none of which are the case in this patient.

A CT scan of the spine to rule out spinal injury is indicated for a patient with any of the following: high-energy trauma, distracting injury, intoxication, focal neurological deficit, altered mental status, or spinal tenderness. A fall from a height ≥ 3 m (≥ 10 ft) is an example of high-energy trauma and this patient's calcaneal fracture is a distracting injury. Following a fall from a height, the patients can develop axial loading injuries, such as vertebral compression fractures or burst fractures.

question_text: A 22-year-old man is brought to the emergency department 30 minutes after being involved in a high-speed motor vehicle collision in which he was an unrestrained driver. After extrication, he had severe upper back pain and was unable to move his legs. On arrival, he is alert and fully oriented. His neck is immobilized in a cervical collar. His pulse is 58/min, respirations are 17/min and regular, and blood pressure is 89/58 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 98%. He has flaccid paralysis and absent reflexes in the lower extremities. Sensory examination shows absent sensation below the level of the nipples including absent sensation in the perianal region. Cardiopulmonary examination shows no abnormalities. The abdomen is soft. Rectal examination discloses no discernable resting tone and squeezing of the glans penis does not elicit anal sphincter contraction. The remainder of the examination, including a focused assessment with sonography for trauma, shows no abnormalities. A whole-body CT scan reveals an isolated burst fracture of the T3 vertebra with no evidence of facet injury. In addition to intravenous fluid therapy, which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
content_preview: A 22-year-old man is brought to the emergency department 30 minutes after being involved in a high-speed motor vehicle collision in which he was an unrestrained driver. After extrication, he had severe upper back pain and was unable to move his legs. On arrival, he is alert and fully oriented. His neck is immobilized in a cervical collar. His pulse is 58/min, respirations are 17/min and regular, and blood pressure is 89/58 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 98%. He has flaccid paralysis and absent reflexes in the lower extremities. Sensory examination shows absent sensation below the level of the nipples including absent sensation in the perianal region. Cardiopulmonary examination shows no abnormalities. The abdomen is soft. Rectal examination discloses no discernable resting tone and squeezing of the glans penis does not elicit anal sphincter contraction. The remainder of the examination, including a focused assessment with sonography for trauma, shows no abnormalities. A whole-body CT scan reveals an isolated burst fracture of the T3 vertebra with no evidence of facet injury. In addition to intravenous fluid therapy, which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
hint: This patient presents with spinal shock (flaccid, areflexic paralysis, anesthesia below the level of the injury) and neurogenic shock (bradycardia, hypotension) due to spinal cord injury (SCI). Absent sacral sparing in the spinal shock phase correlates with a high degree of autonomic dysfunction.
learning_objective: Recognize spinal shock and neurogenic shock due to spinal cord injury, and choose the most appropriate initial management.

answers.explanation_why:
Patients with spinal shock and absent sacral sparing will have impaired micturition reflexes (often with detrusor-sphincter dyssynergia) and no bladder-filling sensation. This may result in acute urinary retention with painless bladder distension and subsequent complications (e.g., hydronephrosis, worsening bradycardia from bladder distention, bladder rupture). Therefore, the most appropriate next step in management is the placement of a Foley catheter. Urinary catheterization also enables the assessment of fluid balance in patients who require careful intravenous fluid therapy for the management of neurogenic shock. When fluid therapy is no longer necessary, the indwelling catheter should be replaced by an intermittent catheter (ideally 3–4 days after the injury) to decrease the risk of urinary tract infection. Intermittent catheterization to decompress the bladder also prevents autonomic dysreflexia, a late complication of SCI above T6.

Other important management steps in the management of SCI include venous thromboembolism prophylaxis, decubitus ulcer prophylaxis, pain control, and bowel care. Patients with SCI should undergo repeated, thorough neurological examinations with documentation of the findings. The return of any neurological function in the sacral segments after spinal shock resolves indicates an incomplete SCI and predicts the return of some degree of bowel and bladder control. The persistence of complete neurological impairment in the sacral segments after spinal shock resolves indicates complete SCI and a poor prognosis.

Routine use of steroids (e.g., dexamethasone) is not recommended for patients with acute nonpenetrating spinal cord injury. Although intravenous methylprednisolone was previously indicated, recent studies have shown that it does not improve neurological recovery and increases the risk of gastrointestinal hemorrhage and respiratory infection.

There is no consensus on the timing of surgical spine stabilization for a patient with vertebral column injury and SCI. Urgent surgical stabilization of the spine is typically performed if the patient has unstable injuries (e.g., bilateral facet dislocation), especially if the injury cannot be treated with closed reduction, or if the patient has progressively worsening neurological deficits. For a patient in neurogenic shock, medical management to limit spinal cord ischemia from hypoperfusion is more important before surgery is performed.

Myelography is an imaging technique that uses fluoroscopy to examine the meninges, nerve roots, and spinal cord by injecting a radiopaque dye into the spinal canal. While myelography can be used to evaluate the spinal canal when MRI is contraindicated or unavailable, it is not routinely recommended for the management of SCI.

Patients who have SCI at T6 and above are often bradycardic, as seen here. Phenylephrine can cause reflex bradycardia and should be avoided in patients who are already bradycardic. In patients with hypotension and bradycardia, atropine or vasopressors with additional inotropic and chronotropic effects (e.g., dopamine, norepinephrine) should be used. In patients with SCI, phenylephrine can be used if the SCI level is at T6 or below because bradycardia is less likely with such an injury.

answers.content: Rapid sequence intubation with manual inline stabilization
answers.explanation_why: In patients with SCI, rapid sequence intubation (RSI) for emergency airway management can be performed with manual inline stabilization of the head and neck. Intubation is performed to treat airway obstruction, to protect the airway (e.g., if the patient has or is expected to develop an altered mental status), or to allow for invasive mechanical ventilation in patients with respiratory failure. Patients are at risk of respiratory failure due to diaphragm paralysis if the SCI is at the level of C5 or above. A different step takes precedence for this patient who has an isolated spinal cord injury at the T3 vertebral level and is alert and oriented without evidence of respiratory failure.

question_text: Four days after having been admitted to the hospital for a pulmonary contusion and whiplash injury sustained in a motor vehicle collision, a 66-year-old woman complains of severe pain in her right flank, abdominal bloating, and nausea. She has also vomited twice in the past 2 hours. Her musculoskeletal pain due to the motor vehicle collision had been well controlled with acetaminophen every 6 hours but the medication provides no relief for the flank pain. She underwent umbilical hernia repair surgery 2 years ago. Her temperature is 36.5°C (97.7°F), pulse is 99/min, respirations are 17/min, and blood pressure is 102/72 mm Hg. After administration of 0.5 L of crystalloid fluids, blood pressure improves to 118/79 mm Hg. Multiple ecchymoses are present over the anterior abdominal wall in a pattern that follows the course of a seatbelt and there are new ecchymoses over the flanks bilaterally. Bowel sounds are absent. There is tenderness to palpation in all four quadrants with voluntary guarding. Her hemoglobin is 7.9 g/dL, leukocyte count is 8500/mm^3, platelet count is 350,000/mm^3, prothrombin time is 11 seconds, and activated partial thromboplastin time is 33 seconds. An x-ray of the abdomen shows obliteration of the right psoas shadow, dilated bowel loops, and uniform distribution of gas in the small bowel, colon, and rectum without air-fluid levels. Which of the following is the most likely explanation for this patient's symptoms?
content_preview: Four days after having been admitted to the hospital for a pulmonary contusion and whiplash injury sustained in a motor vehicle collision, a 66-year-old woman complains of severe pain in her right flank, abdominal bloating, and nausea. She has also vomited twice in the past 2 hours. Her musculoskeletal pain due to the motor vehicle collision had been well controlled with acetaminophen every 6 hours but the medication provides no relief for the flank pain. She underwent umbilical hernia repair surgery 2 years ago. Her temperature is 36.5°C (97.7°F), pulse is 99/min, respirations are 17/min, and blood pressure is 102/72 mm Hg. After administration of 0.5 L of crystalloid fluids, blood pressure improves to 118/79 mm Hg. Multiple ecchymoses are present over the anterior abdominal wall in a pattern that follows the course of a seatbelt and there are new ecchymoses over the flanks bilaterally. Bowel sounds are absent. There is tenderness to palpation in all four quadrants with voluntary guarding. Her hemoglobin is 7.9 g/dL, leukocyte count is 8500/mm3, platelet count is 350,000/mm3, prothrombin time is 11 seconds, and activated partial thromboplastin time is 33 seconds. An x-ray of the abdomen shows obliteration of the right psoas shadow, dilated bowel loops, and uniform distribution of gas in the small bowel, colon, and rectum without air-fluid levels. Which of the following is the most likely explanation for this patient's symptoms?
hint: The presence of acute nausea, vomiting, bloating, absent bowel sounds, and dilated bowel loops with a uniform gas pattern is diagnostic of paralytic ileus.
learning_objective: Recognize retroperitoneal hemorrhage.

answers.explanation_why: Small bowel perforation causes acute abdominal pain and may be associated with paralytic ileus. However, small bowel perforation would cause free intraperitoneal air on abdominal x-ray (70% of cases) and it does not explain unilateral obliteration of the psoas muscle shadow, flank pain, or flank bruising.

images.title: Pneumoperitoneum and Pneumoretroperitoneum
images.description: X-ray abdomen (AP erect view) and chest (PA and lateral views)Multiple air-fluid levels are seen in the colon and small bowel (examples indicated by black lines). Some dilated segments of left colon are seen and gas is present in the peritoneal space as a result of bowel perforation. Gas is primarily located beneath the diaphragms (green overlay) because of the erect positioning of the patient. Additional gas has dissected into the retroperitoneum (examples indicated by red overlay) and is visible as linear collections parallel to the spine.

answers.explanation_why: Intraabdominal adhesions are a common cause of mechanical bowel obstruction, especially in patients with a history of intraperitoneal surgery. Mechanical bowel obstruction manifests with acute obstructive symptoms (bloating, nausea, vomiting) as in this patient, but hyperactive bowel sounds and air-fluid levels (possibly with a transition point) on x-ray would be expected in mechanical obstruction.

images.title: Mechanical small bowel obstruction
images.description: X-ray abdomen (AP view; erect position)Multiple air-fluid levels (green overlay) are visible in the mid-abdomen. The opaque appearance of the pelvis (red overlay) is due to fluid-filled loops of small bowel. There is a paucity of gas in the colon, and an air-fluid level is present in the dilated stomach (S).Erect and decubitus radiographs can reveal air-fluid levels that are not identifiable on supine radiographs. Air-fluid levels can indicate ileus or mechanical obstruction. A lack of distal gas and air-fluid levels at different heights in the same bowel loop (differential air-fluid levels) suggest obstruction.

answers.explanation_why: Pain medications (especially opioids) can cause paralytic ileus. Opioids bind the μ receptor in the gut, which directly inhibits gut motility. However, this patient's pain was controlled with acetaminophen only, which does not cause paralytic ileus.

Sigmoid volvulus is a cause of mechanical bowel obstruction, particularly in older patients such as this one. Mechanical bowel obstruction presents with acute obstructive symptoms (bloating, nausea, vomiting) as in this patient, but hyperactive bowel sounds and air-fluid levels (possibly with a transition point) would be expected in mechanical obstruction. Sigmoid volvulus also has coffee bean sign on x-ray in 60% of patients.

images.title: Coffee bean sign in sigmoid volvulus
images.description: X-ray abdomen (left lateral decubitus view)Gaseous distention of a closed loop of sigmoid colon (red overlay) has caused apposition of the medial walls (green lines). The resultant cleft-like configuration, in conjunction with the lateral walls of the loop, produces an appearance reminiscent of a coffee bean (illustration).The coffee bean sign (also called “kidney-bean sign” or “bent-inner-tube sign”) is a classic conventional radiographic finding of sigmoid volvulus.Dashed line: air-fluid level

answers.explanation_why: Spinal cord injury can cause paralytic ileus. This patient suffered whiplash injury from her accident, which can be associated with mild neurologic injury and signs such as numbness and weakness. However, neurologic injury from whiplash is not significant enough to cause ileus and this patient has had no other evidence of severe neurologic injury (e.g., significant weakness). Significant spinal cord damage is, therefore, unlikely.

Trauma patients may develop paralytic ileus for a variety of reasons (e.g., treatment with opioids). The association of this patient's ileus with bilateral flank pain, seatbelt sign, Grey Turner sign, obliteration of the psoas outline on x-ray, and fluid-responsive hemodynamic changes make trauma-associated retroperitoneal hemorrhage the most likely cause of symptoms here.

The most appropriate next step in the management of uncomplicated paralytic ileus is to make the patient NPO, place a nasogastric tube for decompression, and provide IV fluid (and possibly blood product) resuscitation. Hemodynamic status must also be monitored closely for signs of ongoing or recurrent retroperitoneal hemorrhage.

Acute mesenteric ischemia frequently presents as acute abdominal pain, distention, nausea, and vomiting. Acute mesenteric ischemia can occur as a complication of abdominal trauma and can cause paralytic ileus. However, acute mesenteric ischemia does not cause flank pain or flank bruising.

question_text: A 37-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department 15 minutes after falling down a flight of stairs. On arrival, she has shortness of breath, right-sided chest pain, right upper quadrant abdominal pain, and right shoulder pain. She is otherwise healthy. She takes no medications. She appears pale. Her temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 115/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 85/45 mm Hg. Examination shows several ecchymoses over the right chest. There is tenderness to palpation over the right chest wall and right upper quadrant of the abdomen. Bowel sounds are normal. Cardiopulmonary examination shows no abnormalities. Neck veins are flat. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
content_preview: A 37-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department 15 minutes after falling down a flight of stairs. On arrival, she has shortness of breath, right-sided chest pain, right upper quadrant abdominal pain, and right shoulder pain. She is otherwise healthy. She takes no medications. She appears pale. Her temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 115/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 85/45 mm Hg. Examination shows several ecchymoses over the right chest. There is tenderness to palpation over the right chest wall and right upper quadrant of the abdomen. Bowel sounds are normal. Cardiopulmonary examination shows no abnormalities. Neck veins are flat. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
hint: This patient's injury involves one of the most commonly injured organs following blunt trauma.
learning_objective: Recognize liver hematoma following blunt trauma.

answers.explanation_why: The spleen is one of the most commonly injured organs during blunt abdominal trauma. Severe hemorrhage associated with splenic laceration often results in tachycardia and hypotension. However, rather than right-sided pain, patients with splenic injury usually experience left-sided abdominal pain and left shoulder pain (Kehr sign).

Small bowel perforation is a possible sequela of blunt abdominal trauma such as this patient's fall. While penetrating trauma may lead to immediate bowel injury and intestinal leakage, blunt abdominal trauma typically results in necrosis and delayed perforation after several days, making the diagnosis unlikely in this patient.

Pneumothorax may occur secondary to blunt chest trauma such as falls. It manifests with dyspnea and ipsilateral chest pain, as well as hemodynamic instability in the case of tension pneumothorax (due to mediastinal compression and decreased venous return). However, the physical examination in patients with pneumothorax typically shows reduced or absent breath sounds over the affected lung. Tension pneumothorax would also manifest with jugular venous distention rather than the flat neck veins seen in this patient.

A liver hematoma commonly results from blunt abdominal trauma such as falls. This patient has the typical features of liver injury, including ecchymoses over the right chest, pain in the right upper quadrant and the right chest, referred pain to the right shoulder (due to diaphragmatic irritation), and hemodynamic instability. After stabilizing this patient, a focused assessment with sonography in trauma (FAST) should be performed to assess for free fluid in the abdomen.

Duodenal hematoma is a common injury in children who suffer blunt abdominal trauma. In children, the abdominal wall is thinner and less developed, and inner organs, especially the duodenum, take up a larger portion of the body relative to height, making them more prone to injury. Typical symptoms, such as epigastric pain, bilious emesis, and an upper abdominal mass, result from the associated small bowel obstruction. The absence of these symptoms in combination with the patient's age makes this diagnosis less likely.

question_text: A previously healthy 16-month-old boy is brought to the emergency department after being injured by a dresser falling on him. When the child tried to pull himself up on the dresser, it tipped and fell on his chest and abdomen. He had been awake and agitated at the scene and moved all extremities except for his right arm. On arrival, he is unconscious with rapid, shallow respirations. His temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 164/min and thready, respirations are 45/min, and blood pressure is 68/35 mm Hg. Physical examination shows a bony deformity of the right upper extremity and scattered ecchymoses over the chest and abdomen. Cardiopulmonary examination shows no abnormalities except for tachycardia. The abdomen is distended with guarding and rebound tenderness; bowel sounds are hypoactive. Attempts to obtain venous access were not successful. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in the management of this patient?
content_preview: A previously healthy 16-month-old boy is brought to the emergency department after being injured by a dresser falling on him. When the child tried to pull himself up on the dresser, it tipped and fell on his chest and abdomen. He had been awake and agitated at the scene and moved all extremities except for his right arm. On arrival, he is unconscious with rapid, shallow respirations. His temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 164/min and thready, respirations are 45/min, and blood pressure is 68/35 mm Hg. Physical examination shows a bony deformity of the right upper extremity and scattered ecchymoses over the chest and abdomen. Cardiopulmonary examination shows no abnormalities except for tachycardia. The abdomen is distended with guarding and rebound tenderness; bowel sounds are hypoactive. Attempts to obtain venous access were not successful. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in the management of this patient?
hint: This pediatric patient who suffered blunt abdominal trauma presents with tachycardia, tachypnea, hypotension, and ecchymoses over the chest and abdomen, the combination of which indicates hypovolemic shock as a result of internal hemorrhage. He requires immediate fluid resuscitation.
learning_objective: Choose the most appropriate next step in the management of a pediatric patient in hypovolemic shock.

answers.content: Central venous line insertion into the right subclavian vein
answers.explanation_why: Central venous lines (CVLs) can be placed for various reasons, including inadequate peripheral venous access, hemodynamic monitoring, and administration of medication. However, this patient presents with signs of severe hypovolemia requiring immediate fluid resuscitation. Subclavian vein cannulation performed during emergencies is accompanied by a variety of complications such as hemothorax or pneumothorax. In addition, CVL insertion requires ultrasound guidance, which would consume valuable time in an emergency such as this. Lastly, since flow rates in CVLs are relatively low given the length of the catheter, a CVL is not the preferred access for emergency fluid resuscitation.

answers.content: Peripherally inserted central catheter insertion into the left basilic vein
answers.explanation_why: Indications for placement of a peripherally inserted central catheter (PICC) include inadequate peripheral venous access, the need for hemodynamic monitoring, and administration of medications such as vasopressors or chemotherapy, which can cause phlebitis when administered through a peripheral IV catheter. Although high-volume fluid therapy can be administered using central catheters, it is not the preferred vascular access for emergencies because central line placement is usually performed under ultrasound guidance and its proper placement is checked by x-ray, which consumes valuable time.

answers.content: Peripheral intravenous line insertion into the left dorsal hand veins
answers.explanation_why: Peripheral IV line insertion is the preferred venous access for fluid resuscitation in trauma patients. However, obtaining peripheral venous access has already been attempted without success and the patient requires immediate fluid resuscitation. Particularly in pediatric trauma patients such as this one, peripheral IV access should be achieved within 60–90 seconds of arrival. If vascular access cannot be obtained in this time, alternative access routes should be considered because another attempt at placing a peripheral IV line would only delay treatment and risk organ damage or even death.

answers.content: Venous cutdown of the great left saphenous vein
answers.explanation_why: Saphenous venous cutdown is a technique used to obtain emergency venous access. However, venous cutdown is time-consuming and has lower placement success rates and higher infectious complication rates compared to other means of vascular access. Although peripheral venous access could not be obtained immediately in this patient, venous cutdown of the great left saphenous vein should only be attempted if other forms of vascular access have also been unsuccessful.

answers.content: Peripheral venous line insertion into the left external jugular vein
answers.explanation_why: Insertion of a peripheral IV line is the preferred venous access for fluid resuscitation in trauma patients. Although insertion into the left external jugular vein can be performed by experienced physicians, it should not be used as a primary site in children with airway compromise or respiratory failure because it requires extension as well as rotation of the neck, thereby putting the patient at unnecessary risk of exacerbating symptoms. Another attempt of placing a peripheral IV line would only delay appropriate treatment and increase the patient's risk of complications (e.g., organ damage), meaning that alternative access routes should be considered.

answers.content: Intraosseous line insertion into the right humerus
answers.explanation_why: Intraosseous (IO) cannulation permits rapid intravascular access for both pediatric and adult patients and is obtained in emergencies because it has a very high success rate. This patient presents with a deformity of the right upper extremity suggestive of a fracture. IO infusion has few absolute contraindications, which include bone fractures, bones previously punctured by IO cannulation, and extremities with vascular interruption because fluids might extravasate into tissue and put the patient at risk for compartment syndrome. In addition, while the humerus is commonly used for IO line insertion in adults, other locations are more frequently used in children.

answers.content: Intraosseous line insertion into the left proximal tibia
answers.explanation_why: Severe hypovolemia in children requires immediate and rapid IV fluid replacement (20 mL/kg) and continuous monitoring until adequate perfusion is reestablished. Since venous access could not be obtained in this patient, an intraosseous (IO) access should be placed. The proximal tibia is the preferred site for IO lines, especially in pediatric patients, as it has the highest success rate.

question_text: A 28-year-old man is scheduled for skin grafting of the right leg. Four weeks earlier, he underwent open reduction and internal fixation of an open right tibial fracture. The postoperative period at that time was complicated by necrosis of the overlying skin. In the operating room, he is placed on continuous hemodynamic monitoring and anesthetized with intrathecal bupivacaine injected into the L3–L4 spinal interspace. Thirty minutes later, he has severe shortness of breath and lightheadedness and loses consciousness. His temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F), pulse is 38/min, respirations are 24/min, and blood pressure is 82/50 mm Hg. Examination shows flushed skin. He withdraws the upper extremities to painful stimuli above the navel. The lungs are clear to auscultation. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's symptoms?
content_preview: A 28-year-old man is scheduled for skin grafting of the right leg. Four weeks earlier, he underwent open reduction and internal fixation of an open right tibial fracture. The postoperative period at that time was complicated by necrosis of the overlying skin. In the operating room, he is placed on continuous hemodynamic monitoring and anesthetized with intrathecal bupivacaine injected into the L3–L4 spinal interspace. Thirty minutes later, he has severe shortness of breath and lightheadedness and loses consciousness. His temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F), pulse is 38/min, respirations are 24/min, and blood pressure is 82/50 mm Hg. Examination shows flushed skin. He withdraws the upper extremities to painful stimuli above the navel. The lungs are clear to auscultation. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's symptoms?
hint: Hypotension and bradycardia following spinal anesthesia suggest neurogenic shock.
learning_objective: Recognize neurogenic shock, and recall its association with spinal anesthesia.

answers.explanation_why:
Local spinal anesthetics can interrupt the transmission of nerve impulses in spinal sympathetic pathways, causing a loss of sympathetic vascular tone that ultimately results in neurogenic shock. Neurogenic shock is a type of distributive shock characterized by generalized vasodilation (causing flushed skin). This vasodilation leads to decreased preload and subsequently reduced cardiac output, which results in severe hypotension. Bradycardia results from lack of beta-adrenergic activity and is exacerbated by unopposed parasympathetic tone (vagal tone). Consequently, cerebral perfusion is impaired, leading to loss of consciousness as seen in this patient. Treatment for neurogenic shock secondary to spinal anesthesia usually involves IV fluids and pressor therapy until the concentration of anesthetic agent has decreased adequately.

See “Overview of the types of shock” table.

Bacterial toxin-induced vasodilation is the mechanism underlying septic shock. Although septic shock also causes warm, flushed skin secondary to vasodilation during the early, hyperdynamic phase, it is also characterized by increased cardiac output and tachycardia, which are absent in this patient. Also, he does not show signs of active infection such as fever or hypothermia, making septic shock unlikely. In addition, septic shock generally does not develop hyperacutely over the course of minutes as seen here.

answers.content: Obstructive thrombus in the pulmonary artery
answers.explanation_why: An obstructive thrombus in the pulmonary artery results in pulmonary embolism (PE). This patient is at risk of developing thromboembolism given his history of trauma and immobilization of the lower extremity. Although he also has shortness of breath, tachypnea, and hypotension (which may indicate a severe PE), pulmonary embolism generally leads to tachycardia instead of bradycardia. Also, PE would not explain the flushed, diaphoretic skin, which is a sign of venous vasodilation.

Intravascular volume depletion is the mechanism underlying hemorrhagic (hypovolemic) shock. Patients with hemorrhagic shock usually have a history of severe volume depletion or fluid shift (recent trauma, burns, vomiting/diarrhea), which is not the case in this patient. Although hemorrhagic shock can also cause bradycardia and hypotension, reflex tachycardia is usually present as well. Because this patient is bradycardic, hypovolemic shock is unlikely.

answers.content: Bone marrow embolism to the lungs
answers.explanation_why: Bone marrow embolism to the lungs is the underlying pathophysiology of fat embolism. Although this patient's recent open tibial fracture puts him at risk for developing fat embolism, the symptoms of this condition usually develop 12–72 hours after orthopedic trauma/surgery; this patient's surgery was 4 weeks ago. Patients with fat embolism often present with a petechial rash over the head, neck, or thorax, and tachycardia, not bradycardia.

Type I hypersensitivity reaction is the pathomechanism of anaphylactic shock. Although patients with anaphylactic shock also present with shortness of breath and hypotension, they typically have tachycardia, not bradycardia. Other signs of type I hypersensitivity reaction such as urticaria, angioedema, or abnormal lung sounds such as wheezing or stridor are also absent in this patient.

question_text: A 29-year-old man is brought to the emergency department 20 minutes after sustaining a stab wound to the right chest. First responders found the patient sitting on the curb experiencing pain where he had been stabbed. On arrival at the hospital, he is alert. His temperature is 36.8°C (98.2°F), pulse is 110/min, respirations are 16/min, and blood pressure is 112/70 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 97%. Examination shows several 1–2 cm lacerations and ecchymoses over the face and trunk. There is no neck crepitus. A pocket knife is lodged in the fourth parasternal intercostal space and there is a small amount of blood oozing out of the wound. There is no bubbling of the blood at the wound. The lungs are clear to auscultation with equal breath sounds. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Chest x-ray shows the knife in situ extending into the right thorax. Both lungs appear normal; they are homogeneously aerated and have no abnormal opacities. Size and shape of the heart are within normal limits. No fractures or tracheal deviation are visible. Both hemidiaphragms and costophrenic angles are sharply demarcated. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in treatment?
content_preview: A 29-year-old man is brought to the emergency department 20 minutes after sustaining a stab wound to the right chest. First responders found the patient sitting on the curb experiencing pain where he had been stabbed. On arrival at the hospital, he is alert. His temperature is 36.8°C (98.2°F), pulse is 110/min, respirations are 16/min, and blood pressure is 112/70 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 97%. Examination shows several 1–2 cm lacerations and ecchymoses over the face and trunk. There is no neck crepitus. A pocket knife is lodged in the fourth parasternal intercostal space and there is a small amount of blood oozing out of the wound. There is no bubbling of the blood at the wound. The lungs are clear to auscultation with equal breath sounds. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Chest x-ray shows the knife in situ extending into the right thorax. Both lungs appear normal; they are homogeneously aerated and have no abnormal opacities. Size and shape of the heart are within normal limits. No fractures or tracheal deviation are visible. Both hemidiaphragms and costophrenic angles are sharply demarcated. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in treatment?
hint: Further diagnostic workup in a hemodynamically stable patient with penetrating chest trauma usually includes a CT scan of the chest and often echocardiography, ultrasonography, or angiography to better visualize intrathoracic structures. The knife that caused this patient's stab wound is still in situ.
learning_objective: Choose the most appropriate next step in treatment for a patient with a stab wound to the chest and an impaled object.

answers.explanation_why: A needle thoracostomy is helpful in emergency treatment of patients with a tension pneumothorax, which can be caused by lung injury due to penetrating trauma. A patient with a tension pneumothorax will have hypotension, jugular vein distention, tracheal deviation, and absent breath sounds with hyperresonance to percussion on the ipsilateral side. This patient exhibits none of these features.

A tube thoracostomy is indicated in patients with hemothorax or pneumothorax. Hemothorax and pneumothorax result in decreased or absent breath sounds on the ipsilateral side with associated dullness and hyperresonance to percussion, respectively. This patient, however, has normal breath sounds bilaterally and chest x-ray shows homogeneously aerated lungs and sharply demarcated costophrenic angles.

answers.content: Surgical exploration in the operating room
answers.explanation_why: Impaled foreign bodies should be removed under direct visualization in the operating room. As the knife is still in situ, the exact extent of intrathoracic damage is unknown. Although this patient is currently hemodynamically stable, he could have sustained vascular damage that is masked by the knife tamponading the stab wound and preventing hemorrhage at this time. Upon removal of the knife, the patient could hemorrhage and rapidly deteriorate. Emergency surgery is indicated to remove the knife in an environment in which bleeding can be controlled. Therefore, this patient should undergo rapid sequence endotracheal intubation in anticipation of emergency surgery. In hemodynamically stable patients, some surgeons first use video-assisted thoracoscopic surgery to evaluate the situs and, if safe removal of the foreign body is not possible with this technique, proceed to open thoracotomy.

Cricothyroidotomy is used in patients who require emergency airway protection if other interventions have failed to secure the airways. The most common indication is laryngospasm, an obstruction that prevents less invasive airway management. While an emergency procedure is required to remove the in situ knife and manage the injuries, cricothyroidotomy is not the first choice for airway management in this patient because there is no evidence of laryngospasm (e.g., stridor, shortness of breath, tachypnea) and other interventions to secure the airways have not been attempted.

Emergency department thoracotomy (EDT) is a last resort for patients who have sustained life-threatening thoracic trauma and are at immediate risk for, or already in, cardiac arrest and for patients who require immediate hemostasis for exsanguinating vascular or cardiac injuries. EDT is primarily recommended for pulseless patients with signs of life (e.g., measurable blood pressure, spontaneous breathing) following penetrating thoracic trauma. This patient, however, is hemodynamically stable with only minor bleeding from his chest wound; therefore, there is no indication for resuscitative thoracotomy. Although this patient has sustained penetrating thoracic trauma and an emergency intervention is necessary, a different procedure should be performed in a different setting.
