question_text: A 4-year-old girl is brought to the emergency department after a fall from her bed on her outstretched hand 1 hour ago. Her mother says that she has been inconsolable since. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination of the left forearm reveals a mild swelling distally. Her radial arm pulses are strong and symmetric. X-rays of the left forearm and wrist is shown. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
content_preview: A 4-year-old girl is brought to the emergency department after a fall from her bed on her outstretched hand 1 hour ago. Her mother says that she has been inconsolable since. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination of the left forearm reveals a mild swelling distally. Her radial arm pulses are strong and symmetric. X-rays of the left forearm and wrist is shown. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
hint: This patient fell onto her outstretched hand, which is a common cause of distal forearm fractures. The x-ray shows disruption of the distal radial cortex and periosteum on the side of tension (convex side) with an intact periosteum and cortex on the side of compression (concave side). This is characteristic of a greenstick fracture.
learning_objective: Recognize a greenstick fracture, and choose the most appropriate management.

answers.explanation_why: Application of a soft elastic bandage or a removable splint alone may be appropriate for a different type of incomplete fracture called torus fracture, which is stable and associated with minimal to no angulation. Greenstick fractures are inherently unstable, and there is a risk of further displacement without adequate immobilization.

Percutaneous pinning is not appropriate for greenstick fractures involving the distal radius because satisfactory fracture healing can be achieved by less invasive methods. Closed reduction followed by percutaneous insertion of intramedullary Kirschner wires is usually performed for mid-forearm fractures involving both the radius and the ulna, a radial neck fractures, or supracondylar fractures of the humerus.

Although open reduction and internal fixation (ORIF) achieves perfect anatomical reduction of the fracture, it is rarely required in children because any mild deformity that persists after non-surgical treatment is eventually corrected by bone remodeling as the child grows. Pediatric fractures that almost always require open reduction and internal fixation (i.e., fractures of necessity) include lateral humeral condyle fractures, Galeazzi fractures, displaced scaphoid fractures, displaced femoral neck fractures, distal tibial epiphysis fractures, displaced talar neck fractures, and type III or IV Salter-Harris fractures.

Immobilization with a cast is indicated for nondisplaced or only mildly displaced greenstick fractures, as in this patient. Additionally, physical activity should be restricted to enable healing. Closed reduction is required if there is significant angulation or displacement. Greenstick fractures are inherently unstable, and there is a risk of further displacement without adequate immobilization. After initial care, follow-up with an orthopedic surgeon is indicated to assess for complications (e.g., refracture) and to ensure complete reunion. Nondisplaced greenstick fractures usually heal without long-term complications within 4–6 weeks.

images.title: Complete vs. incomplete fractures
images.description: In a complete fracture, there is a discontinuity between the bone fragments, whereas in incomplete fractures, the fracture line is either absent or does not completely traverse the entire bone. Incomplete fractures are more common in children due to their thicker, stronger periosteum and the greater elasticity of growing bones. Types of incomplete fractures include:Buckle (torus) fracture: A compressive force results in bulging, i.e., buckling of the cortex. More specifically, a buckle fracture is characterized by bulging of only one side of the cortex (the concave side), while a fracture in which the bulge is circumferential is referred to more precisely as a “torus fracture.” However, the terms are frequently used interchangeably.Greenstick fracture: There is discontinuity of the cortex and periosteum on the convex (tension) side of the fracture, but bending occurs only on the concave (compression) side.Bowing fracture: There is angulation but no discontinuity of the cortex or periosteum.

answers.explanation_why: Closed reduction is indicated for displaced fractures or if there is significant angulation (> 10° in children aged 0–5 years). Minor angulations in pediatric fractures do not require manual reduction because they are often compensated during remodeling and growth. Greenstick fractures are inherently unstable, and there is a risk of further displacement without adequate immobilization. Splinting does not provide sufficient immobilization for greenstick fractures.

images.title: Greenstick fracture of the distal radius
images.description: X-ray distal left forearm (left: lateral view; right: PA view) of an adolescentA greenstick fracture of the distal radius is seen. The cortex on the radial (lateral) side of the fracture is disrupted and buckled (green overlay). However, the fracture line has not traversed the bone. The ulnar (medial) side of the radius is bowed, but the cortex is intact (black dotted line).Greenstick fractures are incomplete fractures. Typical locations are the shafts of the bones of the forearm and lower leg.Red overlay: growth plate

question_text: A 7-month-old boy is brought to the emergency department by his mother because of a 3-day history of nonbloody vomiting and poor feeding. He transitioned to pureed vegetables 10 days ago. Over the past 2 weeks, he has become increasingly irritable and within the past day has taken more daytime naps and appears much less responsive and interactive. His mother denies any history of fever or trauma at home. He has not received any vaccinations as his parents believe he is already healthy and does not need them. He spends most of the day with a babysitter while both parents are at work. He appears lethargic. His temperature is 37.8°C (100.1°F), pulse is 140/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 90/55 mm Hg. The abdomen is soft and nontender. Auscultation of the heart and lungs shows no abnormalities. The anterior fontanelle is tense and bulging. Fundoscopic examination shows bilateral retinal hemorrhage. A complete blood count shows a leukocyte count of 10,000/mm^3. An x-ray of the chest shows healing fractures of the 2^nd and 3^rd right ribs. Further evaluation of this patient is most likely to show which of the following findings?
content_preview: A 7-month-old boy is brought to the emergency department by his mother because of a 3-day history of nonbloody vomiting and poor feeding. He transitioned to pureed vegetables 10 days ago. Over the past 2 weeks, he has become increasingly irritable and within the past day has taken more daytime naps and appears much less responsive and interactive. His mother denies any history of fever or trauma at home. He has not received any vaccinations as his parents believe he is already healthy and does not need them. He spends most of the day with a babysitter while both parents are at work. He appears lethargic. His temperature is 37.8°C (100.1°F), pulse is 140/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 90/55 mm Hg. The abdomen is soft and nontender. Auscultation of the heart and lungs shows no abnormalities. The anterior fontanelle is tense and bulging. Fundoscopic examination shows bilateral retinal hemorrhage. A complete blood count shows a leukocyte count of 10,000/mm3. An x-ray of the chest shows healing fractures of the 2nd and 3rd right ribs. Further evaluation of this patient is most likely to show which of the following findings?
hint: Retinal hemorrhage and associated rib fractures in a 7-month-old infant should raise concern for child abuse.
learning_objective: Recognize signs of child abuse, and recall the diagnostic finding associated with shaken baby syndrome.

answers.explanation_why: Tumors of the posterior fossa (e.g., juvenile pilocytic astrocytoma) are the most common pediatric primary brain tumors. A mass in the posterior fossa could gradually lead to altered mental status and could also increase intracranial pressure in a 7-month-old child to the extent that the anterior fontanelle would be tense and bulging. However, increased intracranial pressure would more likely be associated with papilledema on fundoscopic examination than retinal hemorrhages. In addition, this child's healing rib fractures should raise suspicion of a traumatic etiology.

The skeletal manifestations of vitamin D deficiency, rickets, can also be associated with pathological fractures of the ribs and other locations. However, this child has no other signs of bony deformities or fractures, and pathological fracture at an isolated location is less common in vitamin D deficiency. In addition, vitamin D deficiency is not associated with this patient's other findings of retinal hemorrhage, bulging anterior fontanelle, and altered mental status.

images.title: Rickets secondary to vitamin D deficiency fact sheet

answers.explanation_why: Bacterial meningitis could lead to altered mental status, which might manifest in the irritability and lethargy seen in this child. Before the anterior fontanelle closes (at 18–24 months of age), increased intracranial pressure (e.g., due to meningitis) can cause it to bulge. Children who are septic from meningitis may also rarely present with retinal hemorrhages. However, bacterial meningitis typically presents more acutely, in a matter of hours or days. Additionally, this child is afebrile and has a normal white blood cell count, both of which are unexpected findings in children with meningitis, particularly in meningitis due to bacterial pathogens.

An epidural hematoma could also lead to irritability, lethargy, signs of increased intracranial pressure, including a bulging anterior fontanelle, and retinal hemorrhage in rare cases. However, retinal hemorrhages are less frequently associated with epidural hemorrhage than other etiologies. Additionally, an epidural hematoma would likely present more acutely and with other physical examination findings, such as a visible hematoma or swelling in the area of head trauma, which this patient does not have. While this diagnosis cannot be excluded completely, a different option is more likely.

Diffuse axonal injury (DAI) is commonly seen in children with shaken baby syndrome (SBS). In such cases, DAI is most likely caused by rotational acceleration-deceleration forces inflicted by violent shaking of the infant and by secondary hypoxia (e.g., due to transient apnea). Long-term deficits resulting from SBS include sight, hearing, and speech impairment. SBS has an extremely high mortality rate, with approx. 25% of affected children dying as a result of sustained injuries. Cranial CT scan in patients with SBS often shows additional brain injuries such as chronic subdural hematoma (which would explain this patient's subacute presentation over 2 weeks), subarachnoid bleeding, and/or diffuse punctate parenchymal hemorrhages.

Osteogenesis Imperfecta (OI) is caused by defective synthesis of type I collagen. Patients with this disorder are prone to pathologic fractures and may present with rib fractures. Skull fractures and associated intracranial bleeding are more common in children with OI and could cause altered mental status in the absence of a history of significant trauma. However, patients with OI often have blue sclera, hearing loss, and joint laxity, which are not present in this patient. Additionally, while OI is often hard to differentiate from child abuse, the low prevalence of OI makes child abuse more likely in the general population.

Many rodenticides contain long-acting anticoagulants, such as super warfarin. Ingestion of these rodenticides can lead to coagulopathy and pathological bleeding, usually beginning about 24 hours after ingestion. This coagulopathy could cause both retinal hemorrhages and intracranial bleeding leading to altered mental status, as seen in this patient. However, coagulopathy would likely also manifest in other locations, causing gastrointestinal bleeding, ecchymoses, epistaxis, and hematuria. This patient does not have any other signs of pathological bleeding, nor would this etiology explain this patient's associated rib fractures.

question_text: A 56-year-old man is brought to the emergency department 25 minutes after he was involved in a high-speed motor vehicle collision where he was the unrestrained passenger. He has severe lower abdominal and pelvic pain. On arrival, he is alert and oriented. His pulse is 95/min, respirations are 22/min, and blood pressure is 106/62 mm Hg. Examination shows severe tenderness to palpation over the lower abdomen and over the left anterior superior iliac spine. There is no limb length discrepancy. Application of downward pressure over the pelvis shows no springy resistance or instability. Rectal examination is unremarkable. There is no blood at the urethral meatus. Placement of a Foley catheter shows gross hematuria. A focused assessment with sonography shows no free fluid in the abdomen. An x-ray of the pelvis shows a stable fracture of the anterior pelvic ring. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
content_preview: A 56-year-old man is brought to the emergency department 25 minutes after he was involved in a high-speed motor vehicle collision where he was the unrestrained passenger. He has severe lower abdominal and pelvic pain. On arrival, he is alert and oriented. His pulse is 95/min, respirations are 22/min, and blood pressure is 106/62 mm Hg. Examination shows severe tenderness to palpation over the lower abdomen and over the left anterior superior iliac spine. There is no limb length discrepancy. Application of downward pressure over the pelvis shows no springy resistance or instability. Rectal examination is unremarkable. There is no blood at the urethral meatus. Placement of a Foley catheter shows gross hematuria. A focused assessment with sonography shows no free fluid in the abdomen. An x-ray of the pelvis shows a stable fracture of the anterior pelvic ring. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
hint: Genitourinary (GU) trauma must always be ruled out in patients with traumatic pelvic fracture, especially when it involves the pubic rami. The presence of lower abdominal pain and gross hematuria further supports a GU trauma.
learning_objective: Recognize genitourinary trauma in the context of pelvic fracture with gross hematuria, and choose the most appropriate diagnostic test.

answers.explanation_why: Although this patient's FAST shows no free fluid in the abdomen, the presence of hematuria after blunt abdominal trauma is a red flag for GU injury and requires further evaluation. When GU trauma is suspected, the GU tract should be assessed, including the urethra, bladder, ureters, and kidneys. Pelvic fractures in combination with gross hematuria should raise concern for bladder injury. Retrograde cystography (or retrograde CT cystography) is the preferred diagnostic test in patients with suspected bladder rupture. Extravasation of contrast on retrograde cystography confirms the diagnosis.

Intravenous pyelography can be used to assess for renal injury. The most frequent indication for IV pyelography is as a confirmatory test if CT scanning is nondiagnostic. Renal trauma can also manifest with hematuria and should be suspected in patients with associated injuries (e.g., rib fractures) or pain and hematoma over the flank. Because renal trauma is less likely in a patient with lower abdominal pain and a pelvic fracture, evaluation of the lower urinary tract must first be conducted.

Renal ultrasonography has poor sensitivity for renal trauma and is not indicated for traumatic genitourinary injury. Additionally, in this patient with lower abdominal pain, bladder rupture is a more likely cause of traumatic gross hematuria and therefore requires immediate investigation before assessing the kidneys.

Retrograde urethrography is a first-line test to assess for traumatic urethral injury in patients with gross hematuria and associated signs of a urethral injury (e.g., blood at the urethral meatus, perineal hematoma). In patients with gross hematuria and no other signs of urethral injury (such as this patient) a single attempt at Foley catheter placement may be performed. Since the catheter was placed successfully in this patient, a urethral injury has virtually been ruled out and further evaluation should focus on more proximal parts of the genitourinary tract.

External fixation of the pelvis is part of the initial management for unstable pelvic fractures. However, this patient's pelvis was stable on examination and the x-ray showed a stable fracture of the anterior pelvic ring.
Cystoscopy is indicated for non-emergent cases of unexplained hematuria, but it is not indicated for traumatic hematuria and could further damage the urinary tract.

question_text: A 23-year-old man comes to the physician because of a whistling sound during respiration for the past 3 weeks. He reports that the whistling is becoming louder, and is especially loud when he exercises. He says the noise is frustrating for him. Two months ago, the patient underwent outpatient treatment for an uncomplicated nasal fracture after being hit in the nose by a high-velocity stray baseball. Since the accident, the patient has been taking aspirin for pain. He has a history of asymptomatic nasal polyps. His temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 70/min, respirations are 12/min, and blood pressure is 110/70 mm Hg. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following would have prevented the whistling during respiration?
content_preview: A 23-year-old man comes to the physician because of a whistling sound during respiration for the past 3 weeks. He reports that the whistling is becoming louder, and is especially loud when he exercises. He says the noise is frustrating for him. Two months ago, the patient underwent outpatient treatment for an uncomplicated nasal fracture after being hit in the nose by a high-velocity stray baseball. Since the accident, the patient has been taking aspirin for pain. He has a history of asymptomatic nasal polyps. His temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 70/min, respirations are 12/min, and blood pressure is 110/70 mm Hg. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following would have prevented the whistling during respiration?
hint: This patient presents with a nasal whistling sound 2 months after sustaining a nasal fracture, suggesting nasal septal perforation.
learning_objective: Recognize nasal septal perforation due to untreated hematoma, and choose the appropriate preventive measure.

answers.explanation_why:
Nasal septal perforation may develop as a sequela of septal hematoma secondary to a nasal fracture. The hematoma disrupts blood flow to the septal cartilage, resulting in ischemia, necrosis, and subsequent perforation. Analgesics with antiplatelet activity such as aspirin should be avoided 48 hours after nasal trauma or surgery as they may precipitate the development of septal hematoma. This patient's prolonged pain after nasal injury may also be a sign of complications such as nasal hematoma and perforation. If a nasal septal hematoma is present, aspiration and drainage should be performed immediately to reduce pressure on the cartilage and prevent complications.

Whistling typically resolves with the placement of a silicone button prosthesis.

images.title: Hematoma of the nasal septum
images.description: Bilateral, firm, balloon-like swelling of the nasal mucosa.

answers.explanation_why: Although the patient has a history of nasal polyps, polyp resection is unlikely to have prevented the whistling. Surgical removal of nasal polyps is only indicated if the patient is symptomatic and a trial with topical or systemic glucocorticoids is unsuccessful. Symptomatic nasal polyps typically manifest with a postnasal drip, bilateral nasal obstruction, and frequently hyposmia or anosmia; their presence is not associated with a whistling sound.

images.title: Chronic Rhinosinusitis with Nasal Polyps
images.description: CT paranasal sinuses (without contrast; coronal plane) of patient with history of asthmaExtensive soft tissue opacification of the ethmoid sinuses (E; outline) and nasal cavity (NC; outline) shows some lobulation (black arrowhead) and evidence of bony erosion (dashed outline). Lobulated soft tissue is also present along the maxillary sinus walls (white arrowheads).

answers.explanation_why: Antibiotic therapy in combination with incision and drainage is indicated in patients with septal abscess. A septal abscess most commonly develops secondary to a septal hematoma (e.g., due to a facial trauma, as seen in this patient) and can also lead to septal perforation. However, septal abscess is a rare complication of nasal injury and would usually manifest with nasal swelling and obstruction, which this patient does not report.

Rhinoplasty may be performed for aesthetic or functional reasons, such as obstructed breathing due to congenital nasal deformities or trauma. However, rhinoplasty is not indicated for the prevention of nasal septal perforation and may even cause the condition if septal hematoma occurs postoperatively.

Septoplasty is indicated to correct nasal septum deviation in patients with pronounced clinical findings such as difficulty breathing, headaches, or facial pain. Septoplasty is also used in the treatment of nasal septal perforation, but it is not used in the prevention thereof. As septoplasty may precipitate the development of septal hematoma, it can in fact contribute to subsequent septal perforation.

question_text: A 28-year-old research assistant is brought to the emergency department for severe chemical burns 30 minutes after accidentally spilling hydrochloric acid on himself. The burns cover both hands and forearms. His temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 112/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 108/82 mm Hg. Initial stabilization and resuscitation is begun, including respiratory support, fluid resuscitation, and cardiovascular stabilization. The burned skin is irrigated with saline water to remove the chemical agent. Which of the following is the most appropriate method to verify adequate fluid infusion in this patient?
content_preview: A 28-year-old research assistant is brought to the emergency department for severe chemical burns 30 minutes after accidentally spilling hydrochloric acid on himself. The burns cover both hands and forearms. His temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 112/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 108/82 mm Hg. Initial stabilization and resuscitation is begun, including respiratory support, fluid resuscitation, and cardiovascular stabilization. The burned skin is irrigated with saline water to remove the chemical agent. Which of the following is the most appropriate method to verify adequate fluid infusion in this patient?
hint: The most important goal of IV fluid resuscitation is to maintain end-organ perfusion while avoiding fluid overload.
learning_objective: Recognize the goal of IV fluid resuscitation in burn patients, and recall the method to verify adequate fluid infusion.

answers.explanation_why: Tachycardia is a common early sign of hypovolemia. However, the heart rate is of minimal utility in assessing fluid resuscitation because even adequately resuscitated burn patients may be mildly tachycardic, likely due to stress hormone (e.g., catecholamine) release.

The Parkland formula is a tool commonly used to estimate fluid requirements during the first 24 hours of care in burn patients. While this is a good tool for estimating this patient's initial fluid requirements, it is merely an estimate. Another method can more accurately verify if fluid resuscitation is adequate. In addition, because of studies demonstrating serious complications from over-resuscitation (e.g., pleural effusions, compartment syndrome), the ATLS and American Burn Association now recommend only giving half of the fluid resuscitation volume that is calculated by the Parkland formula in adults.

The Holliday-Segar formula may be used to estimate maintenance fluid requirements. However, the fluid requirement of patients with burns during the first 24 hours far exceeds the estimate provided by the Holliday-Segar formula. A different method is therefore required to assess adequate fluid requirement during the first 24 hours.

Sphygmomanometric blood pressure monitoring in a burned limb is unreliable, as edema of the area does not allow for the accurate auscultation of Korotkoff sounds. Blood pressure is therefore underestimated. If more fluid were administered to the patient based on a misinterpretation of blood pressure, edema in the limb would worsen, and the risk of pulmonary edema would increase. Also, blood pressure may be normal despite decreased intravascular fluid volume and end-organ perfusion in a patient with an intact vasomotor response and would only begin to decrease once shock sets in. Even intraarterial manometry may be unreliable because of peripheral vasoconstriction by stress hormones (e.g., catecholamines).

Pulmonary capillary wedge pressure (PCWP) may be increased in patients with burns during the initial 12–18 hours as a result of cardiac dysfunction. However, PCWP should not be used to verify if the infused fluid volume is adequate because PCWP is also not a reliable indicator of end-organ perfusion.

Central venous pressure (CVP) should not be used to verify the adequacy of fluid volume infusion, since a decrease in CVP is a relatively late sign of intravascular volume depletion in patients with intact vasomotor reflexes. CVP is thus not a reliable measure of end-organ perfusion.

Urine output is a good indicator of kidney perfusion, which is an indicator of overall organ perfusion. Maintaining organ perfusion is the primary goal of IV fluid therapy in burn patients. Initially, the approximate volume of fluid required may be estimated (e.g., based on the total body surface area involved), however, this is merely a starting point, and IV fluid volume should be titrated to maintain a urine output of 0.5 mL/kg/h in adults (1 mL/kg/h in children). Although heart rate and blood pressure should be monitored in patients with burns, these parameters are not good indicators of overall organ perfusion. If urine output falls below 0.5 mL/kg/h, a 500–1000 mL bolus of crystalloid fluid should be given, and the maintenance infusion rate should be increased by 20–30%.

question_text: A 47-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of urinary and fecal incontinence for 6 hours. Earlier in the day, he fell off a ladder at a construction site and sustained injuries to his back and thighs but did not seek medical attention. He took ibuprofen for lower back pain. His temperature is 36.9°C (98.4°F), pulse is 80/min, and blood pressure is 132/84 mm Hg. Examination shows tenderness over the lumbar spine and bilateral symmetric lower extremity weakness. Deep tendon reflexes are 3+ in the ankles and 2+ in the knees. Rectal tone is decreased. Abdominal ultrasound shows a distended bladder. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
content_preview: A 47-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of urinary and fecal incontinence for 6 hours. Earlier in the day, he fell off a ladder at a construction site and sustained injuries to his back and thighs but did not seek medical attention. He took ibuprofen for lower back pain. His temperature is 36.9°C (98.4°F), pulse is 80/min, and blood pressure is 132/84 mm Hg. Examination shows tenderness over the lumbar spine and bilateral symmetric lower extremity weakness. Deep tendon reflexes are 3+ in the ankles and 2+ in the knees. Rectal tone is decreased. Abdominal ultrasound shows a distended bladder. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
hint: The patient's history of recent trauma and current symptoms are consistent with spinal compression.
learning_objective: Recognize conus medullaris syndrome.

answers.explanation_why: This patient has conus medullaris syndrome as a result of compression of the most distal region of the spinal cord from his recent accident. Conus medullaris syndrome typically manifests with both upper and lower motor neuron signs. Bladder and bowel dysfunction within hours of the injury, hyperreflexia of the ankles, symmetric lower extremity weakness, and back pain are all consistent with this diagnosis (see “Compressive myelopathies” table).

images.title: Conus medullaris and cauda equina syndromes
images.description: 1 (conus medullaris syndrome): disc herniation at L1-L2 with pressure on the conus medullaris2 (cauda equina syndrome): disc herniation at L3-L4 with pressure on the cauda equinaWhile disk herniation has been used to illustrate the process here, any pathology that compresses the conus medullaris or cauda equina can result in these syndromes.

answers.explanation_why: Cauda equina syndrome (CES) can be due to compression of the nerve roots below where the spinal cord terminates, which may be caused by trauma. However, CES typically manifests with asymmetric muscle weakness, decreased reflexes, and saddle anesthesia due to damage of the lower motor neurons, which is not consistent with this patient's symmetric muscle weakness and hyperreflexia. In addition, bowel and bladder dysfunction are late findings of CES and would not be expected within hours of injury. Lastly, because of nerve root compression, the pain usually radiates along the sensory distribution of the nerves affected.

Anterior spinal cord syndrome can manifest with acute motor weakness and bowel and bladder dysfunction as a result of occlusion of the anterior spinal cord artery and ischemia to the corticospinal tracts and autonomic fibers. However, in this syndrome, the spinothalamic tract is also affected, resulting in pain and temperature sensation deficits, which this patient lacks.

Brown-Sequard syndrome manifests with ipsilateral proprioception and vibration sense loss, ipsilateral flaccid paralysis, and contralateral loss of pain and temperature, which are not consistent with the neurological findings in this patient. Instead, this patient has bilateral lower extremity weakness without sensory deficits. Furthermore, a fall is unlikely to result in Brown-Sequard syndrome, which is usually caused by penetrating injuries to the back.

The cerebellum is supplied by the posterior circulation, and a stroke in this region can be due to dissection of the vertebral artery as a result of trauma. However, cerebellar stroke usually manifests with unilateral signs of ataxia, which this patient lacks. In addition, a cerebellar stroke would not explain this patient's bilateral motor weakness, hyperreflexia of the ankles, and bowel and bladder dysfunction.

A spinal epidural abscess can cause cord compression, resulting in symptoms of weakness, bowel and bladder dysfunction, and back pain, which are seen in this patient. However, spinal epidural abscess results in systemic symptoms, such as fever and malaise, which this patient does not have. Furthermore, the absence of common risk factors for epidural abscess (e.g., IV drug use, recent spine procedure, and contiguous soft tissue infection) and the recent trauma suggest another diagnosis.

question_text: A 34-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department following a high-speed motor vehicle collision in which she was the restrained driver. On arrival, she has a cervical collar in place and is unresponsive. Her temperature is 36.7°C (98.0°F), pulse is 70/min, and blood pressure is 131/76 mm Hg. Her pupils are dilated and not reactive to light. She is unresponsive to noxious stimuli. She is intubated, and mechanical ventilation is begun. Serum concentrations of electrolytes, urea nitrogen, and creatinine are within the reference range. Toxicology screening is negative. A CT scan of the head without contrast shows a massive intracranial bleed and a cervical spine injury at the level of C3. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in diagnosing brain death?
content_preview: A 34-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department following a high-speed motor vehicle collision in which she was the restrained driver. On arrival, she has a cervical collar in place and is unresponsive. Her temperature is 36.7°C (98.0°F), pulse is 70/min, and blood pressure is 131/76 mm Hg. Her pupils are dilated and not reactive to light. She is unresponsive to noxious stimuli. She is intubated, and mechanical ventilation is begun. Serum concentrations of electrolytes, urea nitrogen, and creatinine are within the reference range. Toxicology screening is negative. A CT scan of the head without contrast shows a massive intracranial bleed and a cervical spine injury at the level of C3. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in diagnosing brain death?
hint: This patient meets the clinical criteria for brain death (here coma due to a massive intracranial bleed). Neurological examination shows an absent pupillary light reflex, indicating injury to the midbrain. The next step in diagnosis is assessment of damage to the pons.
learning_objective: Recognize the clinical criteria for brain death, and choose the most appropriate diagnostic study.

answers.explanation_why: The oculocephalic reflex is a component of the neurological exam that is usually performed prior to declaring brain death. However, oculocephalic reflex testing requires quickly turning the patient's head to one side and it should not be performed in patients with C-spine injuries. This patient was recently in an automobile accident and has a confirmed cervical spine injury at C3, which is a contraindication to this test.

images.title: Testing the vestibuloocular reflex with oculocephalic maneuver
images.description: Normal: The eyes remain fixed on an object despite rapid, passive movement of the patient's head.Pathological: The eyes remain midorbit during rapid, passive movement of the patient's head; this indicates a defective brainstem reflex.

answers.explanation_why: Electroencephalography is an ancillary test that shows absent brain electrical activity (i.e., flat EEG) in brain death and that may be used to confirm the diagnosis of brain death if the clinical neurological examination is inconclusive or cannot be completed reliably. Prior to performing this test, however, it is necessary to complete a full clinical evaluation of brain death, which has not yet occurred.

Magnetic resonance angiography is an ancillary test in the assessment of brain death used to evaluate for the presence or absence of cerebral blood flow (with the latter being a sign of brain death) if the clinical examination is inconclusive. Prior to performing any ancillary tests, however, this patient requires a full clinical evaluation of brain death, which has not yet occurred.

Deep tendon reflexes are occasionally seen in brain-dead patients who have intact spinal cords, as these reflexes do not require brain activity. Though they should be tested as part of the complete neurological examination, the presence of deep tendon reflexes should not be misinterpreted as evidence of brainstem function and cannot be used to diagnose brain death.

Transcranial Doppler ultrasonography is an ancillary test in the assessment of brain death used to evaluate the cerebral circulation if the clinical examination is inconclusive or cannot be completed reliably. Prior to performing any ancillary tests, however, this patient requires a full clinical evaluation of brain death, which has not yet occurred.

Corneal reflex testing is indicated in this patient as part of a full neurologic workup for brain death. The accepted criteria for this diagnosis are presence of coma (of known cause), absence of a brain-originating motor response (including response to noxious stimuli), cranial nerve areflexia, and apnea. Currently, this patient has only met two of these requirements (coma, absent response to noxious stimuli). The corneal reflex is one of the brainstem reflexes that must be tested (along with the gag reflex, cough reflex, and pupillary light reflex) prior to declaring brain death. If all these reflexes are negative, an apnea test is performed to confirm the diagnosis.

images.title: Interconnection of brainstem reflexes
images.description:
Simplified representation of the pupillary light reflex (II → IIIa), corneal reflex (V → VII), and vestibuloocular reflex (VIII → III)

(II = pretectal area (afferent part of the optic nerve); IIIa = Edinger–Westphal nucleus: III = oculomotor nucleus; V = trigeminal nerve nucleus; VII = facial motor nucleus; VIII = vestibular nucleus)

question_text: A 15-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department one hour after sustaining an injury during football practice. He collided head-on into another player while wearing a mouthguard and helmet. Immediately after the collision, he was confused but able to use appropriate words. He opened his eyes spontaneously and followed commands. There was no loss of consciousness. He also had a headache with dizziness and nausea. Upon arrival, he is no longer confused. He feels well. Vital signs are within normal limits. He is fully alert and oriented. His speech is organized and he is able to perform tasks demonstrating full attention, memory, and balance. Neurological examination shows no abnormalities. There is mild tenderness to palpation over the crown of his head but no signs of skin break or fracture. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step?
content_preview: A 15-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department one hour after sustaining an injury during football practice. He collided head-on into another player while wearing a mouthguard and helmet. Immediately after the collision, he was confused but able to use appropriate words. He opened his eyes spontaneously and followed commands. There was no loss of consciousness. He also had a headache with dizziness and nausea. Upon arrival, he is no longer confused. He feels well. Vital signs are within normal limits. He is fully alert and oriented. His speech is organized and he is able to perform tasks demonstrating full attention, memory, and balance. Neurological examination shows no abnormalities. There is mild tenderness to palpation over the crown of his head but no signs of skin break or fracture. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step?
hint: Transient headache, dizziness, nausea, and confusion at the time of head injury as well as a Glasgow coma scale (GCS) ≥ 13 at least 30 minutes after the injury is consistent with mild traumatic brain injury (TBI).
learning_objective: Recognize mild traumatic brain injury, and choose the most appropriate management for observation and return to activity.

answers.content: Admit to intensive care for intracranial pressure monitoring
answers.explanation_why: Admission to the intensive care unit for intracranial pressure monitoring would be appropriate in patients with severe TBI, for which elevated intracranial pressure is a serious concern due to brain edema and/or bleeding. Severe TBI is characterized by a GCS ≤ 8. However, this patient has a GCS of 14 in the field and a GCS of 15 in the emergency department, indicating mild TBI.

Imaging is not an essential element in diagnosing concussion; it is largely a clinical diagnosis. Imaging would be important, however, in evaluating for intracranial bleeding or skull/facial fracture. This patient has a low likelihood for structural pathology, such as hematoma (epidural or subdural), hemorrhage, or fracture due to the normal physical and mental status examinations. Imaging would provide little benefit and is not the best next step.

Discharge without activity restrictions is inappropriate and against current guidelines. In this scenario, the patient may return to play that same day. Several studies exist showing that return to play without activity restrictions increases the odds of delayed symptom onset and protracted neuropsychiatric consequences.

answers.content: Administer prophylactic levetiracetam and observe for 24 hours
answers.explanation_why: Levetiracetam is a first-line agent for seizure prophylaxis after severe TBI, which manifests with a GCS ≤ 8. This patient has a GCS of 14 in the field and a GCS of 15 in the emergency department, indicating mild TBI. Seizure prophylaxis is thus not appropriate at this time.

answers.content: Administer prophylactic phenytoin and observe for 24 hours
answers.explanation_why: Phenytoin is a first-line agent for seizure prophylaxis after severe TBI, which manifests with a GCS ≤ 8. This patient has a GCS of 14 in the field and a GCS of 15 in the emergency department, indicating mild TBI. Seizure prophylaxis is thus not appropriate at this time.

answers.content: Discharge and refrain from all physical activity for one week
answers.explanation_why: Immediate discharge following mild TBI is inappropriate because patients may develop delayed-onset complications, such as intracranial bleeding. Serial clinical examinations are important for detecting such complications (as evidenced by altered mental status or focal neurological findings). Moreover, refraining from all physical activity is more strict than what is currently recommended. A gradual return to play is thought to be important in recovery from concussion.

answers.content: Observe for 6 hours in the ED and refrain from contact sports for one week
answers.explanation_why:
Observation followed by a gradual return to playing sports is the current recommendation for mild TBI. Observation in the emergency department (ED) for at least 4–6 hours should include serial neurological examination and assessment of GCS. Alterations in mental status or focal neurological signs may indicate more serious underlying pathology, such as intracranial bleeding. Following discharge, this patient should be monitored by a responsible individual for at least 24 hours after injury and return to the ED if there are any neurological changes. Patients should also progress through six stages of a gradual return to sports. As each stage requires at least 24 hours, this patient will need to refrain from contact sports for at least one week.

Neuroimaging is not routinely recommended for mild TBI. If at any point during the observation period the GCS deteriorates to < 13, patients should be reclassified as having moderate TBI or severe TBI and managed accordingly.

question_text: A 12-year-old boy is brought to the physician because of a 6-day history of gradually worsening right knee pain. The pain is exacerbated by movement and kneeling. There is no pain at rest and no history of trauma to the knee. He is concerned because his soccer tryouts are in a few days. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows mild swelling and tenderness to palpation of the right anterior, superior tibia. Extension of the right knee against resistance reproduces the knee pain; flexion is limited by pain. There is no local erythema or effusion of the right knee. A lateral view of an x-ray of his right knee is shown. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's symptoms?
content_preview: A 12-year-old boy is brought to the physician because of a 6-day history of gradually worsening right knee pain. The pain is exacerbated by movement and kneeling. There is no pain at rest and no history of trauma to the knee. He is concerned because his soccer tryouts are in a few days. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows mild swelling and tenderness to palpation of the right anterior, superior tibia. Extension of the right knee against resistance reproduces the knee pain; flexion is limited by pain. There is no local erythema or effusion of the right knee. A lateral view of an x-ray of his right knee is shown. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's symptoms?
hint: In a physically active adolescent, anterior knee pain that is worse with activity and is reproducible with extension against resistance should raise concern for Osgood Schlatter disease.
learning_objective: Recognize traction apophysitis of the tibial tubercle (Osgood-Schlatter disease).

answers.content: Impingement of the infrapatellar fat pad
answers.explanation_why: Impingement of the infrapatellar fat pad between the femoral condyle and the patella may occur if the fat pad becomes swollen secondary to direct trauma, chronic irritation, or hyperextension injury. Patients present with anterior knee pain inferior to the patella, which is typically exacerbated by sprinting or squatting. Examination may show mild swelling and pain on palpation on either side of the patellar tendon (equivalent to position of the fat pad), but is otherwise unremarkable. Pain over the insertion point of the patellar tendon (proximal anterior tibia), as experienced by this patient, does not occur.

Inflammation of the infrapatellar bursa (i.e., infrapatellar bursitis) can be caused by trauma, overuse, or systemic diseases. It manifests with pain that worsens on kneeling and movement (extension/flexion), reduced mobility, as well as localized swelling, erythema, and warmth. The diagnosis is typically established clinically, and, since bursas are not radiopaque, radiography is rarely used other than to rule out fracture. This patient's x-ray findings suggest another underlying cause of his symptoms.

Osteoid osteomas are benign bone tumors seen typically in individuals 10–30 years old. The tumor can develop in any bone, but most commonly affects the metaphyses and diaphyses of long bones (e.g., femur, tibia, humerus) or the spine. The characteristic clinical feature is a persistent, intense, aching pain localized to the site of the lesion that worsens at night. Physical examination often shows pain on palpation that is not exacerbated by movement, unless intracapsular lesions occur. Since this patient has no history of pain at rest or at night, and extension/flexion elicits pain, osteoid osteoma is unlikely.

Chondromalacia patellae can be due to trauma or overuse and affected individuals (often young adults) report vague discomfort of the anterior knee, which is worsened by activity, especially while climbing stairs. Physical examination may show crepitus of the knee. X-ray is usually normal in early chondromalacia patellae since bones are unaffected.

answers.content: Traction apophysitis of the tibial tubercle
answers.explanation_why:
Traction apophysitis of the tibial tubercle occurs in Osgood Schlatter disease, which typically affects adolescent athletes. Overuse (e.g., sports that involve running and jumping) leads to the patellar tendon exerting excessive strain on the tibial tuberosity, which is not yet fully ossified in adolescents and is thus susceptible to detachment. Patients typically present with anterior knee pain localized to the tibial tubercle. Visible swelling of the proximal tibia may also be present. X-ray is usually not required for diagnosis, but may be helpful to rule out differential diagnoses, especially in cases of atypical presentation (e.g., history of trauma, nocturnal pain, pain at rest). This patient's age, history, and x-ray findings of fragmentation and irregularity of the tibial tubercle are all indicative of Osgood Schlatter disease.

Osgood Schlatter disease is usually self-limited. Treatment is therefore primarily conservative, consisting of rest, ice, stretching exercises, and NSAIDs.

images.title: Lateral view of the knee joint

answers.explanation_why: Osteochondritis dissecans (OCD) commonly occurs in males 10–20 years old and is most likely caused by mechanical stress and/or repetitive trauma. The condition manifests with diffuse joint pain during activities and progressive joint stiffness with locking or catching of the joint. On physical examination, range of motion is intact, though palpation of the femoral condyles in the flexed knee elicits pain. OCD can be ruled out since this patient presents with pain over the proximal tibial and not the femoral condyles. Moreover, patients with OCD would have a crescent-shaped radiolucency on the medial femoral condyle, whereas this patient's abnormality is on the tibial tuberosity.

Iliotibial band syndrome (ITBS) is a common overuse injury of the knee caused by repetitive flexion and extension of the knee. Clinically, the condition manifests with sharp pain at the lateral knee when the foot hits the ground while running and constant, dull pain at rest. Physical examination elicits pain if pressure is applied to the lateral femoral epicondyle during passive flexion of the leg. Although this patient has likely been running frequently and has an increased risk for overuse injury, his symptoms are not consistent with this diagnosis. Moreover, radiographs in patients with ITBS usually appear normal.

answers.content: Avulsion fracture of the proximal tibia
answers.explanation_why:
While an avulsion fracture of the tibial tubercle can also manifest with tenderness over the proximal tibia that is exacerbated by movement, it is generally the result of acute trauma, such as forced flexion against a contracted quadriceps muscle (e.g., coming down from a high jump during basketball). Furthermore, an avulsion fracture of the tibial tubercle would result in severe pain even at rest, as well as effusion of the knee joint. This patient's x-ray shows fragmentation, not avulsion fracture, of the proximal tibia.

This patient's condition may predispose him to developing an avulsion fracture of the tibial tubercle.

images.title: Osgood-Schlatter disease
images.description: X-ray knee (lateral view) of an adolescent with a painful swelling below the kneeThe fragmented appearance of the tibial tuberosity (fragments indicated by green overlay) with overlying soft tissue swelling (indicated by arrow) and thickening of the patellar tendon (red overlay) supports a diagnosis of apophysitis at the patellar tendon insertion (Osgood-Schlatter disease).

question_text: A 4670-g (10-lb 5-oz) male newborn is delivered at term to a 26-year-old woman after prolonged labor. Apgar scores are 9 and 9 at 1 and 5 minutes. Examination in the delivery room shows swelling, tenderness, and crepitus over the left clavicle. There is decreased movement of the left upper extremity. Movement of the hands and wrists is normal. Grasping reflex is normal in both hands. An asymmetric Moro reflex is present. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. An anteroposterior x-ray confirms the diagnosis. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
content_preview: A 4670-g (10-lb 5-oz) male newborn is delivered at term to a 26-year-old woman after prolonged labor. Apgar scores are 9 and 9 at 1 and 5 minutes. Examination in the delivery room shows swelling, tenderness, and crepitus over the left clavicle. There is decreased movement of the left upper extremity. Movement of the hands and wrists is normal. Grasping reflex is normal in both hands. An asymmetric Moro reflex is present. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. An anteroposterior x-ray confirms the diagnosis. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
hint: This neonate's physical examination findings (tenderness, swelling, and crepitus over the left clavicle, decreased mobility of the left upper extremity, asymmetric Moro reflex) are consistent with a neonatal clavicle fracture. Both prolonged labor and macrosomia increase the risk of this birth trauma.
learning_objective: Recognize neonatal clavicle fracture, and choose the most appropriate initial management.

answers.explanation_why: Nerve conduction studies are not indicated in cases of uncomplicated neonatal clavicle fracture. This patient's reduced movement of the left upper extremity is most likely a manifestation of pseudoparalysis, not true brachial plexus injury, especially since his hand movement is normal. Decreased ipsilateral extremity movement is believed to take strain off the clavicle and reduce discomfort for the child. If this infant does not recover function by one month of age, a nerve conduction study should be considered to evaluate for underlying nerve damage.
Surgical fixation may be indicated for clavicle fractures in adults, but neonatal clavicle fractures usually do not require surgery.
Physical therapy can enhance recovery for adults with clavicle fractures, but there is no indication for it in neonates.

Parents of a neonate who has a clavicle fracture should be reassured and advised to handle the affected arm gently (e.g., while dressing). To reduce discomfort, the patient's sleeve can be pinned to the front of their shirt with the arm flexed at 90 degrees. Analgesics may also be considered. After 2 weeks, proper healing should be confirmed either via clinical examination (palpable callus formation) or x-ray. The condition usually self-resolves within 2–3 weeks, and long-term complications are not expected.

Neonatal clavicle fracture is most often a clinical diagnosis but an x-ray can be performed to confirm the diagnosis.
Splinting is not indicated for neonatal clavicle fractures.

MRI is not needed for the diagnosis of a neonatal clavicle fracture. Clinical examination is most often sufficient to establish the diagnosis. For uncertain cases, an anteroposterior x-ray is the preferred imaging modality.

question_text: A previously healthy 3-year-old girl is brought to the physician by her parents because she refuses to use her left arm after tripping over a stone that morning on the way to the supermarket while holding her mother's hand. She did not hit the ground. Growth and development are appropriate for age. She appears anxious. Her vital signs are within normal limits. The left forearm is held close to her body in partial extension and pronation. There is no swelling or bruising of the elbow or the forearm. Palpation of the proximal radius produces pain. The child cries on attempting to passively supinate the forearm. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
content_preview: A previously healthy 3-year-old girl is brought to the physician by her parents because she refuses to use her left arm after tripping over a stone that morning on the way to the supermarket while holding her mother's hand. She did not hit the ground. Growth and development are appropriate for age. She appears anxious. Her vital signs are within normal limits. The left forearm is held close to her body in partial extension and pronation. There is no swelling or bruising of the elbow or the forearm. Palpation of the proximal radius produces pain. The child cries on attempting to passively supinate the forearm. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
hint: Unwillingness to use an upper limb in a child < 5 years of age with tenderness on supination but no signs of local inflammation is diagnostic of radial head subluxation. The mother likely pulled her daughter's left arm to keep her from falling.
learning_objective: Recognize radial head subluxation, and choose the most appropriate management.

answers.explanation_why: Ibuprofen and ice packs reduce pain, inflammation, and edema resulting from fractures and sprains. While the patient's pain with arm motion and on palpation of the arm is consistent with a fracture, the absence of edema, bruising, or other physical deformities makes head subluxation the most likely diagnosis. Appropriate treatment of the radial head subluxation resolves the pain without ibuprofen and ice packs, making this answer an inappropriate next step in management.

Radial head subluxation is the most common elbow injury in children < 5 years of age. It results from sudden traction on the outstretched and pronated arm (e.g., from spinning a child by the hand). The diagnosis is usually made clinically; radiologic imaging is generally not indicated if the patient presents with a typical history and clinical features (i.e., arm held in a flexed and pronated position and tenderness on supination). Treatment consists of closed, manual reduction by forced hyperpronation of the forearm. If hyperpronation is unsuccessful, supination of the forearm with the elbow in flexion can be attempted (under certain circumstances, this supination-flexion technique may be attempted first). Following successful reduction, there is typically immediate pain relief. Reduction can be confirmed if clinical control shows a normal range of motion of the elbow.

images.title: Hyperpronation maneuver for reduction of a radial head subluxation
images.description: Photograph showing hyperpronation technique for reducing a radial head subluxation (also known as pulled elbow or nursemaid's elbow)Step one (left image): the child's arm is supported at the elbow and wrist, with the examiner's thumb exerting moderate pressure over the radial head.Step two (right image): the forearm is hyperpronated; a click may be felt as the ligament moves over the radial head

answers.explanation_why: Splinting the elbow is the appropriate management for radius fractures. While the differential diagnosis for radial head subluxation includes fracture, the absence of edema, bruising, or other evidence of physical deformity make this diagnosis unlikely.

Radial head subluxation is the most common elbow injury in children under 5 years old. It results from accidentally pulling the arms of a child too forcefully. This injury alone without bruises or other injuries is not sufficient to warrant concern for child abuse.

answers.content: Obtain x-ray of the elbow and forearm
answers.explanation_why: X-ray may be necessary in atypical or treatment-resistant cases of radial head subluxation. However, imaging is usually not required to diagnose radial head subluxation in patients < 5 years of age who present with a typical history and clinical features.

question_text:
A 44-year-old man is brought to the emergency department 45 minutes after being involved in a high-speed motor vehicle collision in which he was the restrained driver. On arrival, he has left hip and left leg pain. His pulse is 135/min, respirations are 28/min, and blood pressure is 90/40 mm Hg. Examination shows an open left tibial fracture with active bleeding. The left lower extremity appears shortened, flexed, and internally rotated. Femoral and pedal pulses are decreased bilaterally. Massive transfusion protocol is initiated. An x-ray of the pelvis shows an open pelvic fracture and an open left tibial mid-shaft fracture. A CT scan of the head shows no abnormalities. Laboratory studies show:

Hemoglobin
10.2 g/dL

Leukocyte count
10,000/mm^3

Platelet count
250,000/mm^3

Prothrombin time
12 sec

Partial thromboplastin time
30 sec

Serum

 Na^+

125 mEq/L

 K^+

4.5 mEq/L

 Cl^-

98 mEq/L

 HCO_3^-

25 mEq/L

 Urea nitrogen
18 mg/dL

 Creatinine
1.2 mg/dL

The patient is taken emergently to interventional radiology for exploratory angiography and arterial embolization. Which of the following is the most likely explanation for this patient's hyponatremia?
content_preview: A 44-year-old man is brought to the emergency department 45 minutes after being involved in a high-speed motor vehicle collision in which he was the restrained driver. On arrival, he has left hip and left leg pain. His pulse is 135/min, respirations are 28/min, and blood pressure is 90/40 mm Hg. Examination shows an open left tibial fracture with active bleeding. The left lower extremity appears shortened, flexed, and internally rotated. Femoral and pedal pulses are decreased bilaterally. Massive transfusion protocol is initiated. An x-ray of the pelvis shows an open pelvic fracture and an open left tibial mid-shaft fracture. A CT scan of the head shows no abnormalities. Laboratory studies show: Hemoglobin 10.2 g/dL Leukocyte count 10,000/mm3 Platelet count 250,000/mm3 Prothrombin time 12 sec Partial thromboplastin time 30 sec Serum Na+ 125 mEq/L K+ 4.5 mEq/L Cl- 98 mEq/L HCO3- 25 mEq/L Urea nitrogen 18 mg/dL Creatinine 1.2 mg/dL The patient is taken emergently to interventional radiology for exploratory angiography and arterial embolization. Which of the following is the most likely explanation for this patient's hyponatremia?
hint: Hyponatremia that develops after massive hemorrhage is likely dilutional.
learning_objective: Recognize hypovolemic hyponatremia, and recall the role of ADH in its pathophysiology.

answers.explanation_why: In response to renal hypoperfusion, as in this patient with massive blood loss, the kidneys release renin, which ultimately induces physiologic secretion of aldosterone through the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system (RAAS). This increases renal reabsorption of both sodium and water to help maintain blood volume. Serum sodium levels do not typically change because of the concurrent reabsorption of sodium and water.

Pathologic aldosterone secretion occurs in primary hyperaldosteronism, which occurs secondary to adrenal hyperplasia or adrenal adenoma and would be an unlikely coincidental finding given this patient's acute presentation after a motor vehicle collision. Moreover, high systemic aldosterone levels increase renal reabsorption of both sodium and water; serum sodium levels are therefore typically normal. Other typical laboratory findings include hypokalemia and metabolic alkalosis, which this patient does not have. Clinical features include hypertension and features of hypokalemia, including fatigue, muscle weakness, and headache.

Adrenal crisis can occur after trauma in a patient with underlying adrenal insufficiency and can cause hypotension and hyponatremia. However, adrenal crisis also typically manifests with other electrolyte abnormalities, including hyperkalemia and metabolic acidosis. Other clinical features include vomiting, severe abdominal pain, and hypoglycemia.

Syndrome of inappropriate antidiuretic hormone secretion (SIADH) can occur in the setting of cerebral trauma. Although it is possible that this patient sustained head trauma during the motor vehicle collision, another explanation for this patient's hyponatremia is more likely.

A decrease in effective arterial blood volume (e.g., after massive blood loss) results in decreased baroreceptor firing. This leads to compensatory secretion of antidiuretic hormone (ADH), which increases renal reabsorption of free water, thereby diluting serum sodium levels and causing hyponatremia. Management of hypovolemic hyponatremia includes volume repletion with normal saline. Correction of hypovolemia results in decreased ADH secretion, which increases free water excretion by the kidneys, leading to correction of serum sodium levels.

Renal hypoperfusion can cause acute kidney injury, including the renal tubules, which may lead to electrolyte derangements and is a plausible concern in a patient with massive blood loss. However, laboratory values would typically show multiple abnormalities, including hyperkalemia and increases in serum creatinine and blood urea nitrogen.

question_text: Two days after undergoing emergent laparotomy with splenectomy for a grade IV splenic laceration sustained in a motor vehicle collision, a 54-year-old man develops decreased urinary output. His urine output is < 350 mL/day despite aggressive fluid resuscitation. During the emergent laparotomy, he required three units of packed RBCs. He has type 2 diabetes mellitus and is on an insulin sliding scale. His vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows a healing surgical incision in the upper abdomen and multiple large ecchymoses of the superior right and left abdominal wall. His hematocrit is 28%, platelet count is 400,000/mm^3, serum creatinine is 3.9 mg/dL, and serum urea nitrogen concentration is 29 mg/dL. Urinalysis shows brown granular casts. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of these findings?
content_preview: Two days after undergoing emergent laparotomy with splenectomy for a grade IV splenic laceration sustained in a motor vehicle collision, a 54-year-old man develops decreased urinary output. His urine output is < 350 mL/day despite aggressive fluid resuscitation. During the emergent laparotomy, he required three units of packed RBCs. He has type 2 diabetes mellitus and is on an insulin sliding scale. His vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows a healing surgical incision in the upper abdomen and multiple large ecchymoses of the superior right and left abdominal wall. His hematocrit is 28%, platelet count is 400,000/mm3, serum creatinine is 3.9 mg/dL, and serum urea nitrogen concentration is 29 mg/dL. Urinalysis shows brown granular casts. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of these findings?
hint: This condition can be triggered by renal ischemia or nephrotoxic injury caused by toxic substances such as radiocontrast agents, myoglobin, or aminoglycosides.
learning_objective: Recognize acute tubular necrosis as a cause of acute kidney injury.

answers.explanation_why: Acute tubular necrosis is the most common cause of intrinsic acute kidney injury (AKI), accounting for approx. 85% of cases. Prolonged hypotension in association with trauma and surgery significantly increases the risk of renal ischemia, which results in damage to and necrosis of the tubules. Subsequently, patients present with signs of AKI (e.g., oliguria, elevated BUN and creatinine). Renal epithelial cells and muddy brown granular casts that slough off in the tubular lumen are seen on urine microscopy.

Rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis manifests with signs of acute renal injury (oliguria, elevated BUN and creatinine), which are seen in this patient, but also nephritic syndrome and findings of the underlying condition (e.g., pulmonary symptoms in Goodpasture syndrome). Furthermore, instead of brown granular casts in the urine, urine analysis would show nephritic sediment.

Focal segmental glomerulosclerosis (FSGS) is a common cause of nephrotic syndrome. Patients present with heavy proteinuria, pitting edema, hypertension, weight gain, hypoalbuminemia, and hyperlipidemia, which is not consistent with this patient's presentation. Furthermore, this patient does not have any risk factors for FSGS (e.g., heroin abuse, obesity, sickle cell disease, or HIV infection).

Allergic interstitial nephritis is typically caused by a hypersensitivity reaction to drugs, especially NSAIDs, antibiotics, PPIs, and diuretics. It manifests days or weeks after starting treatment with the offending drug, with gross hematuria, flank pain, rash, and eosinophiluria. This patient's clinical features are not consistent with this diagnosis.

Myorenal syndrome resulting in acute kidney injury is a common complication of rhabdomyolysis and crush syndrome. While it is an important differential diagnosis to consider in trauma patients, it typically manifests with diffuse muscle tenderness, highly elevated creatinine kinase, and elevated LDH as well as darkened urine in the absence of RBCs on urine analysis, none of which is seen in this patient.

Acute renal infarction (ARI) is a rare complication of reactive thrombocytosis following splenectomy, and it can manifest with signs of acute kidney injury (e.g., oliguria, elevated creatinine and BUN). However, ARI most commonly develops in patients with severe thrombocytosis (> 1,000,000/mm^3) and/or individuals with preexisting renal impairment, none of which is seen here.

question_text: A 65-year-old African American woman comes to the physician because of severe lower back pain. She has had dull lower back pain for several months, which suddenly became sharp in nature after lifting a heavy bucket of water 2 days ago. The pain is midline and does not radiate. She has had frequent vaginal dryness and hot flashes since menopause at the age of 55 years, for which she is on hormone replacement therapy. She has hypertension, hypercholesterolemia, and hypothyroidism. Her other medications include hydrochlorothiazide, simvastatin, and levothyroxine. She attends a 30-minute power walking class twice a week. She has smoked a pack of cigarettes daily for 40 years. She does not drink alcohol. She does not appear in distress. She is 165 cm (5 ft 5 in) tall and weighs 75 kg (165 lb); her BMI is 28 kg/m^2. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows midline lumbar tenderness. Muscle strength is full and deep tendon reflexes are 2+. Straight leg raising is negative but painful. MRI of the spine shows an acute compression fracture of the L3 vertebral body and an old compression fracture of the L4 vertebra. Which of the following factors in this patient's history is the strongest predisposing factor for her condition?
content_preview: A 65-year-old African American woman comes to the physician because of severe lower back pain. She has had dull lower back pain for several months, which suddenly became sharp in nature after lifting a heavy bucket of water 2 days ago. The pain is midline and does not radiate. She has had frequent vaginal dryness and hot flashes since menopause at the age of 55 years, for which she is on hormone replacement therapy. She has hypertension, hypercholesterolemia, and hypothyroidism. Her other medications include hydrochlorothiazide, simvastatin, and levothyroxine. She attends a 30-minute power walking class twice a week. She has smoked a pack of cigarettes daily for 40 years. She does not drink alcohol. She does not appear in distress. She is 165 cm (5 ft 5 in) tall and weighs 75 kg (165 lb); her BMI is 28 kg/m2. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows midline lumbar tenderness. Muscle strength is full and deep tendon reflexes are 2+. Straight leg raising is negative but painful. MRI of the spine shows an acute compression fracture of the L3 vertebral body and an old compression fracture of the L4 vertebra. Which of the following factors in this patient's history is the strongest predisposing factor for her condition?
hint: This patient is presenting with a spontaneous fracture following mild physical exertion (e.g., lifting objects, bending over, or sneezing/coughing). There is also evidence on imaging of an additional, older compression fracture. In a postmenopausal woman, these pathological fractures are often a result of underlying osteoporosis.
learning_objective: Recognize smoking as a risk factor for osteoporosis.

answers.explanation_why: This patient's age at menopause (55 years) is at the upper end of the typical age bracket. Undergoing menopause late in life is a protective factor against osteoporosis because it means that levels of estrogen, which is bone-protective, also drop later.

Weight-bearing exercise is a protective measure against osteoporosis, as it helps to maintain and increase bone mass. This patient regularly goes power-walking (a moderate impact weight-bearing activity), which can also provide functional benefits. Exercise also improves balance, which reduces the risk of falling and fractures.

Smoking is a risk factor for osteoporosis in both premenopausal and postmenopausal women. The strongest risk factor for osteoporosis in this patient is her 40-pack-year history of smoking.

Screening recommendations for osteoporosis vary. The USPSTF recommends routine screening with dual-energy x-ray absorptiometry for all women ≥ 65 years of age and for postmenopausal patients < 65 years of age who have one or more risk factors, such as prolonged glucocorticoid use, low BMI (< 21 kg/m^2) or weight < 127 lb, alcohol use, or smoking. Other individuals with risk factors for osteoporosis should be assessed using osteoporosis risk assessment tools to determine the need for screening.
The lower the BMI, the higher the risk of lower bone density (e.g., as a result of malnutrition). This patient's BMI is in the overweight range.

Hormone replacement therapy is the second-line treatment for osteoporosis, with bisphosphonate therapy being the first-line treatment. Hormone replacement therapy exerts a beneficial effect on the bone by inhibiting apoptosis of osteoblasts and decreasing osteoclast function.

Hyperthyroidism, not hypothyroidism, is a risk factor for osteoporosis because it causes an accelerated metabolic rate and, subsequently, accelerated bone metabolism. While an excess of thyroid hormones due to medication error cannot be ruled out, this patient does not show any symptoms of clinically manifest hyperthyroidism.

The use of certain diuretics (e.g., loop diuretics) is associated with a decline in bone mineral density. However, this patient takes hydrochlorothiazide, which increases serum calcium levels through decreased urinary calcium secretion and has been shown to attenuate bone mineral loss. This patient's diuretic use would not contribute to declining bone mineral density.

In the African American population, the incidence of osteoporosis is statistically lower than in individuals of Asian, Hispanic, and northern European ancestry. It is therefore considered a protective factor against osteoporosis.

question_text:
A 25-year-old man is brought to the emergency room 20 minutes after being involved in a high-speed motor vehicle collision in which he was the restrained driver. His pulse is 55/min, respirations are 12/min, and blood pressure is 155/70 mm Hg. Breath sounds are shallow. Examination shows multiple head contusions and a 3 cm x 3-cm soft hematoma on his left temporal region. He is intubated and mechanically ventilated, and infusion of 0.9% saline is started. A CT scan of the head shows a left-sided temporal bone fracture with an associated small left subarachnoid hemorrhage. He is taken to the neurosurgical intensive care unit for further management. The decision to intubate this patient was most likely based on which of the following combination of findings?

Eye opening
Verbal response
Motor response

A
To verbal command
Oriented
Obeys commands

B
To pain
Incomprehensible sounds
Abnormal flexion

C
To verbal command
Confused speech
Localizes pain

D
To pain
Incomprehensible words
Obeys commands

E
Open spontaneously
Inappropriate words
Withdraws from pain
content_preview: A 25-year-old man is brought to the emergency room 20 minutes after being involved in a high-speed motor vehicle collision in which he was the restrained driver. His pulse is 55/min, respirations are 12/min, and blood pressure is 155/70 mm Hg. Breath sounds are shallow. Examination shows multiple head contusions and a 3 cm x 3-cm soft hematoma on his left temporal region. He is intubated and mechanically ventilated, and infusion of 0.9% saline is started. A CT scan of the head shows a left-sided temporal bone fracture with an associated small left subarachnoid hemorrhage. He is taken to the neurosurgical intensive care unit for further management. The decision to intubate this patient was most likely based on which of the following combination of findings? Eye opening Verbal response Motor response A To verbal command Oriented Obeys commands B To pain Incomprehensible sounds Abnormal flexion C To verbal command Confused speech Localizes pain D To pain Incomprehensible words Obeys commands E Open spontaneously Inappropriate words Withdraws from pain
hint: In cases of acute trauma, a Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) score ≤ 8 is an indication for urgent endotracheal intubation.
learning_objective: Recall the indications for intubation, and how the Glasgow Coma Scale score is calculated.

answers.explanation_why: A trauma patient who opens their eyes to verbal command, is oriented, and obeys commands would receive a GCS score of 14 (3 for eye opening, 5 for verbal response, and 6 for motor response). A GCS score of 14 indicates only mild head injury and would not be an indication for endotracheal intubation

A patient who opens their eyes to pain, makes incomprehensible sounds, and has decorticate posture (or abnormal flexion) would receive a total GCS score of 7 (2 for eye-opening, 2 for a verbal response, and 3 for motor response). GCS assessment is part of the primary trauma survey in any trauma patient to evaluate neurological status, consciousness, and degree of brain injury. A GCS score of ≤ 8 indicates severe brain injury with a decreasing level of consciousness, which requires emergency endotracheal intubation to protect the patient's airway and reduce the risk of aspiration of gastric contents.

See “Glasgow coma scale” table.

A trauma patient who opens their eyes to verbal command, speaks confused or disoriented words, and localizes pain would receive a GCS score of 12 (3 for eye-opening, 4 for verbal response, and 5 for motor response). A GCS score of 12 indicates only moderate head injury and would not be an indication for endotracheal intubation.

A trauma patient who opens their eyes to pain and makes incomprehensible sounds but obeys commands would receive a GCS score of 10 (2 for eye-opening, 2 for verbal response, and 6 for motor response). A GCS score of 10 indicates moderate head injury and would not be an indication for endotracheal intubation.

A trauma patient who opens their eyes spontaneously, speaks inappropriate words, and withdraws from pain would receive a GCS score of 11 (4 for eye-opening, 3 for verbal response, and 4 for motor response). A GCS score of 11 indicates moderate head injury and would not be an indication for endotracheal intubation.
